analyzed: yatra ca mātaṅga gāminyaḥ śīlavatyaḥ ca gauryaḥ vibhava ratāḥ ca śyāmāḥ padma rāgiṇyaḥ ca dhavala dvija śuci vadanāḥ madirā āmodi śvasanāḥ ca pramadāḥ  atra hi vācyaḥ virodhaḥ tad chāyā anugrāhī vā śleṣaḥ yam iti na śakyam vaktum
translated: Where the women are both elephant-gaited and virtuous, both fair and dark, both passionate and pure-faced like white Brahmins, and both fragrant with wine and fragrant with breath.🔽Here it cannot be said that the contradiction expressed is subordinated to the alliteration,

original: sākṣācchabdena virodhālaṅkārasyāprakāśitatvāt /
analyzed: sākṣāt śabdena virodha alaṅkārasya aprakāśita tvāt
translated: because the figure of contradiction is not directly manifested by the words.

original: yatra hi sākṣācchabdāvedito virodhālaṅkāras tatra hi śliṣṭoktau vācyālaṅkārasya virodhasya śleṣasya vā viṣayatvam /
analyzed: yatra hi sākṣāt śabda āveditaḥ virodha alaṅkāraḥ tatra hi śliṣṭa uktau vācyālaṅkārasya virodhasya śleṣasya vā viṣaya tvam
translated: Where the figure of contradiction is directly conveyed by the words, there it is the domain of the expressed figure of contradiction or alliteration in the case of a double meaning.

original: yathā tatraiva
analyzed: yathā tatra eva
translated: As in the same text:

original: samavāya iva virodhināṃ padārthānām /
analyzed: samavāyaḥ iva virodhinām padārthānām
translated: Like a gathering of mutually contradictory things.🔽As in the example:

original: tathā hisannihitabālāndhakārāpi bhāsvanmūrtiḥ ity ādau /
analyzed: tathā hi sannihita bāla andhakārā api bhāsvat mūrtiḥ iti ādau
translated: Even though the darkness of childhood is present, the form is radiant.

original: yathā vā mamaiva
analyzed: yathā vā mama eva
translated: Or as in my own:🔽The moon, though full, is eclipsed by Rāhu;

original: sarvaikaśaraṇam akṣayam adhīśam īśaṃ dhiyāṃ hariṃ kṛṣṇam /
analyzed: sarva eka śaraṇam akṣayam adhīśam īśam dhiyām harim kṛṣṇam
translated: The all-pervading, imperishable, supreme lord of lords, Hari Krishna,

original: caturātmānaṃ niṣkriyam arimathanaṃ namata cakradharam //
analyzed: catur ātmānam niṣkriyam ari mathanam namata cakradharam
translated: I bow to the four-formed, actionless, enemy-destroyer, the wielder of the discus.

original: atra hi śabdaśaktimūlānusvānarūpo virodhaḥ sphuṭam eva pratīyate /
analyzed: atra hi śabda śakti mūla anusvāna rūpaḥ virodhaḥ sphuṭam eva pratīyate
translated: Here, the contradiction based on the resonance rooted in the power of the word is clearly perceived.

original: evaṃvidho vyatireko 'pi dṛśyate /
analyzed: evaṃvidhaḥ vyatirekaḥ pi dṛśyate
translated: Such a vyatireka (negative concomitance) is also seen.

original: yathā mamaiva
analyzed: yathā mama eva
translated: As in my own

original: khaṃ ye 'tyujjvalayanti lūnatamaso ye vā nakhodbhāsino
analyzed: kham ye ti ujjvalayanti lūna tamasaḥ ye vā nakha udbhāsinaḥ
translated: Those who greatly illuminate the sky, having cut off the darkness, or those shining with nails,

original: ye puṣṇanti saroruhaśriyam api kṣiptābjabhāsaś ca ye /
analyzed: ye puṣṇanti saroruha śriyam api kṣipta abja bhāsaḥ ca ye
translated: Those who nourish the beauty of the lotus, even those who throw the radiance of the lotus,

original: ye mūrdhasv avabhāsinaḥ kṣitibhṛtāṃ ye cāmarāṇāṃ śirāṃ
analyzed: ye mūrdhasu avabhāsinaḥ kṣitibhṛtām ye ca amarāṇām śirām
translated: Those who shine on the heads of the mountain kings, and those who ascend the heads of the immortals,

original: syākrāmanty ubhaye 'pi te dinapateḥ pādāḥ śriye santu vaḥ //
analyzed: sya ākrāmanti ubhaye te dinapateḥ pādāḥ śriye santu vaḥ
translated: May both of them, the feet of the sun god, be for your glory.

original: evam anye 'pi śabdaśaktimūlānusvānarūpavyaṅgyadhvaniprakārāḥ santi te sahṛdayaiḥ svayam anusartavyāḥ /
analyzed: evam anye pi śabda śakti mūla anusvāna rūpa vyaṅgya dhvani prakārāḥ santi te sahṛdayaiḥ svayam anusartavyāḥ
translated: Thus, there are other types of dhvani based on the resonance rooted in the power of the word, which should be followed by the connoisseurs themselves.

original: iha tu granthavistarabhayān na tatprapañcaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: iha tu grantha vistara bhayāt na tad prapañcaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: But here, out of fear of the length of the text, that elaboration has not been done.

original: arthaśaktyudbhavas tv anyo yatrārthaḥ sa prakāśate /
analyzed: artha śakti udbhavaḥ tu anyaḥ yatra arthaḥ sa prakāśate
translated: But another is born from the power of meaning, where the meaning shines,

original: yas tātparyeṇa vastv anyad vyanakty uktiṃ vinā svataḥ // / //
analyzed: yaḥ tātparyeṇa vastu anyat vyanakti uktim vinā svatas
translated: which, by its very nature, suggests another fact without the help of any other word.

original: yatrārthaḥ svasāmarthyād arthāntaram abhivyanakti śabdavyāpāraṃ vinaiva so 'rthaśaktyudbhavo nāmānusvānopamavyaṅgyo dhvaniḥ /
analyzed: yatra arthaḥ sva sāmarthyāt artha antaram abhivyanakti śabda vyāpāram vinā eva saḥ rtha śakti udbhavaḥ nāma anusvāna upama vyaṅgyaḥ dhvaniḥ
translated: When a fact, by its own force, suggests another fact without the operation of any word, it is called dhvani arising from the force of the meaning. It is suggested by the anuprāsa type of dhvani.

original: yathā ku /saṃ / /
analyzed: yathā kusam
translated: For example, in the verse of Kusa-Samhita:

original: evaṃ vādini devarṣau pārśve pitur adhomukhī /
analyzed: evam vādini devarṣau pārśve pituḥ adhomukhī
translated: When the divine sage was speaking thus, Parvati, with her face down,

original: līlākamalapatrāṇi gaṇayāmāsa pārvatī //
analyzed: līlā kamala patrāṇi gaṇayāmāsa pārvatī
translated: was counting the petals of the playful lotus by the side of her father.

original: atra hi līlākamalapatragaṇanam upasarjanīkṛtasvarūpaṃ śabdavyāpāraṃ vinaivārthāntaraṃ vyabhicāribhāvalakṣaṇaṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: atra hi līlā kamala patra gaṇanam upasarjanīkṛta svarūpam śabda vyāpāram vinā eva artha antaram vyabhicāri bhāva lakṣaṇam prakāśayati
translated: Here, the counting of the petals of the playful lotus, which is of secondary nature, reveals another fact characterized by the variable emotion without the operation of any word.

original: na cāyam alakṣyakramavyaṅgyasyaiva dhvaner viṣayaḥ /
analyzed: na ca ayam alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya eva dhvaneḥ viṣayaḥ
translated: And this is not the subject matter of dhvani that is suggested by the imperceptible sequence.

original: yato yatra sākṣacchabdaniveditebhyo vibhāvānubhāvavyabhicāribhyo rasādīnāṃ pratītiḥ /
analyzed: yatas yatra sākṣat śabda niveditebhyaḥ vibhāva anubhāva vyabhicāribhyaḥ rasa ādīnām pratītiḥ
translated: Because where the rasa etc. are cognized from the vibhāvas, anubhāvas and vyabhicāribhāvas directly indicated by words,

original: sa tasya kevalasya mārgaḥ /
analyzed: sa tasya kevalasya mārgaḥ
translated: that is the only path of that (dhvani).

original: yathā kumārasambhave madhuprasaṅge vasantapuṣpābharaṇaṃ vahantyā devyā āgamanādivarṇanaṃ
analyzed: yathā kumārasambhave madhuprasaṅge vasanta puṣpa ābharaṇam vahantyāḥ devyāḥ āgamana ādi varṇanam
translated: For example, in the Madhu-prasanga of Kumara-samhava, the description of the arrival etc. of the goddess wearing the spring flower ornaments,

original: manobhavaśarasandhānaparyantaṃ śambhoś ca parivṛttadhairyasya ceṣṭāviśeṣavarṇanādi
analyzed: manobhava śara sandhāna paryantam śambhoḥ ca parivṛtta dhairyasya ceṣṭā viśeṣa varṇana ādi
translated: The description of the special activities of Śiva, whose steadfastness has been shaken, up to the joining of the arrows of Kāma,

original: sākṣacchabdaniveditam /
analyzed: sākṣat śabda niveditam
translated: is directly indicated by the words.

original: tasmād ayam anyo dhvaneḥ prakāraḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt ayam anyaḥ dhvaneḥ prakāraḥ
translated: Therefore, this is another type of dhvani.

original: yatra ca śabdavyāpārasahāyo 'rtho 'rthāntarasya vyañjakatvenopādīyate sa nāsya dhvaner viṣayaḥ / yathā
analyzed: yatra ca śabda vyāpāra sahāyaḥ rthaḥ rtha antarasya vyañjaka tvena upādīyate sa na asya dhvaneḥ viṣayaḥ yathā
translated: And where the meaning, assisted by the operation of the word, is employed as the revealer of another meaning, that is not the domain of this dhvani. For example,

original: saṅketakālamanasaṃ viṭaṃ jñātvā vidagdhayā /
analyzed: saṅketa kāla manasam viṭam jñātvā vidagdhayā
translated: knowing that the libertine has his mind on the time of the rendezvous,🔽the clever one,🔽with a wink,

original: hasannetrārpitākūtaṃ līlāpadmaṃ nimīlitam //
analyzed: hasat netra arpita ākūtam līlā padmam nimīlitam
translated: closed the lotus of her sport.

original: atra līlākamalanimīlanasya vyañjakatvam uktyaiva niveditam // / //
analyzed: atra līlā kamala nimīlanasya vyañjaka tvam uktyā eva niveditam
translated: Here, the revealing of the closing of the lotus of sport is indicated by the statement itself.

original: tathā ca
analyzed: tathā ca
translated: And so,

original: śabdārthaśaktyā kṣipto 'pi vyaṅgyo 'rthaḥ kavinā punaḥ /
analyzed: śabda artha śaktyā kṣiptaḥ u pi vyaṅgyaḥ rthaḥ kavinā punar
translated: even when suggested meaning is projected by the power of the word or meaning or both,

original: yatrāviṣkriyate svoktyā sānyaivālaṅkṛtir dhvaneḥ // / //🔽śabdaśaktyārthaśaktyā śabdārthaśaktyā vākṣipto 'pi vyaṅgyo 'rthaḥ kavinā punaryatra svoktyā prakāśīkriyate so 'smād anusvānopamavyaṅgyād
analyzed: yatra āviṣkriyate sva uktyā sā anyā eva alaṅkṛtiḥ dhvaneḥ  śabda śaktyā artha śaktyā śabda artha śaktyā vā ākṣiptaḥ pi vyaṅgyaḥ rthaḥ kavinā punar yatra sva uktyā prakāśīkriyate saḥ u smāt anusvāna upama vyaṅgyāt
translated: where the poet again reveals it by his own statement, that is a different figure from dhvani, which is like an echo.

original: dhvaner anya evālaṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: dhvaneḥ anyaḥ eva alaṅkāraḥ
translated: Even when the suggested meaning is projected by the power of the word, the power of the meaning, or the power of both the word and meaning, where the poet again reveals it by his own statement, that is a different figure from dhvani, which is like an echo.

original: alakṣyakramavyaṅgyasya vā dhvaneḥ sati sambhave sa tādṛg anyo 'laṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya vā dhvaneḥ sati sambhave sa tādṛś anyaḥ laṅkāraḥ
translated: Or, when there is a possibility of dhvani, which is manifested by an imperceptible sequence, that other figure is of that kind.

original: tatra śabdaśaktyā yathā
analyzed: tatra śabda śaktyā yathā
translated: Among them, by the power of the word, it is like this:

original: vatse mā gā viṣādaṃ śvasanam urujavaṃ santyajordhvapravṛttaṃ
analyzed: vatse mā gāḥ viṣādam śvasanam uru javam santyaja ūrdhva pravṛttam
translated: O child, do not go to grief, abandon the long and upward-moving breath,

original: kampaḥ ko vā gurus te bhavatu balabhidā jṛmbhitenātra yāhi /
analyzed: kampaḥ kaḥ vā guruḥ te bhavatu balabhidā jṛmbhitena atra yāhi
translated: what tremor or heaviness can there be for you? Go by yawning, which conquers weakness.

original: pratyākhyānaṃ surāṇām iti bhayaśamanacchadmanā kārayitvā
analyzed: pratyākhyānam surāṇām iti bhaya śamana chadmanā kārayitvā
translated: Having caused the gods to be rejected under the pretext of dispelling fear,

original: yasmai lakṣmīmadād vaḥ sa dahatu duritaṃ manthamūḍhāṃ payodhiḥ //
analyzed: yasmai lakṣmī madāt vaḥ sa dahatu duritam mantha mūḍhām payodhiḥ
translated: may that ocean, which gave you Lakshmi, burn away your sins, deluded in churning you.

original: arthaśaktyā yathā
analyzed: artha śaktyā yathā
translated: By the power of the meaning, it is like this:

original: ambā śete 'tra vṛddhā pariṇatavayasām agraṇīr atra tāto
analyzed: ambā śete tra vṛddhā pariṇata vayasām agraṇīḥ atra
translated: Mother sleeps here, the aged, the foremost of those in the prime of life, father is here,

original: niḥśeṣāgārakarmaśramaśithilatanuḥ kumbhadāsī tathātra /
analyzed: niḥśeṣa āgāra karma śrama śithila tanuḥ kumbhadāsī tathā atra
translated: and the potter's wife, whose body is relaxed from the fatigue of household work, is here.

original: asmin pāpāham ekā katipayadivasaproṣitaprāṇanāthā
analyzed: asmin pāpa aham ekā katipaya divasa proṣita prāṇa nāthā
translated: I, the sinful one, am alone here, my husband away for a few days,

original: pānthāyetthaṃ taruṇyā kathitam avasaravyāhṛtivyājapūrvam //
analyzed: pānthāya ittham taruṇyā kathitam avasara vyāhṛti vyāja pūrvam
translated: thus a young woman spoke to a traveler, under the pretext of making a timely remark.

original: ubhayaśaktyā /
analyzed: ubhaya śaktyā
translated: By the power of both,

original: yathādṛṣṭyā keśavagoparāgahṛtayā ity ādau // / //
analyzed: yathā dṛṣṭyā keśava gopa rāga hṛtayā iti ādau
translated: as in By the eye that sees as it is, taken away by the affection for Keshava and Gopala, etc.

original: prauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīraḥ sambhavī svataḥ /
analyzed: prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīraḥ sambhavī svatas
translated: The embodied one, born of the mere statement of the mature, is possible by itself.

original: artho 'pi dvividho jñeyo vastuno 'nyasya dīpakaḥ // / //
analyzed: dvividhaḥ jñeyaḥ vastunaḥ nyasya dīpakaḥ
translated: The object also is to be known as of two kinds, one that illuminates another object, and the other that does not.

original: arthaśaktyudbhavānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgye dhvanau yo vyañjako 'rtha uktas tasyāpi dvau prakāraukaveḥ kavinibaddhasya vā vaktuḥ prauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīra
analyzed: artha śakti udbhava anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgye dhvanau yaḥ vyañjakaḥ rthaḥ uktaḥ tasya api dvau prakārau kaveḥ kavi nibaddhasya vā vaktuḥ prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīra
translated: In the case of dhvani, which consists of suggestion in the form of an echo produced by the power of the object, the suggestive object has been said to be of two kinds: one having its body produced merely by the bold assertion of the poet or the speaker, and

original: svataḥsambhavī ca dvitīyaḥ /🔽kaviprauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīro yathā
analyzed: svataḥsambhavī ca dvitīyaḥ  kavi prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīraḥ yathā
translated: the other, the natural one, as the second.🔽That having its body produced merely by the bold assertion of the poet is as follows:🔽The fragrant month is preparing, not yet🔽giving the targets for the arrows of love to the young women.

original: sajjehi surahimāso ṇa dāva
analyzed: sajjehi surahi māsaḥ ṇa dāva
translated: The arrows of love, with faces like fresh mangoes,

original: appei juvaijaṇalakkhasuhe /🔽ahiṇavasahaāramuhe🔽ṇavapattale aṇaṅgassa sare //
analyzed: appei  ahi nava saha āra muhe  ṇava pattale aṇaṅgassa sare
translated: with new leaves, are not yet ready.

original: sajjayati surabhimāso na tāvad
analyzed: sajjayati surabhi māsaḥ na tāvat
translated: The fragrant month is preparing, not yet

original: arpayati yuvatijanalakṣyasahān /
analyzed: arpayati yuvati jana lakṣya sahān
translated: giving the targets for the arrows of love to the young women.

original: abhinavasahakāramukhān
analyzed: abhinava sahakāra mukhān
translated: The arrows of love, with faces like fresh mangoes,

original: navapatralān anaṅgasya śarān //
analyzed: nava patralān anaṅgasya śarān
translated: with new leaves, are not yet ready.

original: kavinibaddhavaktṛprauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīro yathodāhṛtam evaśikhariṇi ity ādi / yathā vā
analyzed: kavi nibaddha vaktṛ prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīraḥ yathā udāhṛtam eva śikhariṇi iti ādi yathā vā
translated: That having its body produced merely by the bold assertion of the speaker employed by the poet is as has been cited already, beginning with O you who are crested with matted hair, or as follows:🔽Your breasts seem to give rise to the uprising

original: sādaravitīrṇayauvanahastālambaṃ samunnamadbhyām /🔽abhyutthānam iva manmathasya dattaṃ tava stanābhyām //
analyzed: sa ādara vitīrṇa yauvana hasta ālambam samunnamadbhyām 🔽abhyutthānam iva manmathasya dattam tava stanābhyām
translated: of love, with hands of youthfulness respectfully offered and raised up.

original: svataḥ sambhavī ya aucityena bahir api sambhāvyamānasadbhāvo na kevalaṃ bhaṇitivaśenaivābhiniṣpannaśarīraḥ /
analyzed: svatas sambhavī yaḥ aucityena bahis api sambhāvyamāna sadbhāvaḥ na kevalam bhaṇiti vaśena eva abhiniṣpanna śarīraḥ
translated: That which is self-existent, which is possible externally also by propriety, and whose body is accomplished not merely by the power of expression,

original: yathodāhṛtam evaṃvādini ity ādi / yathā vā
analyzed: yathā udāhṛtam evaṃvādini iti ādi yathā vā
translated: as has been cited, When he spoke thus, or as

original: śikhipicchakarṇapūrā jāyā vyādhasya garviṇī bhramati /
analyzed: śikhi piccha karṇapūrā jāyā vyādhasya garviṇī bhramati
translated: The wife of the hunter, with peacock feathers in her ears, is proud and wanders about,

original: muktāphalaracitaprasādhanānāṃ madhye sapatnīnām // / //
analyzed: muktāphala racita prasādhanānām madhye sapatnīnām
translated: In the midst of her co-wives adorned with pearls.

original: arthaśakter alaṅkāro yatrāpy anyaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: artha śakteḥ alaṅkāraḥ yatra api anyaḥ pratīyate
translated: Where another figure of speech is suggested by the power of the meaning,

original: anusvānopamavyaṅgyaḥ sa prakāro 'paro dhvaneḥ // / //
analyzed: anusvāna upama vyaṅgyaḥ sa paraḥ dhvaneḥ
translated: That type of dhvani is said to be suggestively conveyed like an echo.

original: vācyālaṅkāravyatirikto yatrānyo 'laṅkāro 'rthasāmarthyāt pratīyamāno 'vabhāsate so 'rthaśaktyudbhavo nāmānusvānarūpavyaṅgyo 'nyo dhvaniḥ
analyzed: vācya alaṅkāra vyatiriktaḥ yatra anyaḥ laṅkāraḥ rtha sāmarthyāt pratīyamānaḥ vabhāsate saḥ rtha śakti udbhavaḥ nāma anusvāna rūpa vyaṅgyaḥ nyaḥ dhvaniḥ
translated: Where another figure of speech, different from the expressed figure of speech, appears to be suggested by the power of the meaning, that is another type of dhvani, arising from the power of the meaning, suggestively conveyed like an echo.

original: tasya praviralaviṣayatvam āśaṅkyedam ucyate
analyzed: tasya pravirala viṣaya tvam āśaṅkya idam ucyate
translated: Fearing that its scope is limited, this is said:

original: rūpakādir alaṅkāravargo yo vācyatāṃ śritaḥ /
analyzed: rūpaka ādiḥ alaṅkāra vargaḥ yaḥ vācya tām śritaḥ
translated: That class of figures of speech beginning with metaphor, which is based on the expressed meaning,

original: sa sarvo gamyamānatvaṃ bibhrad bhūmnā pradarśitaḥ // / //
analyzed: sa sarvaḥ gamyamāna tvam bibhrat bhūmnā pradarśitaḥ
translated: All that is shown by the great one to bear the nature of being conveyed.

original: anyatra vācyatvena prasiddho yo rūpakādir alaṅkāraḥ so 'nyatra pratīyamānatayā bāhulyena pradarśitas tatrabhavadbhir bhaṭṭodbhaṭādibhiḥ /
analyzed: anyatra vācya tvena prasiddhaḥ yaḥ rūpaka ādiḥ alaṅkāraḥ saḥ nyatra pratīyamāna tayā bāhulyena pradarśitaḥ tatrabhavadbhiḥ bhaṭṭodbhaṭa ādibhiḥ
translated: Other figures of speech, such as metaphor, which are well-known as being denoted elsewhere, are shown by you, Bhatta Lollaṭa and others, to be mostly suggested elsewhere.

original: tathā ca sasandehādiṣūpamārūpakātiśayoktīnāṃ prakāśamānatvaṃ pradarśitam ity alaṅkārāntarasyālaṅkārāntare vyaṅgyatvaṃ na yatnapratipādyam
analyzed: tathā ca sa sandeha ādiṣu upamā rūpaka atiśayoktīnām prakāśamāna tvam pradarśitam iti alaṅkāra antarasya alaṅkāra antare vyaṅgya tvam na yatna pratipādyam
translated: And thus the presence of simile, metaphor and hyperbole in doubt and other figures is shown. So the fact that one figure of speech is suggested by another figure of speech does not need to be laboriously demonstrated.

original: iyat punar ucyata eva🔽alaṅkārāntarasyāpi pratītau yatra bhāsate /
analyzed: iyat punar ucyate eva  alaṅkāra antarasya api pratītau yatra bhāsate
translated: This much, however, is said:🔽Where, even when another figure of speech is suggested,

original: tatparatvaṃ na vācyasya nāsau mārgo dhvaner mataḥ // / //
analyzed: tad para tvam na vācyasya na asau mārgaḥ dhvaneḥ mataḥ
translated: the beauty of the denoted sense does not shine forth, that is not considered the path of suggestion.

original: alaṅkārāntareṣu tv anuraṇanarūpālaṅkārapratītau satyām api yatra vācyasya vyaṅgyapratipādanaunmukhyena cārutvaṃ na prakāśate nāsau dhvaner 🔽mārgaḥ /
analyzed: alaṅkāra antareṣu tu anuraṇana rūpa alaṅkāra pratītau satyām api yatra vācyasya vyaṅgya pratipādana aunmukhyena cāru tvam na prakāśate na asau dhvaneḥ  mārgaḥ
translated: But in other figures of speech, even when the figure of repetition is suggested, if the beauty of the denoted sense does not shine forth with a tendency to suggest the suggested sense, that is not the path of suggestion.

original: tathā ca dīpakādāv alaṅkāre upamāyā gamyamānatve 'pi tatparatvena cārutvasyāvyavasthānān na dhvanivyapadeśaḥ / yathā
analyzed: tathā ca dīpaka ādau alaṅkāre upamāyāḥ gamyamāna tve pi tad para tvena cāru tvasya avyavasthānāt na dhvani vyapadeśaḥ yathā
translated: And thus, even when simile is understood in a figure of speech such as paronomasia, since the beauty based on that is not established, it is not called dhvani. For example:

original: candamaūehiṃ ṇimā ṇalinī kamalehiṃ kusumagucchehiṃ laā /
analyzed: canda maūehim ṇimā ṇalinī kamalehim kusuma gucchehim laā
translated: By the moonbeams, the night; by the lotus-flowers, the lotus-plant; by the clusters of flowers, the creeper.

original: haṃsehiṃ saraasohā kavvakahā sajjanehiṃ karai garuī //
analyzed: haṃsehiṃ saraa sohā sajjanehiṃ karai
translated: By the swans, the beauty of autumn; by the poetry, the story; by the good people, the respect is created.

original: candramayūkhair niśā nalinī kamalaiḥ kusumagucchair latā /
analyzed: candra mayūkhaiḥ niśā nalinī kamalaiḥ kusuma gucchaiḥ latā
translated: By the moonbeams, the night; by the lotus-flowers, the lotus-plant; by the clusters of flowers, the creeper.

original: haṃsaiḥ śāradaśobhā kāvyakathā sajjanaiḥ kriyate gurvī //
analyzed: haṃsaiḥ śārada śobhā kāvya kathā sat janaiḥ kriyate gurvī
translated: By the swans, the beauty of autumn; by the poetry, the story; by the good people, the respect is created.

original: ity ādiṣūpamāgarbhatve 'pi sati vācyālaṅkāramukhenaiva cārutvaṃ vyavatiṣṭhate na vyaṅgyālaṅkāratātparyeṇa /
analyzed: iti ādiṣu upamā garbha tve sati vācya alaṅkāra mukhena eva cāru tvam vyavatiṣṭhate na vyaṅgya alaṅkāra tātparyeṇa
translated: Thus, even when there is an implication of simile, the beauty is established only through the face of the expressed ornament, not through the intention of the suggested ornament.

original: tasmāt tatra vācyālaṅkāramukhenaiva kāvyavyapadeśo nyāyyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tatra vācya alaṅkāra mukhena eva kāvya vyapadeśaḥ nyāyyaḥ
translated: Therefore, in that case, the designation of poetry is proper only through the face of the expressed ornament.

original: yatra tu vyaṅgyaparatvenaiva vācyasya vyavasthānaṃ tatra vyaṅgyamukhenaiva vyapadeśo yuktaḥ / yathā
analyzed: yatra tu vyaṅgya para tvena eva vācyasya vyavasthānam tatra vyaṅgya mukhena eva vyapadeśaḥ yuktaḥ yathā
translated: But where the expressed meaning is established only through the intention of the suggested meaning, there the designation is proper only through the suggested meaning. For example:

original: prāptaśrīr eṣa kasmāt punar api mayi taṃ manthakhedaṃ vidadhyān
analyzed: prāpta śrīḥ eṣa kasmāt punar api mayi tam mantha khedam vidadhyān
translated: Having attained prosperity, why would he again inflict that pain of churning on me?

original: nidrām apy asya pūrvām analamanaso naiva sambhāvayāmi /
analyzed: nidrām api asya pūrvām anala manasaḥ nā eva sambhāvayāmi
translated: I do not even consider it possible that he would first fall asleep, his mind not at peace.

original: setuṃ badhnāti bhūyaḥ kim iti ca sakaladvīpanāthānuyātas
analyzed: setum badhnāti bhūyas kim iti ca sakala dvīpa nātha anuyātaḥ
translated: Why does he again build a dam, followed by the lords of all the islands?

original: tvayy āyāte vitarkāniti dadhata ivābhāti kampaḥ payodheḥ //
analyzed: tvayi āyāte vitarkān iti dadhataḥ iva ābhāti kampaḥ payodheḥ
translated: as if the ocean were trembling, thinking: 'When you come, my waves will be gone.'

original: yathā vā mamaiva🔽lāvaṇyakāntiparipūritadiṅmukhe 'smin
analyzed: yathā vā mama eva  lāvaṇya kānti paripūrita diṅmukhe smin
translated: Or, as in one of my own [verses]:🔽In this world filled with the beauty and loveliness of your face,

original: smere 'dhunā tava mukhe taralāyatākṣi /
analyzed: smere dhunā tava mukhe tarala āyata akṣi
translated: O you with restless long eyes, now smiling,

original: kṣobhaṃ yadeti na manāg api tena manye
analyzed: kṣobham yadā iti na manāk api tena manye
translated: when it does not cause the slightest agitation,

original: suvyaktam eva jalarāśir ayaṃ payodhiḥ //
analyzed: su vyaktam eva jala rāśiḥ ayam payodhiḥ
translated: I think it is quite clear that this is indeed the ocean of water.

original: ity evaṃvidhe viṣaye 'nuraṇanarūparūpakāśrayeṇa kāvyacārutvavyavasthānād rūpakadhvanir iti vyapadeśo nyāyyaḥ /
analyzed: iti evaṃvidhe viṣaye nuraṇana rūpa rūpaka āśrayeṇa kāvya cāru tva vyavasthānāt rūpaka dhvaniḥ iti vyapadeśaḥ nyāyyaḥ
translated: In such a case, since the beauty of poetry is established by the basis of resonance in the form of a metaphor, it is proper to designate it as an indication of metaphor.

original: upamādhvanir / yathā🔽vīrāṇaṃ ramai ghusiṇāruṇammi ṇa tahā piāthaṇucchaṅge /
analyzed: upamā dhvaniḥ yathā  vīrāṇam ramai ghusiṇa aruṇammi ṇa tahā
translated: Indication of simile, as in:🔽The eyes of heroes delight in the red like saffron, not so much in the bosom of their beloved.

original: diṭṭhī riugaakumbhatthalammi jaha bahalasindūre //
analyzed: diṭṭhī jaha bahala sindūre
translated: As on the forehead of the enemy's elephant, where there is thick vermilion.

original: vīrāṇāṃ ramate ghusṛṇāruṇe na tathā priyāstanotsaṅge /
analyzed: vīrāṇām ramate ghusṛṇa aruṇe na tathā priyā stana utsaṅge
translated: The eyes of heroes delight in the red like saffron, not so much in the bosom of their beloved.

original: dṛṣṭī ripugajakumbhasthale yathā bahalasindūre //
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ ripu gaja kumbha sthale yathā bahala sindūre
translated: As on the forehead of the enemy's elephant, where there is thick vermilion.

original: yathā vā mamaiva viṣamabāṇalīlāyām asuraparākramaṇe kāmadevasya
analyzed: yathā vā mama eva viṣama bāṇa līlāyām asura parākramaṇe kāmadevasya
translated: Or, as in one of my own [verses] in the play 'Vishamabana-lila', about Kamadeva's attack on the demons:

original: taṃ tāṇaṃ sirisahoararaaṇāharaṇammi hiaam ekkarasam /
analyzed: tam tāṇam siri sahoara raaṇa āharaṇammi hiaam ekkarasam
translated: His heart is single-minded in carrying off the bride of Shiva, the enemy of the demon's prosperity.

original: bimbāhare piāṇaṃ nivesiaṃ kusumabāṇena //
analyzed: bimba āhare piāṇam nivesiam kusuma bāṇena
translated: The arrow of Cupid has placed the beloved's lips,

original: Supplement to Gāhāsattasāi /
analyzed: supplement to
translated: Supplement to the Gāhāsattsai.

original: tat teṣāṃ śrīsahodararatnāharaṇe hṛdayam ekarasam /
analyzed: tat teṣām śrī sahodara ratna āharaṇe hṛdayam ekarasam
translated: That is their one-pointed heart in stealing the jewel of the glorious elder brother.

original: bimbādhare priyāṇāṃ niveśitaṃ kusumabāṇena //
analyzed: bimba adhare priyāṇām niveśitam kusuma bāṇena
translated: The arrow of Cupid has placed the beloved's bimba-like lips.

original: ākṣepadhvanir / yathā
analyzed: ākṣepa dhvaniḥ yathā
translated: Suggestive sound, as in

original: sa vaktum akhilāñ śakto hayagrīvāśritān guṇān /
analyzed: sa vaktum akhilām śaktaḥ hayagrīva āśritān guṇān
translated: He is able to describe all the qualities of Hayagriva,

original: yo 'mbukumbhaiḥ paricchedaṃ jñātuṃ śakto mahodadheḥ //
analyzed: yaḥ mbu kumbhaiḥ paricchedam jñātum śaktaḥ mahā udadheḥ
translated: Who is able to determine the extent of the great ocean with water pots.

original: atrātiśayoktyā hayagrīvaguṇānām avarṇanīyatāpratipādanarūpasyāsādhāraṇatadviśeṣaprakāśanaparasyākṣepasya prakāśanam /
analyzed: atra atiśayoktyā hayagrīva guṇānām avarṇanīya tā pratipādana rūpasya asādhāraṇa tad viśeṣa prakāśana parasya ākṣepasya prakāśanam
translated: Here, by hyperbole, there is the suggestion of reproach, which is intended to reveal an extraordinary special quality in the form of conveying the indescribability of the qualities of Hayagriva.

original: arthāntaranyāsadhvaniḥ śabdaśaktimūlānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyo 'rthaśaktimūlānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyaś ca sambhavati /
analyzed: arthāntaranyāsa dhvaniḥ śabda śakti mūla anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyaḥ rtha śakti mūla anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyaḥ ca sambhavati
translated: The suggestive sound based on the power of meaning can be either a reverberation based on the power of word or a reverberation based on the power of meaning.

original: tatrādyasyodāharaṇam
analyzed: tatra ādyasya udāharaṇam
translated: An example of the first is

original: devāettammi phale kiṃ kīrai ettiaṃ puṇā bhaṇimo /
analyzed: phale kim kīrai ettiam puṇā bhaṇimaḥ
translated: What can be done about the fruit that is dependent on fate? We say this much again.

original: kaṅkillapallavāḥ pallavāṇaṃ aṇṇāṇaṃ ṇa saricchā //🔽daivāyatte phale kiṃ kriyatām etāvat punar bhaṇāmaḥ /
analyzed: kaṅkilla pallavāḥ pallavāṇam annāṇam na 🔽daiva āyatte phale kim kriyatām etāvat punar bhaṇāmaḥ
translated: The tender sprouts are the bow, the other rivers are not equal.

original: raktāśokapallavāḥ pallavānām anyeṣāṃ na sadṛśāḥ //
analyzed: rakta aśoka pallavāḥ pallavānām anyeṣām na sadṛśāḥ
translated: The tender shoots of the red Ashoka tree are not like other tender shoots.

original: padaprakāśaś cāyaṃ dhvanir iti vākyasyārthāntaratātparye 'pi sati na virodhaḥ /
analyzed: pada prakāśaḥ ca ayam dhvaniḥ iti vākyasya artha antara tātparye sati na virodhaḥ
translated: And this sound is illuminating the word. Even when there is a different intended meaning of the sentence, there is no contradiction.

original: dvitīyasyodāharaṇaṃ yathā🔽hiaaṭṭhābiamaṇṇuṃ abaruṇṇamuhaṃ hi maṃ pasāanta /🔽abaraddhassa bi ṇa hu de bahujāṇaa rosiuṃ sakkaṃ //🔽hṛdayasthāpitamanyum aparoṣamukhīm api māṃ prasādayan /
analyzed: dvitīyasya udāharaṇam yathā  abaruṇṇa muham hi mama  a baraddhassa bi ṇa hu de bahu jāṇaa rosium sakkam  hṛdaya sthāpita manyum aparoṣa mukhīm api mām prasādayan
translated: An example of the second type is like this:🔽Though I have placed anger in my heart and am frowning, you are trying to appease me.

original: aparāddhasyāpi na khalu te bahujña roṣitum śakyam //
analyzed: aparāddhasya api na khalu te bahujña roṣitum śakyam
translated: But even when I have offended, O very wise one, it is not possible to be angry with you.

original: atra hi vācyaviśeṣeṇa sāparādhasyāpi bahujñasya kopaḥ kartum aśakya iti samarthakaṃ sāmānyam anvitam anyat tātparyeṇa prakāśate /
analyzed: atra hi vācya viśeṣeṇa sa aparādhasya api bahu jñasya kopaḥ kartum aśakyaḥ iti samarthakam sāmānyam anvitam anyat tātparyeṇa prakāśate
translated: Here, the general meaning that it is impossible to make the very wise one who has offended be angry, which is supported by a particular expressed meaning, is illuminated by another intended meaning.

original: vyatirekadhvanir apy ubhayarūpaḥ sambhavati /
analyzed: vyatireka dhvaniḥ api ubhaya rūpaḥ sambhavati
translated: The suggestion of contradiction also occurs in both forms.

original: tatrādyasyodāharaṇaṃ prākpradarśitam eva /
analyzed: tatra ādyasya udāharaṇam prāk pradarśitam eva
translated: An example of the first type has already been shown.

original: dvitīyasyodāharaṇaṃ yathā
analyzed: dvitīyasya udāharaṇam yathā
translated: An example of the second type is like this:

original: jāejja vanuddese khujja bbia pāabo gaḍiabatto /
analyzed: khujja bbia pāabaḥ
translated: Though born in a different country, the lame and hunchbacked one has become a servant of the king.

original: mā mānusammi loe tāekkaraso dariddo a //
analyzed: mā mānusammi loe dariddo
translated: In the human world, he alone is poor, who is destitute of self-respect.

original: jāyeya vanoddeśe kubja eva pādapo galitapatraḥ /
analyzed: jāyeya vana uddeśe kubjaḥ eva pādapaḥ galita patraḥ
translated: I would rather be born in a forest region as a crooked tree with withered leaves.

original: mā mānuṣe loke tyāgaikaraso daridraś ca //
analyzed: mā mānuṣe loke tyāga eka rasaḥ daridraḥ ca
translated: In the human world, I would rather be a poor man solely devoted to charity, than a rich man who is miserly.

original: atra hi tyāgaikarasasya daridrasya janmānabhinandanaṃ truṭitapatrakubjapādapajanmābhinandanaṃ ca sākṣācchabdavācyam /
analyzed: atra hi tyāga eka rasasya daridrasya janma anabhinandanam truṭita patra kubja pādapa janma abhinandanam ca sākṣāt śabda vācyam
translated: Here, the direct expression of the non-delight in being born as a poor man solely devoted to charity, and the delight in being born as a tree with withered leaves and crooked branches, is by the word 'rather'.

original: tathāvidhād api pādapāt tādṛśasya puṃsa upamānopameyatvapratītipūrvakaṃ śocyatāyām ādhikyaṃ tātparyeṇa prakāśayati /
analyzed: tathāvidhāt api pādapāt tādṛśasya puṃsaḥ upamāna upameya tva pratīti pūrvakam śocya tāyām ādhikyam tātparyeṇa prakāśayati
translated: And from such a tree, he shows by implication the superiority in pitiableness of such a man, preceded by the understanding of the relation of the object compared to and the object compared,

original: utprekṣādhvanir yathā🔽candanāsaktabhujaganiḥśvāsānilamūrcchitaḥ /
analyzed: utprekṣā dhvaniḥ yathā  candana āsakta bhujaga niḥśvāsa anila mūrcchitaḥ
translated: Suggestion of poetic fancy is as follows:🔽The Malaya breeze in spring, intoxicated by the breath of the serpent clinging to sandal,

original: mūrcchayaty eṣa pathikān madhau malayamārutaḥ //
analyzed: mūrcchayati eṣa pathikān madhau malaya mārutaḥ
translated: senseless with intoxication, causes fainting among travelers.

original: atra hi madhau malayamārutasya pathikamūrcchākāritvaṃ manmathonmāthadāyitvenaiva /
analyzed: atra hi madhau malaya mārutasya pathika mūrcchā kāri tvam manmatha unmātha dāyi tvena eva
translated: Here, the causing of fainting among travelers by the Malaya breeze in spring is only by its giving rise to the madness of love.

original: tat tu candanāsaktabhujaganiḥśvāsānilamūrcchitatvenotprekṣitam ity utprekṣā sākṣād anuktāpi vākyārthasāmarthyād anuraṇanarūpā lakṣyate
analyzed: tat tu candana āsakta bhujaga niḥśvāsa anila mūrcchita tvena utprekṣitam iti utprekṣā sākṣāt anuktā api vākya artha sāmarthyāt anuraṇana rūpā lakṣyate
translated: But that is poetically fancied as being due to being intoxicated by the breath of the serpent clinging to sandal. Thus, although the poetic fancy is not directly expressed, it is perceived as reverberating by the force of the meaning of the sentence.

original: na caivaṃvidhe viṣaye ivādiśabdaprayogam antareṇāsaṃbaddhataiveti śakyate vaktum /
analyzed: na ca evaṃvidhe viṣaye iva ādi śabda prayogam antareṇa asaṃbaddha tā eva iti śakyate vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that in such a case, without the use of words like 'iva' etc., it would be incoherent.

original: gamakatvād anyatrāpi tadaprayoge tadarthāvagatidarśanāt / yathā🔽īsākalusassa bi tuha muhassa ṇaṃ esa puṇṇimācando /🔽ajja sarisattaṇaṃ pābiūṇa aṅge bia ṇa māi //
analyzed: gamaka tvāt anyatra api tad aprayoge tad artha avagati darśanāt yathā  īsā kalusassa bi tuha muhassa ṇaṃ esa puṇṇimā candaḥ  ajja sarisa ttaṇam aṅge bia ṇa māi
translated: Because it is suggestive, even without its use elsewhere, the meaning is understood, as in

original: īrṣyākaluṣasyāpi tava mukhasya nanv eṣa pūrṇimācandraḥ /
analyzed: īrṣyā kaluṣasya api tava mukhasya nanu eṣa pūrṇimā candraḥ
translated: The moon is full for you, whose face is afflicted with jealousy,

original: adya sadṛśatvaṃ prāpyāṅga eva na māti //
analyzed: adya sadṛśa tvam prāpya aṅge eva na māti
translated: Today, having attained similarity, it does not shine in any limb.

original: yathā vā
analyzed: yathā vā
translated: Or as in

original: trāsākulaḥ paripatan parito niketān🔽puṃbhir na kaiścid api dhanvibhir anvabandhi /🔽tasthau tathāpi na mṛgaḥ kvacid aṅganābhir
analyzed: trāsa ākulaḥ paripatan paritas niketān  puṃbhiḥ na kaiścid api dhanvibhiḥ anvabandhi  tasthau tathā api na mṛgaḥ kvacid aṅganābhiḥ
translated: Terrified, wandering around the shelters,🔽Not followed by any archers,🔽Still the deer did not stay anywhere, its beauty of eyes destroyed by the glances of the women,

original: ākarṇapūrṇanayaneṣuhatekṣaṇaśrīḥ //
analyzed: ākarṇapūrṇa nayana iṣu hata īkṣaṇa śrīḥ
translated: With eyes wide open up to the ears.

original: śabdārthavyavahāre ca prasiddhir eva pramāṇam /
analyzed: śabda artha vyavahāre ca prasiddhiḥ eva pramāṇam
translated: And in the usage of words and meanings, tradition alone is the authority.

original: śleṣadhvanir yathā
analyzed: śleṣa dhvaniḥ yathā
translated: Alliteration-based suggestion, as in🔽The flags, having attained beauty,

original: ramyā iti prāptavatīḥ patākāḥ rāgaṃ viviktā iti vardhayantīḥ /
analyzed: ramyāḥ iti prāptavatīḥ patākāḥ rāgam viviktāḥ iti vardhayantīḥ
translated: Increasing passion, being secluded,

original: yasyām asevanta namadvalīkāḥ samaṃ vadhūbhir valabhīr yuvānaḥ //
analyzed: yasyām asevanta namat valīkāḥ samam vadhūbhiḥ valabhīḥ yuvānaḥ
translated: On which young men with curved arms did not serve the balconies, together with their wives.

original: atra vadhūbhiḥ saha valabhīrasevanteti vākyārthapratīter anantaraṃ vadhva iva valabhya iti śleṣapratītir aśabdāpy arthasāmarthyān mukhyatvena
analyzed: atra vadhūbhiḥ saha valabhīḥ asevanta iti vākya artha pratīteḥ anantaram vadhvaḥ iva valabhyaḥ iti śleṣa pratītiḥ aśabdā api artha sāmarthyāt mukhya tvena
translated: Here, after the understanding of the sentence meaning they enjoy the balconies with the brides, the understanding of the pun like the brides, the balconies occurs even though not expressed by the words, by the power of the meaning, as the primary [meaning].

original: vartate /
analyzed: vartate
translated: It occurs.

original: yathāsaṅkhyadhvanir yathā
analyzed: yathāsaṅkhya dhvaniḥ yathā
translated: The indication of numerical order is like this:

original: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakitaḥ puṣpitaś ca sahakāraḥ /
analyzed: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakitaḥ puṣpitaḥ ca sahakāraḥ
translated: The mango tree has sprouted, leafed, budded, and flowered.

original: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakitaḥ puṣpitaś ca hṛdi madanaḥ //
analyzed: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakitaḥ puṣpitaḥ ca hṛdi madanaḥ
translated: In the heart, Cupid has sprouted, leafed, budded, and flowered.

original: atra hi yathoddeśam anūddeśe yac cārutvam anuraṇanarūpaṃ madanaviśeṣaṇabhūtāṅkuritādiśabdagataṃ
analyzed: atra hi yathoddeśam anūddeśe yat cāru tvam anuraṇana rūpam madana viśeṣaṇa bhūta aṅkurita ādi śabda gatam
translated: Here, indeed, the beauty that is in the words sprout, etc., which are attributes of Cupid in the form of an echo, according to the order of enumeration and the order of reference,

original: tanmadanasahakārayos tulyayogitāsamuccayalakṣaṇād vācyād atiricyamānam ālakṣyate /
analyzed: tat madana sahakārayoḥ tulya yogitā samuccaya lakṣaṇāt vācyāt atiricyamānam ālakṣyate
translated: is seen to exceed the expressible meaning in the form of the compound tulyayogitāsamuccaya of Cupid and the mango tree.

original: evam anye 'py alaṅkārā yathāyogaṃ yojanīyāḥ // / //
analyzed: evam anye pi alaṅkārāḥ yathāyogam yojanīyāḥ
translated: In the same way, other figures of speech should be connected as appropriate.

original: evam alaṅkāradhvanimārgaṃ vyutpādya tasya prayojanavattāṃ khyāpayitum idam ucyate
analyzed: evam alaṅkāra dhvani mārgam vyutpādya tasya prayojanavat tām khyāpayitum idam ucyate
translated: Having thus explained the path of suggestion of figures of speech, this is said to proclaim its usefulness:

original: śarīrīkaraṇaṃ yeṣāṃ vācyatve na vyavasthitam /
analyzed: śarīrīkaraṇam yeṣām vācya tve na vyavasthitam
translated: Those which are embodied, not fixed in the state of being expressed,

original: te 'laṅkārāḥ parāṃ chāyāṃ yānti dhvanyaṅgatāṃ gataḥ // / //
analyzed: te laṅkārāḥ parām chāyām yānti dhvani aṅga tām gataḥ
translated: Those ornaments attain the highest beauty when they become a part of suggestion.

original: dhvanyaṅgatā cobhābhyāṃ prakārābhyāṃ vyañjakatvena vyaṅgyatvena ca /
analyzed: dhvani aṅgatā ca ubhābhyām prakārābhyām vyañjaka tvena vyaṅgya tvena ca
translated: And the state of being a part of suggestion is of two kinds: by being suggestive and by being suggested.

original: tatreha prakaraṇād vyaṅgyatvenety avagantavyam /🔽vyaṅgyatve 'py alaṅkārāṇāṃ prādhānyavivakṣāyām eva satyāṃ dhvanāv antaḥpātaḥ /
analyzed: tatra iha prakaraṇāt vyaṅgya tvena iti avagantavyam  vyaṅgya tve pi alaṅkārāṇām prādhānya vivakṣāyām eva satyām dhvanau antaḥpātaḥ
translated: Among them, here it should be understood that they are suggested by the context.🔽Even when ornaments are suggested, they are included in dhvani only when there is the intention to make them primary.

original: itarathā tu guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatvaṃ pratipādayiṣyate // / //🔽aṅgitvena vyaṅgyatāyām api /
analyzed: itarathā tu guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tvam pratipādayiṣyate  aṅgi tvena vyaṅgya tāyām api
translated: Otherwise, it will be shown that they are subordinated to suggestion.🔽Even when ornaments are suggested as subordinate,

original: alaṅkārāṇāṃ dvayī gatiḥkadācid vastumātreṇa vyajyante /
analyzed: alaṅkārāṇām dvayī gatiḥ kadācid vastu mātreṇa vyajyante
translated: they have two courses: sometimes they are suggested by the mere fact,

original: kadācid alaṅkāreṇa / tatra🔽vyajyante vastumātreṇa yadālaṅkṛtayastayā /
analyzed: kadācid alaṅkāreṇa tatra  vyajyante vastu mātreṇa yadā alaṅkṛtayaḥ tayā
translated: sometimes by an ornament. Among them,🔽those ornaments which are suggested by the mere fact,

original: dhruvaṃ dhvanyaṅgatā tāsāṃ / / / / / / / /
analyzed: dhruvam dhvani aṅga tā tāsām
translated: they certainly become a part of suggestion.

original: atra hetuḥ
analyzed: atra hetuḥ
translated: The reason for this is:

original: kāvyavṛttis tadāśrayā // / //
translated: the function of poetry is based on that.

original: yasmāt tatra tathāvidhavyaṅgyālaṅkāraparatvenaiva kāvyaṃ pravṛttam /
analyzed: yasmāt tatra tathāvidha vyaṅgya alaṅkāra para tvena eva kāvyam pravṛttam
translated: Because in that case, poetry proceeds with the sole purpose of suggesting such ornaments.

original: anyathā tu tadvākyamātram eva syāt // / //
analyzed: anyathā tu tad vākya mātram eva syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be mere statement.

original: tāsām evālaṅkṛtīnām
analyzed: tāsām eva alaṅkṛtīnām
translated: Of those very ornaments,

original: alaṅkārāntaravyaṅgyabhāve / / / / / / / /
analyzed: alaṅkāra antara vyaṅgya bhāve
translated: When there is suggestion by another figure of speech,

original: punaḥ /
analyzed: punar
translated: again,

original: dhvanyaṅgatā bhavet /
analyzed: bhavet
translated: it may be a subordinate suggestion.

original: cārutvotkarṣato vyaṅgyaprādhānyaṃ yadi lakṣyate // / //🔽uktaṃ hy etatcārutvotkarṣanibandhanā vācyavyaṅgyayoḥ prādhānyavivakṣā iti /
analyzed: cāru tva utkarṣataḥ vyaṅgya prādhānyam yadi lakṣyate  uktam hi etad cāru tva utkarṣa nibandhanā vācya vyaṅgyayoḥ prādhānya vivakṣā iti
translated: If the predominance of the suggested meaning is recognized due to the excellence of beauty,🔽it has been said that the predominance of the expressed and suggested meanings is based on the excellence of beauty.

original: vastu mātravyaṅgyatve cālaṅkārāṇām anantaropadarśitebhya evodāharaṇebhyo viṣaya unneyaḥ /
analyzed: vastu mātra vyaṅgya tve ca alaṅkārāṇām anantara upadarśitebhyaḥ evā udāharaṇebhyaḥ viṣayaḥ unneyaḥ
translated: And when figures of speech are suggested merely by the meaning, the subject can be inferred from the very examples shown immediately before.

original: tad evam arthamātreṇālaṅkāraviśeṣarūpeṇa vārthenārthāntarasyālaṅkārasya vā prakāśane
analyzed: tat evam artha mātreṇa alaṅkāra viśeṣa rūpeṇa vā arthena artha antarasya alaṅkārasya vā prakāśane
translated: Thus, when the excellence of beauty is based on the revelation of another meaning or a figure of speech by the mere meaning, which is of the nature of a particular figure of speech,

original: cārutvotkarṣanibandhane sati prādhānye 'rthaśaktyudbhavānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyo🔽niravagantavyaḥ // / //
analyzed: niravagantavyaḥ
translated: the suggestion that arises from the power of the meaning, which is in the form of an echo, should be understood to be subordinate.

original: evaṃ dhvaneḥ prabhedān pratipādya tadābhāsavivekaṃ kartum ucyate
analyzed: evam dhvaneḥ prabhedān pratipādya tad ābhāsa vivekam kartum ucyate
translated: Having thus explained the varieties of dhvani, in order to distinguish its imitations, it is said:

original: yatra pratīyamāno 'rthaḥ pramliṣṭatvena bhāsate /
analyzed: yatra pratīyamānaḥ rthaḥ pramliṣṭa tvena bhāsate
translated: Where the suggested meaning appears as indistinct,

original: vācyasyāṅgatayā vāpi nāsyāsau gocaro dhvaneḥ // / //
analyzed: vācyasya aṅga tayā vā api na asya asau gocaraḥ dhvaneḥ
translated: or as a subordinate of the expressed meaning, that is not the domain of dhvani.

original: dvividho 'pi pratīyamānaḥ sphuṭo 'sphuṭaś ca /
analyzed: dvividhaḥ pi pratīyamānaḥ sphuṭaḥ sphuṭaḥ ca
translated: The suggested meaning is of two kinds: clear and unclear.

original: tatra ya eva sphuṭaḥ śabdaśaktyārthaśaktyā vā prakāśate sa eva dhvaner mārgo netaraḥ /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ eva sphuṭaḥ śabda śaktyā artha śaktyā vā prakāśate saḥ eva dhvaneḥ mārgaḥ na itaraḥ
translated: Of these, that which is clear, whether by the power of the word or by the power of the meaning, is the path of dhvani, not the other.

original: sphuṭo 'pi yo 'bhidheyasyāṅgatvena pratīyamāno 'vabhāsate so 'syānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyasya dhvaner agocaraḥ / yathā🔽kamalāarā ṇa maliā haṃsā uḍḍābiā ṇa a piucchā /🔽keṇa bi gāmataḍāe abbhaṃ uttāṇaaṃ phaliham //
analyzed: sphuṭaḥ pi yaḥ bhidheyasya aṅga tvena pratīyamānaḥ vabhāsate saḥ sya anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ agocaraḥ yathā  kamalāarā na maliā haṃsā uḍḍābiā na a piucchā  keṇa bi gāma taḍāe abbham uttāṇaam phaliham
translated: Even the clear one, which appears as subordinate to the denoted meaning, is not the domain of dhvani, which has resonance as its suggestive form, as in:

original: kamalākarā na malitā haṃsā uḍḍāyitā na ca pitṛśvasaḥ /
analyzed: kamala ākarāḥ na malitāḥ haṃsāḥ uḍḍāyitāḥ na ca
translated: Kamalākarāṇāṃ na malitā haṃsā uḍḍāyitā na ca pitṛśvasūḥ.

original: kenāpi grāmataṭāke 'bhram uttānitaṃ kṣiptam //
analyzed: kena api grāma taṭāke bhram uttānitam kṣiptam
translated: Kenāpi grāmātāṭāke 'bhraṃ tānītam utkṣiptam.

original: atra hi pratīyamānasya mugdhavadhvā jaladharapratibimbadarśanasya vācyāṅgatvam eva /
analyzed: atra hi pratīyamānasya mugdha vadhvāḥ jaladhara pratibimba darśanasya vācya aṅga tvam eva
translated: Here, the suggested sight of the young bride seeing the reflection of the raincloud is indeed subordinate to the denoted meaning.

original: evaṃvidhe viṣaye 'nyatrāpi yatra vyaṅgyāpekṣayā vācyasya cārutvotkarṣapratītyā prādhānyam avasīyate /
analyzed: evaṃvidhe viṣaye nyatra api yatra vyaṅgya apekṣayā vācyasya cāru tva utkarṣa pratītyā prādhānyam avasīyate
translated: In such a case, and elsewhere too, where the predominance of the denoted meaning is determined by the appreciation of the enhanced beauty in relation to the suggested meaning,

original: tatra vyaṅgyasyāṅgatvena pratīter dhvaner aviṣayatvam / yathā
analyzed: tatra vyaṅgyasya aṅga tvena pratīteḥ dhvaneḥ aviṣaya tvam yathā
translated: there the suggested meaning is perceived as subordinate, and it is not the domain of dhvani. For example:

original: vāṇarikuḍaṅgoḍḍīṇasaunikolāhalaṃ suṇantīe /
analyzed: vāṇari kuḍaṅga uḍḍīṇa sauni kolāhalam suṇantīe
translated: Hearing the commotion of hunters and dogs howling in the forest,

original: gharakammavāvaḍāe bahue sīanti aṅgāiṃ //
analyzed: bahue
translated: The limbs of the young wife, busy with household work, are languid.

original: Supplement to Gāhāsattasāi /
analyzed: supplement to
translated: Supplement to the Seven Discourses on the Gaṇḍī.

original: vetasalatāgahanoḍḍīnaśakunikolāhalaṃ śṛṇvatyāḥ /
analyzed: vetasa latā gahana uḍḍīna śakuni kolāhalam śṛṇvatyāḥ
translated: While listening to the commotion of birds flying out of the dense reeds,

original: gṛhakarmavyāpṛtāyā vadhvāḥ sīdanty aṅgāni //🔽evaṃvidho hi viṣayaḥ prāyeṇa guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasyodāharaṇatvena nirdekṣyate /🔽yatra tu prakaraṇādipratipattyā nirdhāritaviśeṣo vācyo 'rthaḥ punaḥ pratīyamānāṅgatvenaivāvabhāsate so 'syaivānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyasya dhvaner
analyzed: gṛhakarma vyāpṛtāyāḥ vadhvāḥ sīdanti aṅgāni  evaṃvidhaḥ hi viṣayaḥ prāyeṇa guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya udāharaṇa tvena nirdekṣyate  yatra tu prakaraṇa ādi pratipattyā nirdhārita viśeṣaḥ vācyaḥ rthaḥ punar pratīyamāna aṅgatvena eva avabhāsate saḥ tya eva anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ
translated: the limbs of the young wife, busy with household work, are languid.🔽Such a subject will generally be shown as an example of the subordinated suggestion.

original: mārgaḥ / yathā🔽uccinasu paḍiaṃ kusumaṃ mā dhuṇa sehāliaṃ haliasuhṇe /🔽aha de visamavirāvo sasureṇa suo valaasaddo //
analyzed: mārgaḥ yathā  uccinasu paḍiam kusumam mā dhuṇa sehāliam halia suhṇe  aha de visama virāvaḥ sa sureṇa suaḥ vala a saddaḥ
translated: But where the expressed meaning, whose specification is determined by the understanding of the context, etc., appears only as a subordinate element in the suggested meaning, that is the path of this very dhvani, the suggestion that is a reverberation. For example:

original: uccinu patitaṃ kusumaṃ mā dhunīhi śephālikāṃ hālikasnuṣe /
analyzed: uccinu patitam kusumam mā dhunīhi śephālikām hālika snuṣe
translated: O daughter-in-law of the ploughman, pick up the fallen flower, do not crush the jasmine.

original: eṣa te viṣamavipākaḥ śvasureṇa śruto valayaśabdaḥ //
analyzed: eṣa te viṣama vipākaḥ śvasureṇa śrutaḥ valaya śabdaḥ
translated: This is the uneven ripening, the sound of the bracelet heard by your father-in-law.

original: atra hy avinayapatinā saha ramamāṇā sakhī bahiḥśrutavalayakalakalayā sakhyā pratibodhyate /
analyzed: atra hi avinaya patinā saha ramamāṇā sakhī bahis śruta valaya kalakalayā sakhyā pratibodhyate
translated: Here, a friend who is enjoying herself with an immodest lover is awakened by her friend with the sound of the bracelet heard outside.

original: etad apekṣaṇīyaṃ vācyārthapratipattaye /🔽pratipanne ca vācye 'rthe tasyāvinayapracchādanatātparyeṇābhidhīyamānatvāt punar vyaṅgyāṅgatvam evety asminn anuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyadhvanāvantarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: etat apekṣaṇīyam vācya artha pratipattaye  pratipanne ca vācye rthe tasya avinaya pracchādana tātparyeṇa abhidhīyamāna tvāt punar vyaṅgya aṅga tvam eva iti asmin anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgya dhvanau antarbhāvaḥ
translated: This is to be taken into account for the understanding of the expressed meaning.🔽And when the expressed meaning is understood, it is stated with the intention of concealing its impropriety, so it is again a subordinate element of the suggested meaning. Thus it is included in the resonance-type suggested meaning.

original: evaṃ vivakṣitavācyasya dhvanes tadābhāsaviveke prastute satyavivakṣitavācyasyāpi taṃ kartum āha
analyzed: evam vivakṣita vācyasya dhvaneḥ tad ābhāsa viveke prastute satya vivakṣita vācyasya api tam kartum āha
translated: Thus, when the distinction between the intended expressed meaning and its semblance is presented in the case of dhvani, he says to make that distinction in the case of the unintended expressed meaning as well.

original: avyutpatter aśakter vā nibandho yaḥ skhaladgateḥ /
analyzed: avyutpatteḥ aśakteḥ vā nibandhaḥ yaḥ skhalat gateḥ
translated: The composition of a word with a faltering gait, due to lack of knowledge or inability,

original: śabdasya sa ca na jñeyaḥ sūribhir viṣayo dhvaneḥ // / //
analyzed: śabdasya sa ca na jñeyaḥ sūribhiḥ viṣayaḥ dhvaneḥ
translated: should not be known by the wise as the domain of dhvani.

original: skhaladgater upacaritasya śabdasyāvyutpatter aśakter vā nibandho yaḥ sa ca na dhvaner viṣayaḥ / yataḥ
analyzed: skhalat gateḥ upacaritasya śabdasya avyutpatteḥ aśakteḥ vā nibandhaḥ yaḥ sa ca na dhvaneḥ viṣayaḥ yatas
translated: The composition of a word with a faltering gait, due to lack of knowledge or inability, is not the domain of dhvani, because

original: sarveṣv eva prabhedeṣu sphuṭatvenāvabhāsanam /
analyzed: sarveṣu eva prabhedeṣu sphuṭa tvena avabhāsanam
translated: in all the varieties, the suggested meaning appears clearly.

original: yad vyaṅgyasyāṅgibhūtasya tat pūrṇaṃ dhvanilakṣaṇam // / //
analyzed: yat vyaṅgyasya aṅgi bhūtasya tat pūrṇam dhvani lakṣaṇam
translated: That is the complete definition of dhvani, where the suggested meaning is subordinate.

original: tac codāhṛtaviṣayam eva // / //
analyzed: tat ca udāhṛta viṣayam eva
translated: And that is illustrated in the subject matter itself.

original: iti śrīrājānakānandavardhanācāryaviracite dhvanyāloke dvitīya uddyotaḥ //
analyzed: iti śrī rāja ānaka ānandavardhana ācārya viracite dhvanyāloke dvitīyaḥ uddyotaḥ
translated: Thus ends the second chapter of the Dhwanyaloka composed by the venerable Acharya Rajanakanandavardhana.

original: tṛtīyiddyotaḥ
analyzed: tṛtīyi ddyotaḥ
translated: The third chapter

original: evaṃ vyaṅgyamukhenaiva dhvaneḥ pradarśite saprabhede svarūpe punar vyañjakamukhenaitat prakāśyate
analyzed: evam vyaṅgya mukhena eva dhvaneḥ pradarśite sa prabhede svarūpe punar vyañjaka mukhena etat prakāśyate
translated: Thus, having shown the nature of dhvani along with its divisions, by means of the suggestive element alone, it is now being revealed by means of the suggestive element.

original: avivakṣitavācyasya padavākyaprakāśatā /
analyzed: avivakṣita vācyasya pada vākya prakāśa tā
translated: The manifestation of words and sentences in what is not intended to be expressed,

original: tadanyasyānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyasya ca dhvaneḥ // / //
analyzed: tad anyasya anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyasya ca dhvaneḥ
translated: and also in dhvani where the suggested meaning is in the form of an echo,

original: avivakṣitavācyasyātyantatiraskṛtavācye prabhede padaprakāśatā yathā maharṣer vyāsasyasaptaitāḥ samidhaḥ śriyaḥ /
analyzed: avivakṣita vācyasya atyanta tiraskṛta vācye prabhede pada prakāśa tā yathā mahā ṛṣeḥ vyāsasya saptā etāḥ samidhaḥ śriyaḥ
translated: In the variety where the expressed meaning is completely set aside, the manifestation of words is as follows: The great sage Vyasa's seven kinds of fuel are his glories.

original: yathā vā kālidāsasyakaḥ sannaddhe virahavidhurāṃ tvayy upekṣeta jāyām /
analyzed: yathā vā kālidāsa syakaḥ sannaddhe viraha vidhurām tvayi upekṣeta jāyām
translated: Or as Kalidasa says: Who would ignore his wife, who is distressed by separation from him, when he is ready?🔽Or as: What is the ornament of sweet things other than beautiful forms?

original: yathā vākim iva hi madhurāṇāṃ maṇḍanaṃ nākṛtīnām /🔽eṣūdāharaṇeṣu samidha iti /
analyzed: yathā vākim iva hi madhurāṇām maṇḍanam na ākṛtīnām  eṣu udāharaṇeṣu samidhaḥ iti
translated: In these examples, the words fuel,

original: sannaddha iti /🔽madhurāṇām iti ca padāni vyañjakatvābhiprāyeṇaiva kṛtāni /
analyzed: sannaddhaḥ iti  madhurāṇām iti ca padāni vyañjaka tva abhiprāyeṇa eva kṛtāni
translated: ready,🔽and of sweet things are used with the intention of suggesting.

original: tasyaivārthāntarasaṅkramitavācye yathārāmeṇa priyajīvitena tu kṛtaṃ premṇaḥ priye nocitam /
analyzed: tasya eva artha antara saṅkramita vācye yathā rāmeṇa priya jīvitena tu kṛtam premṇaḥ priye nā ucitam
translated: In the same [variety] where the expressed meaning has shifted to another meaning, as in: But by the beloved who cherishes life, love's due service to the loved one has not been done.

original: atra rāmeṇety etatpadaṃ samasāhasaikarasatvādivyaṅgyābhisaṅkramitavācyaṃ vyañjakam /
analyzed: atra rāmeṇa iti etat padam sama sāhasa eka rasa tva ādi vyaṅgya abhisaṅkramita vācyam vyañjakam
translated: Here the word 'Rama' is suggestive, its denoted sense being transferred to the suggested sense of 'equality in daring and love'.

original: yathā vā🔽emea jaṇo tissā deu kabolopamāi sasibimbaṃ /🔽paramatthaviāre uṇa cando cando bia varāo //
analyzed: yathā vā  jaṇaḥ tissā  paramattha viāre uṇa cando candaḥ bia varāo
translated: Or, for example:

original: evam eva janas tasyā dadāti kapolopamāyāṃ śaśibimbam /
analyzed: evam eva janaḥ tasyāḥ dadāti kapola upamāyām śaśi bimbam
translated: Thus the people give to her the image of the moon as a comparison for her cheeks.

original: paramārthavicāre punaś candraś candra iva varākaḥ //
analyzed: parama artha vicāre punar candraḥ candraḥ iva varākaḥ
translated: But upon examination of the ultimate truth, the moon is indeed a mere moon.

original: atra dvitīyaś candraśabdo 'rthāntarasaṅkramitavācyaḥ /
analyzed: atra dvitīyaḥ candra śabdaḥ rtha antara saṅkramita vācyaḥ
translated: Here the second word 'moon' has a denoted sense transferred to another meaning.

original: avivakṣitavācyasyātyantatiraskṛtavācye prabhede vākyaprakāśatā yathā🔽yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī /
analyzed: avivakṣita vācyasya atyanta tiraskṛta vācye prabhede vākya prakāśa tā yathā  yā niśā sarva bhūtānām tasyām jāgarti saṃyamī
translated: In the case of the type of suggestion where the denoted sense is not intended at all, but is completely set aside, the expression is based on a sentence, as in:🔽That which is night for all beings, in that the self-controlled one is awake.

original: yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ //
analyzed: yasyām jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyataḥ muneḥ
translated: In that which the beings are awake, that is night for the seeing sage.

original: anena hi vākyena niśārtho na ca jāgaraṇārthaḥ kaścid vivakṣitaḥ /
analyzed: anena hi vākyena niśā arthaḥ na ca jāgaraṇa arthaḥ kaścid vivakṣitaḥ
translated: For by this sentence neither the meaning of 'night' nor that of 'being awake' is intended at all.

original: kiṃ tarhi / tattvajñānāvahitatvam atattvaparāṅmukhatvaṃ ca muneḥ pratipādyata iti tiraskṛtavācyasyāsya vyañjakatvam /
analyzed: kim tarhi tattva jñāna avahita tvam atattva parāṅmukha tvam ca muneḥ pratipādyate iti tiraskṛta vācyasya asya vyañjaka tvam
translated: What then? It is taught that the sage is intent on the knowledge of truth and averse to what is not truth. Thus this [sentence] has the nature of a suggester, where the denoted sense is set aside.

original: tasyaivārthāntarasaṅkramitavācyasya vākyaprakāśatā yathā🔽visamaio ccia kāṇa bi kāṇa bi bolei amiaṇimmāo /🔽kāṇa bi bisāmiamao kāṇa bi abisāmao kālo //🔽viṣam ayitaḥ keṣām api keṣām api prayāty amṛtanirmāṇaḥ /
analyzed: tasya eva artha antara saṅkramita vācyasya vākya prakāśa tā yathā  visamaiaḥ ccia kāṇa bi kāṇa bi  kāṇa bi a bisa amao kālaḥ  viṣam ayitaḥ keṣām api keṣām api prayāti amṛta nirmāṇaḥ
translated: The illumination of a sentence is seen in the case of a word whose primary meaning is transferred to something else, as in the following:

original: keṣām api viṣāmṛtamayaḥ keṣām apy aviṣāmṛtaḥ kālaḥ //🔽atra hi vākye viṣāmṛtaśabdābhyāṃ duḥkhasukharūpasaṅkramitavācyābhyāṃ vyavahāra ity arthāntarasaṅkramitavācyasya vyañjakatvam /🔽vivakṣitābhidheyasyānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyasya śabdaśaktyudbhave prabhede padaprakāśatā yathā
analyzed: keṣām api viṣa amṛta mayaḥ keṣām api a viṣa amṛtaḥ kālaḥ  atra hi vākye viṣa amṛta śabdābhyām duḥkha sukha rūpa saṅkramita vācyābhyām vyavahāraḥ iti artha antara saṅkramita vācyasya vyañjaka tvam  vivakṣita abhidheyasya anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyasya śabda śakti udbhave prabhede pada prakāśa tā yathā
translated: To some it becomes poison, to some it becomes nectar, to some it becomes both poison and nectar, to some it becomes neither poison nor nectar—that is Time.🔽Here, in this sentence, the words 'poison' and 'nectar' have their primary meanings transferred to the forms of sorrow and happiness respectively, and thus they are used in the sense of something else. Thus, the word that has its primary meaning transferred to something else is the suggester.

original: prātuṃ dhanair arthijanasya vāñchāṃ🔽daivena sṛṣṭo yadi nāma nāsmi /🔽pathi prasannāmbudharas taḍāgaḥ
analyzed: prātum dhanaiḥ arthi janasya vāñchām  daivena sṛṣṭaḥ yadi nāma na asmi  pathi prasanna ambudharaḥ taḍāgaḥ
translated: The illumination of a word is seen in the case of a secondary meaning that is an echo of the intended primary meaning, which arises from the power of the word, as in the following:🔽If I have not been created by fate to fulfill the desire of the needy for wealth,

original: kūpo 'thavā kiṃ na jaḍaḥ kṛto 'ham //
analyzed: kim na jaḍaḥ kṛtaḥ ham
translated: then why have I been made a dull well or a lake with clear water on the path?

original: atra hi jaḍa iti padaṃ nirviṇṇena vakrātmasamānādhikaraṇatayā prayuktam anuraṇanarūpatayā kūpasamānādhikaraṇatāṃ svaśaktyā pratipadyate
analyzed: atra hi jaḍaḥ iti padam nirviṇṇena vakra ātma samāna adhikaraṇatayā prayuktam anuraṇana rūpatayā kūpa samāna adhikaraṇatām sva śaktyā pratipadyate
translated: For here, the word 'dull' is used by a disgusted person in relation to the crooked self, and by its own power it attains the state of being in relation to the well in the form of an echo.

original: tasyaiva vākyaprakāśatā yathā harṣacarite siṃhanādavākyeṣuvṛtte 'smin mahāpralaye dharaṇīdhāraṇāyādhunā tvaṃ śeṣaḥ /🔽etad dhi vākyam anuraṇanarūpam arthāntaraṃ śabdaśaktyā sphuṭam eva prakāśayati /
analyzed: tasya eva vākya prakāśa tā yathā harṣacarite siṃhanāda vākya iṣu vṛtte smin mahāpralaye dharaṇī dhāraṇāya adhunā tvam śeṣaḥ  etat hi vākyam anuraṇana rūpam artha antaram śabda śaktyā sphuṭam eva prakāśayati
translated: The same is the case with the statement in the Haravijaya, in the verses on the lion's roar, that Now that this great dissolution has taken place, you are the only one to support the earth.🔽For this statement clearly reveals another meaning in the form of an echo by the power of the word.

original: asyaiva kaviprauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīrasyārthaśaktyudbhave prabhede padaprakāśatayā /
analyzed: asya eva kavi prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīrasya artha śakti udbhave prabhede pada prakāśa tayā
translated: This is the variety that arises from the power of the meaning in the case of this [statement] whose body is produced merely by the bold statement of the poet, as word-illumination.

original: yathā harivijaye
analyzed: yathā harivijaye
translated: As in the Haravijaya:

original: cūaṃkurābaaṃsaṃ chaṇapasara
analyzed: chaṇapasara
translated: With a mango bud as an earring, with a momentary gait,

original: mahagghaṇamaṇaharasurāmoaṃ /
translated: intoxicated with the fragrance of the very expensive perfume,

original: asamappiaṃ pi gahiaṃ kusuma
analyzed: a samappiam pi gahiam kusuma
translated: the flower arrow, though not offered, took hold of

original: sareṇa mahumāsalacchimuhaṃ //
analyzed: sareṇa
translated: the face of the spring season's Lakshmi.

original: cūtāṅkurāvataṃsaṃ kṣaṇaprasara
analyzed: cūta aṅkura avataṃsam kṣaṇa prasara
translated: With a mango bud as an earring, with a momentary gait,

original: mahārghamanoharasurāmodam /
analyzed: mahārgha manohara sura āmodam
translated: intoxicated with the fragrance of the very expensive perfume,

original: asamarpitam api gṛhītaṃ kusuma
analyzed: a samarpitam api gṛhītam kusuma
translated: the flower arrow, though not offered, took hold of

original: śareṇa madhumāsalakṣmīmukham //
analyzed: śareṇa madhu māsa lakṣmī mukham
translated: the face of the spring season's Lakshmi.

original: atra hy asamarpitam api kusumaśareṇa madhumāsalakṣmyā mukhaṃ gṛhītam ity asamarpitam apīty etad avasthābhidhāyipadam arthaśaktyā kusumaśarasya
analyzed: atra hi asamarpitam api kusuma śareṇa madhu māsa lakṣmyāḥ mukham gṛhītam iti asamarpitam api iti etat avasthā abhidhāyi padam artha śaktyā kusuma śarasya
translated: For here, although not offered by the flower-arrowed one, the face is taken by the glory of the month of spring. Thus, the word although not offered expressing a state reveals by the power of meaning that the flower-arrowed one

original: balātkāraṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: balātkāram prakāśayati
translated: uses force.

original: atraiva prabhede vākyaprakāśatā yathodāhṛtaṃ prāk sajjayati surabhimāso ity ādi /
analyzed: atrā eva prabhede vākya prakāśa tā yathā udāhṛtam prāk sajjayati iti ādi
translated: In this very division, the manifestation by sentence is as previously cited, beginning with The fragrant month prepares.

original: atra sajjayati surabhimāso na tāvad arpayaty anaṅgāya śarān ity ayaṃ vākyārthaḥ kaviprauḍhoktimātraniṣpannaśarīro manmathonmāthakadanāvasthāṃ
analyzed: atra sajjayati surabhi māsaḥ na tāvat arpayati anaṅgāya śarān iti ayam vākya arthaḥ kavi prauḍha ukti mātra niṣpanna śarīraḥ manmatha unmātha kadana avasthām
translated: Here, the sentence meaning The fragrant month prepares, but does not yet offer arrows to the god of love, which has a body produced solely by the poet's mature statement, indicates the state of confusion and destruction by Cupid

original: vasantasamayasya sūcayati /
analyzed: vasanta samayasya sūcayati
translated: of the spring season.

original: svataḥsambhaviśarīrārthaśaktyudbhave prabhede padaprakāśatā yathā
analyzed: svatas sambhavi śarīra artha śakti udbhave prabhede pada prakāśa tā yathā
translated: In the division arising from the power of the inherent meaning of the self-existent body, the manifestation by word is as follows:🔽Merchant! Where are the ivory and tiger-skins for us?

original: vāṇiaa hatthidantā kutto amhāṇaṃ bāghakittī a /🔽jāva luliālaamuhī gharammi parisakkae suṇhā //
analyzed: hatthi dantā kuttaḥ amhāṇam  jāva suṇhā
translated: As long as the daughter-in-law with disheveled hair is embraced in the house.

original: vāṇijaka hastidantāḥ kuto 'smākaṃ vyāghrakṛttayaś ca /
analyzed: vāṇijaka hasti dantāḥ kutas smākam vyāghra kṛttayaḥ ca
translated: Merchant! Where are the ivory and tiger-skins for us?

original: yāval lulitālakamukhī gṛhe pariṣvakkate snuṣā //
analyzed: yāvat lulita alaka mukhī gṛhe pariṣvakkate snuṣā
translated: As long as the daughter-in-law with disheveled hair is embraced in the house.

original: atra lulitālakamukhīty etatpadaṃ vyādhavadhvāḥ svataḥsambhāvitaśarīrārthaśaktyā suratakrīḍāsaktiṃ sūcayaṃs tadīyasya bhartuḥ satatasambhogakṣāmatāṃ
analyzed: atra lulita alaka mukhī iti etat padam vyādha vadhvāḥ svatas sambhāvita śarīra artha śaktyā surata krīḍā saktim sūcayan tadīyasya bhartuḥ satata sambhoga kṣāma tām
translated: Here, the word 'with hair disheveled and face' by the power of the inherent meaning of the body of the hunter's wife, indicating her attachment to love play, reveals the constant exhaustion of her husband

original: prakāśayati /
analyzed: prakāśayati
translated: due to enjoyment.

original: tasyaiva vākyaprakāśatā / yathā
analyzed: tasya eva vākya prakāśa tā yathā
translated: The illumination is by that very sentence. For example:

original: sihipicchakaṇṇaūrā bahuā bāhassa gabbirī bhamai /
analyzed: sihi piccha kaṇṇa ūrā bahuā bāhassa gabbirī bhamai
translated: With peacock feathers in her ears, the pregnant wife of the hunter wanders.

original: muttāphalaraiapasāhaṇāṇaṃ majjhe sabattīṇaṃ //
analyzed: muttāphala raia pasāhaṇāṇam majjhe
translated: In the midst of those adorned with pearl ornaments, she is the most beautiful.

original: śikhipicchakarṇapūrā jāyā vyādhasya garviṇī bhramati /
analyzed: śikhi piccha karṇapūrā jāyā vyādhasya garviṇī bhramati
translated: With peacock feathers in her ears, the pregnant wife of the hunter wanders.

original: muktāphalaracitaprasādhanānāṃ madhye sapatnīnām //
analyzed: muktāphala racita prasādhanānām madhye sapatnīnām
translated: In the midst of those adorned with pearl ornaments, she is the most beautiful.

original: anenāpi vākyena vyādhavadhvāḥ śikhipicchikarṇapūrāyā navapariṇītāyāḥ kasyāścit saubhāgyātiśayaḥ prakāśyate /
analyzed: anena api vākyena vyādha vadhvāḥ śikhi picchi karṇapūrāyāḥ nava pariṇītāyāḥ kasyāścid saubhāgya atiśayaḥ prakāśyate
translated: By this sentence also, the excessive good fortune of some newly married wife of the hunter with peacock feather earrings is revealed.

original: tatsambhogaikarato mayūramātramāraṇasamarthaḥ patir jāta ity arthaprakāśanāt tad anyāsāṃ cirapariṇītānāṃ muktāphalaracitaprasādhanānāṃ
analyzed: tad sambhoga eka rataḥ mayūra mātra māraṇa samarthaḥ patiḥ jātaḥ iti artha prakāśanāt tat anyāsām cira pariṇītānām muktāphala racita prasādhanānām
translated: Her husband, who is devoted only to enjoying her and capable of killing only peacocks, is born. By revealing this meaning, the excessive misfortune of others who are married for a long time

original: daurbhāgyātiśayaḥ khyāpyate /
analyzed: daurbhāgya atiśayaḥ khyāpyate
translated: and are adorned with pearl ornaments is proclaimed.

original: tat sasambhogakāle sa eva vyādhaḥ karivaravadhavyāpārasamartha āsīd ity arthaprakāśanāt /
analyzed: tat sa sambhoga kāle saḥ eva vyādhaḥ kari vara vadha vyāpāra samarthaḥ āsīt iti artha prakāśanāt
translated: because the meaning that is revealed is that at the time of the enjoyment of the rasa, the hunter was capable of the act of killing the best of elephants.

original: nanu kāvyaviśeṣo dhvanir ity uktaṃ tat kathaṃ tasya padaprakāśatā /
analyzed: nanu kāvya viśeṣaḥ dhvaniḥ iti uktam tat katham tasya pada prakāśa tā
translated: But it has been said that dhvani is a particular kind of poetry. How then can it be manifested by words?

original: kāvyaviśeṣo hi viśiṣtārthapratipattihetuḥ śabdasandarbhaviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kāvya viśeṣaḥ hi viśiṣta artha pratipatti hetuḥ śabda sandarbha viśeṣaḥ
translated: For a particular kind of poetry is a particular arrangement of words that causes the understanding of a particular meaning.

original: tadbhāvaś ca padaprakāśatve nopapadyate /
analyzed: tad bhāvaḥ ca pada prakāśa tve nā upapadyate
translated: And that cannot be established if it is manifested by words.

original: padānāṃ smārakatvenāvācakatvāt /
analyzed: padānām smāraka tvena a vācaka tvāt
translated: Because words are not expressive by way of reminding.

original: ucyatesyād eṣa doṣaḥ yadi vācakatvaṃ prayojakaṃ dhvanivyavahāre syāt /
analyzed: ucyate syāt eṣa doṣaḥ yadi vācaka tvam prayojakam dhvani vyavahāre syāt
translated: It is said that this fault would arise if expressiveness were the basis for the designation of dhvani.

original: na tv evam / tasya vyañjakatvena vyavasthānāt /
analyzed: na tu evam tasya vyañjaka tvena vyavasthānāt
translated: But that is not so, because it is established by way of suggestion.

original: kiṃ ca kāvyānāṃ śarīrāṇām iva saṃsthānaviśeṣāvacchinnasamudāyasādhyāpi cārutvapratītir
analyzed: kim ca kāvyānām śarīrāṇām iva saṃsthāna viśeṣa avacchinna samudāya sādhyā api cāru tva pratītiḥ
translated: Moreover, the perception of beauty, which is accomplished by a collection of parts defined by a particular arrangement, is like the beauty of the bodies of poems.

original: anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ bhāgeṣu kalpyata iti padānām api vyañjakatvamukhena vyavasthito
analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām bhāgeṣu kalpyate iti padānām api vyañjaka tva mukhena
translated: It is imagined in the parts by the methods of agreement and difference. Thus, even for words, the designation of dhvani, which is established by way of suggestion,

original: dhvanivyavahāro na virodhī /
analyzed: dhvani vyavahāraḥ na virodhī
translated: is not contradictory.

original: aniṣṭasya śrutir yadvad āpādayati duṣṭatām /
analyzed: aniṣṭasya śrutiḥ yadvat āpādayati duṣṭa tām
translated: Just as the hearing of something undesirable brings about a sense of fault,

original: śrutiduṣṭādiṣu vyaktaṃ tadvad iṣṭasmṛtir guṇam //
analyzed: śruti duṣṭa ādiṣu vyaktam tadvat iṣṭa smṛtiḥ guṇam
translated: In the case of words like 'śrutiduṣṭa' etc., the recollection of the desired meaning is clearly a quality.

original: padānāṃ smārakatve 'pi padamātrāvabhāsinaḥ /
analyzed: padānām smāraka tve pi pada mātra avabhāsinaḥ
translated: Even when words serve to remind, they appear as mere words.

original: tena dhvaneḥ prabhedeṣu sarveṣv evāsti ramyatā //
analyzed: tena dhvaneḥ prabhedeṣu sarveṣu evā asti ramya tā
translated: Therefore, in all the varieties of dhvani, there is beauty.

original: vicchittiśobhinaikena bhūṣaṇeneva kāminī /
analyzed: vicchitti śobhinā ekena bhūṣaṇena iva kāminī
translated: Like a woman adorned with a single ornament that is pleasing to the eye,

original: padadyotyena sukaver dhvaninā bhāti bhāratī //
analyzed: pada dyotyena su kaveḥ dhvaninā bhāti bhāratī
translated: The speech of a good poet shines with dhvani, which is illuminated by words.

original: iti parikaraślokāḥ // / //🔽yas tv alakṣyakramavyaṅgyo dhvanir varṇapadādiṣu /
analyzed: iti parikara ślokāḥ  yaḥ tu alakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ dhvaniḥ varṇa pada ādiṣu
translated: Thus are the introductory verses.🔽That dhvani which is manifested by words, sentences, etc. without the sequence being perceived,

original: vākye saṅghaṭanāyāṃ ca sa prabandhe 'pi dīpyate // / //
analyzed: vākye saṅghaṭanāyām ca sa prabandhe dīpyate
translated: shines in a composition, in a metrical composition, and also in a connected series.

original: tatra varṇānām anarthakatvād dyotakatvam asambhavīty āśaṅkyedam ucyate
analyzed: tatra varṇānām anarthaka tvāt dyotaka tvam asambhavi iti āśaṅkya idam ucyate
translated: There, since letters are meaningless, the possibility of their being illuminators is doubted, and this is said:

original: śaṣau sarephasaṃyogo ḍhakāraś cāpi bhūyasā /
analyzed: śa ṣau sa repha saṃyogaḥ ḍhakāraḥ ca api bhūyasā
translated: The combination of śa, ṣa, and sa, and also the letter ḍha, are mostly contradictory,

original: virodhinaḥ syuḥ śṛṅgāre te na varṇā rasacyutaḥ // / //
analyzed: virodhinaḥ syuḥ śṛṅgāre te na varṇāḥ rasa cyutaḥ
translated: in erotic sentiment. Those letters do not deviate from rasa.

original: ta eva tu niveśyante bībhatsādau rase yadā /
analyzed: te eva tu niveśyante bībhatsā ādau rase yadā
translated: But when they are used in a sentiment like disgust,

original: tadā taṃ dīpayanty eva te na varṇā rasacyutaḥ // / //
analyzed: tadā tam dīpayanti eva te na varṇāḥ rasa cyutaḥ
translated: then they illuminate it. Those letters do not deviate from rasa.

original: ślokadvayenānvayavyatirekābhyāṃ varṇānāṃ dyotakatvaṃ darśitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: śloka dvayena anvaya vyatirekābhyām varṇānām dyotaka tvam darśitam bhavati
translated: By the two verses, the illuminator nature of letters is shown by positive and negative concomitance.

original: pade cālakṣyakramavyaṅgyasya dyotanaṃ yathā🔽utkampinī bhayapariskhalitāṃśukāntā🔽te locane pratidiśaṃ vidhure kṣipantī /
analyzed: pade ca alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya dyotanam yathā  utkampinī bhaya pariskhalita aṃśuka antā  te locane pratidiśam vidhure kṣipantī
translated: The suggestion of the sentiment that is manifested by the word, without regard to sequence, is as follows:🔽Your eyes, trembling, with the hem of your garment slipping off in fear,🔽casting about in all directions,

original: krūreṇa dāruṇatayā sahasaiva dagdhā
analyzed: krūreṇa dāruṇa tayā sahasā eva dagdhā
translated: were suddenly burned by the cruel fire, with its terrible nature,

original: dhūmāndhitena dahanena na vīkṣitāsi //
analyzed: dhūma andhitena dahanena na vīkṣitā asi
translated: but not seen by me, blinded by the smoke of the burning.🔽Here, the word your is clearly perceived by the connoisseurs as being full of sentiment.

original: atra hi te ity etat padaṃ rasamayatvena sphuṭam evāvabhāsate sahṛdayānām / yathā vā
analyzed: atra hi te iti etat padam rasa maya tvena sphuṭam eva avabhāsate sahṛdayānām yathā vā
translated: Or, as in the following verse:

original: jhagiti kanakacitre tatra dṛṣṭe kuraṅge
analyzed: kanaka citre tatra dṛṣṭe kuraṅge
translated: When the golden-spotted deer was seen there suddenly,

original: rabhasavilasitās te dṛṣṭipātāḥ priyāyāḥ /🔽pavanavilulitānām utpalānāṃ palāśa
analyzed: rabhasa vilasitāḥ te dṛṣṭipātāḥ priyāyāḥ  pavana vilulitānām utpalānām palāśa
translated: those glances of the beloved, playfully darting about,🔽scattering like a cluster of blue lotuses shaken by the wind,

original: prakaram iva kirantaḥ smaryamāṇā dahanti //
analyzed: prakaram iva kirantaḥ smaryamāṇāḥ dahanti
translated: when remembered, burn (me).

original: Not found in all editions /
analyzed: not found in all editions
translated: not found in all editions.

original: padāvayavena dyotanaṃ yathā🔽vrīḍāyogān natavadanayā sannidhāne gurūṇāṃ
analyzed: pada avayavena dyotanam yathā  vrīḍā yogāt nata vadanayā sannidhāne gurūṇām
translated: The suggestion by a part of the word is as follows:🔽Out of bashfulness, with her face lowered, in the presence of elders,

original: baddhotkampaṃ kucakalaśayor manyum antar nigṛhya /🔽tiṣṭhety uktaṃ kim iva na tayā yat samutsṛjya bāṣpaṃ
analyzed: baddha utkampam kuca kalaśayoḥ manyum antar nigṛhya  tiṣṭha iti uktam kim iva na tayā yat samutsṛjya bāṣpam
translated: restraining the anger that trembled in her breasts,🔽what is it that she did not say to me, when, holding back her tears,

original: mayy āsaktaś cakitahariṇīhārinetratribhāgaḥ //
analyzed: mayi āsaktaḥ cakita hariṇī hāri netra tri bhāgaḥ
translated: her eyes, which are like those of a startled doe, were fixed upon me?

original: ity atra tribhāgaśabdaḥ /
analyzed: iti atra tri bhāga śabdaḥ
translated: Here the word tribhāga (three parts).

original: vākyarūpaś cālakṣyakramavyaṅgyo dhvaniḥ śuddho 'laṅkārasaṅkīrṇaś ceti dvidhā mataḥ /
analyzed: vākya rūpaḥ ca alakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ dhvaniḥ śuddhaḥ laṅkāra saṅkīrṇaḥ ca iti dvidhā mataḥ
translated: And suggestion whose sequence is not perceived is considered to be of two kinds: pure and mixed with figures of speech.

original: tatra śuddhasyodāharaṇaṃ yathā rāmābhyudayekṛtakakupitaiḥ ity ādi ślokaḥ /
analyzed: tatra śuddhasya udāharaṇam yathā rāma abhyudaye kṛtaka kupitaiḥ iti ādi ślokaḥ
translated: An example of the pure kind is the verse beginning with Kṛtaka-kupitair in the Rāmābhyudaya.

original: etad dhi vākyaṃ parasparānurāgaṃ paripoṣaprāptaṃ pradarśayat sarvata eva paraṃ rasatattvaṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: etat hi vākyam paraspara anurāgam paripoṣa prāptam pradarśayat sarvatas eva param rasa tattvam prakāśayati
translated: For this sentence, displaying mutual affection that has reached fullness, reveals the highest truth of rasa in every way.

original: alaṅkārāntarasaṅkīrṇo /
analyzed: alaṅkāra antara saṅkīrṇaḥ
translated: Mixed with another figure of speech.

original: yathāsmaranavanadīpūreṇoḍhāḥ ity ādiślokaḥ /
analyzed: yathā asmara nava nadīpūreṇa ūḍhāḥ iti ādi ślokaḥ
translated: Like the verse beginning with Uḍhāḥ in Smarana-navanadīpūreṇa.

original: atra hi rūpakeṇa yathoktavyañjakalakṣaṇānugatena prasādhito rasaḥ sutarām abhivyajyate // / //
analyzed: atra hi rūpakeṇa yathā ukta vyañjaka lakṣaṇa anugatena prasādhitaḥ rasaḥ sutarām abhivyajyate
translated: For here rasa, accomplished by a simile that conforms to the definition of what manifests as stated, is expressed all the more.

original: alakṣyakramavyaṅgyaḥ saṅghaṭanāyāṃ bhāsate dhvanir ity uktaṃ tatra saṅghaṭanāsvarūpam eva tāvan nirūpyate
analyzed: alakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ saṅghaṭanāyām bhāsate dhvaniḥ iti uktam tatra saṅghaṭanā svarūpam eva tāvat nirūpyate
translated: It has been said that suggestion shines in composition whose sequence is not perceived. There, the nature of composition itself is being determined.

original: asamāsā samāsena madhyamena ca bhūṣitā /
analyzed: asamāsā samāsena madhyamena ca bhūṣitā
translated: Adorned with the middle and with a long compound,

original: tathā dīrghasamāseti tridhā saṅghaṭanoditā // / //
analyzed: tathā dīrgha samāsa iti tridhā saṅghaṭana uditā
