translated: with tears flowing from the eyes of beautiful women, and with horripilation upon seeing a virtuous person of great qualities,

original: hā dhik kaṣṭam aho kva yāmi śaraṇaṃ teṣāṃ janānāṃ kṛte
analyzed: hā dhik kaṣṭam aho kva yāmi śaraṇam teṣām janānām kṛte
translated: alas, alas! What shall I do for the sake of those people,

original: nītānāṃ pralayaṃ śaṭhena vidhinā sādhudviṣaḥ puṣyatā //ity ādau /
analyzed: nītānām pralayam śaṭhena vidhinā sādhu dviṣaḥ puṣyatai iti ādau
translated: who have been destroyed by the deceitful fate that hates the virtuous?

original: padapaunaruktyaṃ ca vyañjakatvāpekṣayaiva kadācitprayujyamānaṃ śobhāmāvahati /
analyzed: pada paunaruktyam ca vyañjaka tva apekṣayā eva kadācid prayujyamānam śobhām āvahati
translated: And the repetition of words, when used sometimes, brings beauty, depending on the suggestive power.

original: yathā🔽yad vañcanāhitamatir bahucāṭugarbhaṃ
analyzed: yathā  yat vañcana āhita matiḥ bahu cāṭu garbham
translated: As in the following:🔽The wicked person, his mind captivated by deceit, speaks insincerely,

original: kāryonmukhaḥ khalajanaḥ kṛtakaṃ bravīti /
analyzed: kārya unmukhaḥ khala janaḥ kṛtakam bravīti
translated: full of flattery, with his face turned towards his goal.

original: tat sādhavo na na vidanti vidanti kintu
analyzed: tat sādhavaḥ na na vidanti vidanti kintu
translated: The virtuous do not not know this, but they know it;

original: kartuṃ vṛthāpraṇayam asya na pārayanti //ity ādau /
analyzed: kartum vṛthā praṇayam asya na pārayanti iti ādau
translated: but they cannot bring themselves to show him false affection.

original: kālasya vyañjakatvaṃ yathā🔽samaviṣamanirviśeṣāḥ samantato mandamandasañcārāḥ /
analyzed: kālasya vyañjaka tvam yathā  sama viṣama nirviśeṣāḥ samantataḥ manda manda sañcārāḥ
translated: As for the suggestive power of time, it is as follows:🔽The paths, without distinction of even and uneven, moving slowly and slowly in all directions,

original: acirād bhaviṣyanti panthāno manorathānām api durlaṅghyāḥ //
analyzed: acirāt bhaviṣyanti panthānaḥ manorathānām api durlaṅghyāḥ
translated: will soon become impassable even for the wishes.

original: atra hy acirād bhaviṣyanti panthāna ity atra bhaviṣyantīty asmin pade pratyayaḥ kālaviśeṣābhidhāyī rasaparipoṣahetuḥ prakāśate /
analyzed: atra hi acirāt bhaviṣyanti panthānaḥ iti atra bhaviṣyanti iti asmin pade pratyayaḥ kāla viśeṣa abhidhāyī rasa paripoṣa hetuḥ prakāśate
translated: For here the suffix in the word 'will be' (bhaviṣyanti) which expresses a particular time, namely, 'in a short while', appears as the cause of the nourishment of rasa.

original: ayaṃ hi gāthārthaḥ pravāsavipralambhaśṛṅgāravibhāvatayā vibhāvyamāno rasavān /
analyzed: ayam hi gāthā arthaḥ pravāsa vipralambha śṛṅgāra vibhāva tayā vibhāvyamānaḥ rasavān
translated: For this verse-meaning, being conceived as the excitant of the sentiment of love in separation due to the husband's absence, is endowed with rasa.

original: yathātra pratyayāṃśo vyañjakas tathā kvacit prakṛtyaṃśo 'pi dṛśyate / yathā
analyzed: yathā atra pratyaya aṃśaḥ vyañjakaḥ tathā kvacid prakṛti aṃśaḥ dṛśyate yathā
translated: Just as the suffix is the suggester here, in some cases the stem is also seen to be so. For example,

original: tad gehaṃ natabhitti mandiram idaṃ labdhāvagāhaṃ divaḥ🔽sā dhenur jaratī caranti kariṇām etā ghanābhā ghaṭāḥ /
analyzed: tat geham nata bhitti mandiram idam labdha avagāham divaḥ  sā dhenuḥ jaratī caranti kariṇām etāḥ ghana ābhāḥ ghaṭāḥ
translated: That house with sloping walls, this temple has obtained the depth of heaven,🔽Those are old cows grazing, these are the dark-hued clouds of elephants.

original: sa kṣudro musaladhvaniḥ kalam idaṃ saṅgītakaṃ yoṣitām🔽āścaryaṃ divasair dvijo 'yam iyatīṃ bhūmiṃ samāropitaḥ //
analyzed: sa kṣudraḥ musala dhvaniḥ kalam idam saṅgītakam yoṣitām  āścaryam divasaiḥ dvijaḥ yam iyatīm bhūmim samāropitaḥ
translated: That is the small sound of the pestle, this is the melodious singing of the women.🔽It is a wonder that in a few days this brahmin has been raised to such a high position.

original: atra śloke divasair ity asmin pade prakṛtyaṃśo 'pi dyotakaḥ /
analyzed: atra śloke divasaiḥ iti asmin pade prakṛti aṃśaḥ dyotakaḥ
translated: In this verse, the stem in the word 'divasaiḥ' (in a few days) is also the illuminator.

original: sarvanāmnāṃ ca vyañjakatvaṃ yathānantarokte śloke /
analyzed: sarvanāmnām ca vyañjaka tvam yathā anantara ukte śloke
translated: And the suggestiveness of all nouns is like in the verse just mentioned.

original: atra ca sarvanāmnām eva vyañjakatvaṃ hṛdi vyavasthāpya kavinā kvetyādiśabdaprayogo na kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: atra ca sarvanāmnām eva vyañjaka tvam hṛdi vyavasthāpya kavinā kva ityādi śabda prayogaḥ na kṛtaḥ
translated: And here the poet, having determined that it is only the pronouns that are suggestive, has not used words like 'kva' etc.

original: anayā diśā sahṛdayair anye 'pi vyañjakaviśeṣāḥ svayam utprekṣaṇīyāḥ /
analyzed: anayā diśā sahṛdayaiḥ anye vyañjaka viśeṣāḥ svayam utprekṣaṇīyāḥ
translated: In this way, other specific suggesters should be imagined by the connoisseurs themselves.

original: etac ca sarvaṃ padavākyaracanādyotanoktyaiva gatārtham api vaicitryeṇa vyutpattaye punaruktam /
analyzed: etat ca sarvam pada vākya racanā dyotana uktyā eva gatārtham api vaicitryeṇa vyutpattaye punar uktam
translated: And although all this has been explained by the statement on the arrangement of words and sentences, it is repeated again for the sake of understanding the variety.

original: nanu cārthasāmarthyākṣepyā rasādaya ity uktam /
analyzed: nanu ca artha sāmarthya ākṣepyāḥ rasa ādayaḥ iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that rasa etc. are implied by the power of the meaning.

original: tathā ca subādīnāṃ vyañjakatvavaicitryakathanam ananvitam eva /
analyzed: tathā ca sup ādīnām vyañjaka tva vaicitrya kathanam ananvitam eva
translated: And in that case, the description of the variety of suggestiveness of words like 'su' etc. is indeed irrelevant.

original: uktam atra padānāṃ vyañjakatvoktyavasare /
translated: This has been said on the occasion of the statement of the suggestiveness of words.

original: kiṃ cārthaviśeṣākṣepyatve 'pi rasādīnāṃ teṣām arthaviśeṣāṇāṃ vyañjakaśabdāvinābhāvitvād yathāpradarśitaṃ vyañjakasvarūpaparijñānaṃ vibhajyopayujyata 🔽eva /
analyzed: kim ca artha viśeṣa ākṣepya tve pi rasa ādīnām teṣām artha viśeṣāṇām vyañjaka śabda avinābhāvi tvāt yathā pradarśitam vyañjaka svarūpa parijñānam vibhajya upayujyata  eva
translated: Moreover, even if rasa etc. are implied by the specific meaning, since those specific meanings are invariably concomitant with the suggestive words, the knowledge of the nature of the suggestive form as demonstrated is useful when analyzed.

original: śabdaviśeṣāṇāṃ cānyatra ca cārutvaṃ yad vibhāgenopadarśitaṃ tad api teṣāṃ vyañjakatvenaivāvasthitam ity avagantavyam /
analyzed: śabda viśeṣāṇām ca anyatra ca cāru tvam yat vibhāgena upadarśitam tat api teṣām vyañjaka tvena eva avasthitam iti avagantavyam
translated: And the beauty that is shown separately in the specific words should also be understood to exist as their suggestiveness.

original: yatrāpi na tat sampratibhāsate tatrāpi vyañjake racanāntare yad adṛṣṭaṃ sauṣṭhavaṃ teṣāṃ pravāhapatitānāṃ tad evābhyāsād apoddhṛtānām apy 🔽avabhāsata ity avasātavyam /
analyzed: yatra api na tat sampratibhāsate tatra api vyañjake racanā antare yat adṛṣṭam sauṣṭhavam teṣām pravāha patitānām tat eva abhyāsāt apoddhṛtānām api  avabhāsate iti avasātavyam
translated: Even where that [beauty] does not appear, in that case also, when the skill of those [words] that is not seen in another arrangement of the suggestive [words] falls into a stream, that very [skill] is perceived even when extracted by practice. This should be ascertained.

original: ko 'nyathā tulye vācakatve śabdānāṃ cārutvaviṣayo viśeṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kaḥ nyathā tulye vācaka tve śabdānām cāru tva viṣayaḥ viśeṣaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, what difference could there be in the expressiveness of words, which is the same, that would be the basis for beauty?

original: anya evāsau sahṛdayasaṃvedya iti cet /
analyzed: anyaḥ eva asau sahṛdaya saṃvedyaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is a different [kind of beauty] that is to be experienced by the connoisseur,

original: kim idaṃ sahṛdayatvaṃ nāma /🔽kiṃ rasabhāvānapekṣakāvyāśritasamayaviśeṣābhijñatvam /
analyzed: kim idam sahṛdaya tvam nāma  kim rasa bhāva anapekṣa kāvya āśrita samaya viśeṣa abhijña tvam
translated: then what is this so-called connoisseurship?🔽Is it the knowledge of a particular convention based on a poem that does not depend on rasa and bhāva?

original: uta rasabhāvādimayakāvyasvarūpaparijñānanaipuṇyam /
analyzed: uta rasa bhāva ādi maya kāvya svarūpa parijñāna naipuṇyam
translated: Or is it the skill in fully understanding the nature of a poem consisting of rasa, bhāva, etc.?

original: pūrvasmin pakṣe tathāvidhasahṛdayavyavasthāpitānāṃ śabdaviśeṣāṇāṃ cārutvaniyamo na syāt /
analyzed: pūrvasmin pakṣe tathāvidha sahṛdaya vyavasthāpitānām śabda viśeṣāṇām cāru tva niyamaḥ na syāt
translated: In the former case, there would be no fixed rule of beauty for the particular words established by such connoisseurs.

original: punaḥ samayāntareṇānyathāpi vyavasthāpanasambhavāt /
analyzed: punar samaya antareṇa anyathā api vyavasthāpana sambhavāt
translated: Because it is possible to establish them differently again by another convention.

original: dvitīyasmiṃs tu pakṣe rasajñataiva sahṛdayatvam iti /
analyzed: dvitīyasmin tu pakṣe rasa jña tā eva sahṛdaya tvam iti
translated: But in the latter case, connoisseurship is just the knowledge of rasa.

original: tathāvidhaiḥ sahṛdayaiḥ saṃvedyo rasādisamarpaṇasāmarthyam eva naisargikaṃ śabdānāṃ viśeṣa iti vyañjakatvāśrayy eva teṣāṃ mukhyaṃ cārutvam
analyzed: tathāvidhaiḥ sahṛdayaiḥ saṃvedyaḥ rasa ādi samarpaṇa sāmarthyam eva naisargikam śabdānām viśeṣaḥ iti vyañjaka tva āśrayi eva teṣām mukhyam cāru tvam
translated: The natural excellence of words is their ability to convey rasa, etc., which is to be experienced by such sensitive readers. Thus, their primary beauty rests on their expressive power.

original: vācakatvāśrayāṇāṃ tu prasāda evārthāpekṣāyāṃ teṣāṃ viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: vācaka tva āśrayāṇām tu prasādaḥ eva artha apekṣāyām teṣām viśeṣaḥ
translated: But in the case of those [words] that depend on denotation, their excellence is clarity, which depends on the meaning.

original: arthānapekṣāyāṃ tv anuprāsādir eva // / //
analyzed: artha anapekṣāyām tu anuprāsa ādiḥ eva
translated: But in the case of those [words] that do not depend on the meaning, their excellence is alliteration, etc.

original: evaṃ rasādīnāṃ vyañjakasvarūpam abhidhāya teṣām eva virodhirūpaṃ lakṣayitum idam upakramyate
analyzed: evam rasa ādīnām vyañjaka svarūpam abhidhāya teṣām eva virodhi rūpam lakṣayitum idam upakramyate
translated: Having thus described the nature of the expressive power of rasa, etc., in order to define their contradictory forms, this is begun:

original: prabandhe muktake vāpi rasādīn bandhum icchatā /
analyzed: prabandhe muktake vā api rasa ādīn bandhum icchatā
translated: One who wishes to combine rasa, etc. in a long poem or a muktaka

original: yatnaḥ kāryaḥ sumatinā parihāre virodhinām // / //
analyzed: yatnaḥ kāryaḥ sumatinā parihāre virodhinām
translated: should make an effort, with a good mind, to avoid their contradictions.

original: prabandhe muktake vāpi rasabhāvanibandhanaṃ pratyādṛtamanāḥ kavir virodhiparihāre paraṃ yatnam ādadhīta /
analyzed: prabandhe muktake vā api rasa bhāva nibandhanam pratyādṛta manāḥ kaviḥ virodhi parihāre param yatnam ādadhīta
translated: In a long poem or a muktaka, a poet who is devoted to the composition of rasa and bhāva should make a great effort to avoid contradictions.

original: anyathā tv asya rasamayaḥ śloka eko 'pi samyaṅ na sampadyate // / //
analyzed: anyathā tu asya rasa mayaḥ ślokaḥ samyak na sampadyate  /
translated: Otherwise, even a single verse full of rasa will not be properly composed.

original: kāni punas tāni virodhīni yāni yatnataḥ kaveḥ parihartavyāni / ity ucyate
analyzed: kāni punar tāni virodhīni yāni yatnataḥ kaveḥ parihartavyāni iti ucyate
translated: Now, what are those contradictions that a poet should carefully avoid? It is said:

original: virodhirasasambandhivibhāvādiparigrahaḥ /
analyzed: virodhi rasa sambandhi vibhāva ādi parigrahaḥ
translated: The inclusion of excitants, etc. related to a contradictory sentiment,

original: vistareṇānvitasyāpi vastuno 'nyasya varṇanam // / //
analyzed: vistareṇa anvitasya api vastunaḥ nyasya varṇanam
translated: The description of another extensive topic out of order,

original: akāṇḍa eva vicchittir akāṇḍe ca prakāśanam /
analyzed: akāṇḍe eva vicchittiḥ akāṇḍe ca prakāśanam
translated: Disruption out of order, and revelation out of order,

original: paripoṣaṃ gatasyāpi paunaḥpunyena dīpanam /
analyzed: paripoṣam gatasya api paunaḥpunyena dīpanam
translated: Repeatedly illuminating even a well-developed topic,

original: rasasya syād virodhāya vṛttyanaucityam eva ca // / //🔽prastutarasāpekṣayā virodhī yo rasas tasya sambandhināṃ vibhāvabhāvānubhāvānāṃ parigraho rasavirodhahetukaḥ sambhavanīyaḥ /
analyzed: rasasya syāt virodhāya vṛtti anaucityam eva ca  prastuta rasa apekṣayā virodhī yaḥ rasaḥ tasya sambandhinām vibhāva bhāva anubhāvānām parigrahaḥ rasa virodha hetukaḥ sambhavanīyaḥ
translated: May be contradictory to the sentiment, and also unsuitability of expression.🔽The inclusion of excitants, etc. related to a contradictory sentiment, which is a cause of contradiction in sentiment, should be possible.

original: tatra virodhirasavibhāvaparigraho yathā śāntarasavibhāveṣu tadvibhāvatayaiva nirūpiteṣv anantaram eva śṛṅgārādivibhāvavarṇane /
analyzed: tatra virodhi rasa vibhāva parigrahaḥ yathā śānta rasa vibhāveṣu tad vibhāva tayā eva nirūpiteṣu anantaram eva śṛṅgāra ādi vibhāva varṇane
translated: There, the inclusion of excitants of a contradictory sentiment is like describing the excitants of erotic love, etc. immediately after the excitants of the tranquil sentiment have been determined simply as its excitants.

original: virodhirasabhāvaparigraho yathā priyaṃ prati praṇayakalahakupitāsu kāminīṣu vairāgyakathābhir anunaye /
analyzed: virodhi rasa bhāva parigrahaḥ yathā priyam prati praṇaya kalaha kupitāsu kāminīṣu vairāgya kathābhiḥ anunaye
translated: The inclusion of emotions of a contradictory sentiment is like conciliation through discourses on detachment in amorous women angry in simulated quarrels with their lovers.

original: virodhirasānubhāvaparigraho yathā praṇayakupitāyāṃ priyāyām aprasīdantyāṃ nāyakasya kopāveśavivaśasya raudrānubhāvavarṇane /
analyzed: virodhi rasa anubhāva parigrahaḥ yathā praṇaya kupitāyām priyāyām a prasīdantyām nāyakasya kopa āveśa vivaśasya raudra anubhāva varṇane
translated: An example of the introduction of the excitants and ensuants of a contradictory sentiment is found in the description of the manifestation of the sentiment of wrath in the hero who is overpowered by the influence of anger when his beloved is angry and does not appease him.

original: ayaṃ cānyo rasabhaṅgahetur yat prastutarasāpekṣayā vastuno 'nyasya kathañcid anvitasyāpi vistareṇa kathanam /
analyzed: ayam ca anyaḥ rasa bhaṅga hetuḥ yat prastuta rasa apekṣayā vastunaḥ nyasya kathañcid anvitasya api vistareṇa kathanam
translated: Another cause of the disruption of rasa is the detailed description of some other matter, even though it may be somehow connected with the sentiment intended to be described.

original: yathā vipralambhaśṛṅgāre nāyakasya kasyacid varṇayitum upakrānte kaver yamakādyalaṅkāranibandhanarasikatayā mahatā prabandhena parvatādivarṇane
analyzed: yathā vipralambha śṛṅgāre nāyakasya kasyacid varṇayitum upakrānte kaveḥ yamaka ādi alaṅkāra nibandhana rasika tayā mahatā prabandhena parvata ādi varṇane
translated: For example, when the poet begins to describe some hero in the sentiment of love in separation, he may, out of a fondness for alliteration and other figures of speech, describe at great length some mountain or other.

original: ayaṃ cāparo rasabhaṅgahetur avagantavyo yad akāṇḍa eva vicchittiḥ rasasyākaṇḍa eva ca prakāśanam /🔽tatrānavasare virāmo rasasya yathā nāyakasya kasyacit spṛhaṇīyasamāgamayā nāyikayā
analyzed: ayam ca aparaḥ rasa bhaṅga hetuḥ avagantavyaḥ yat akāṇḍe eva vicchittiḥ rasasya akaṇḍe eva ca prakāśanam  tatra anavasare virāmaḥ rasasya yathā nāyakasya kasyacid spṛhaṇīya samāgamayā nāyikayā
translated: Another cause of the disruption of rasa should be understood to be the sudden interruption of the sentiment and its sudden manifestation.🔽An example of the sudden interruption of the sentiment at an inappropriate time is found in the following verse:🔽When a certain hero, whose union with a certain beloved is much desired,

original: kayācit parāṃ paripoṣapadavīṃ prāpte śṛṅgāre vidite ca parasparānurāge samāgamopāyacintocitaṃ
analyzed: kayācid parām paripoṣa padavīm prāpte śṛṅgāre vidite ca paraspara anurāge samāgama upāya cintā ucitam
translated: has attained the highest degree of the sentiment of love, and when their mutual affection is known, and when it is proper to think of the means of bringing about their union,

original: vyavahāram utsṛjya svatantratayā vyāpārāntaravarṇane /🔽anavasare ca prakāśanaṃ rasasya yathā pravṛtte pravṛttavividhavīrasaṅkṣaye kalpasaṅkṣayakalpe
analyzed: vyavahāram utsṛjya svatantra tayā vyāpāra antara varṇane  anavasare ca prakāśanam rasasya yathā pravṛtte pravṛtta vividha vīra saṅkṣaye kalpa saṅkṣaya kalpe
translated: In abandoning the conventional mode of narration and describing the action independently,🔽and in revealing the rasa at an inappropriate time, as in the following example:

original: saṅgrāme rāmadevaprāyasyāpi tāvan nāyakasyānupakrāntavipralambhaśṛṅgārasya nimittam🔽ucitam antareṇaiva śṛṅgārakathāyām avatāravarṇane /
analyzed: saṅgrāme rāmadeva prāyasya api tāvat nāyakasya anupakrānta vipralambha śṛṅgārasya nimittam  ucitam antareṇa eva śṛṅgāra kathāyām avatāra varṇane
translated: When the various heroes were being destroyed in the battle that was like the destruction of a kalpa, even for a hero like Ramadeva, who was not engaged in the sentiment of love in separation,🔽it was not appropriate to introduce a story of love without a proper reason.🔽And in the description of the hero's entry into the story of love,

original: na caivaṃvidhe viṣaye daivavyāmohitatvaṃ kathāpuruṣasya parihāro yato rasabandha eva kaveḥ prādhānyena pravṛttinibandhanaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: na ca evaṃvidhe viṣaye daiva vyāmohita tvam kathā puruṣasya parihāraḥ yatas rasa bandhaḥ eva kaveḥ prādhānyena pravṛtti nibandhanam yuktam
translated: and in such a matter, the author's delusion by fate is not to be avoided, because the poet's engagement is rightly based primarily on the binding of rasa.

original: itivṛttavarṇanaṃ tadupāya evety uktaṃ prāk ālokārthi yathā dīpaśikhāyāṃ yatnavān janaḥ ity ādinā /
analyzed: iti vṛtta varṇanam tad upāyaḥ eva iti uktam prāk āloka arthi yathā dīpa śikhāyām yatnavān janaḥ iti ādinā
translated: The description of the story is only a means to that, as stated earlier with the words as a person striving for light is diligent in the flame of a lamp.

original: ata eva cetivṛttamātravarṇanaprādhānye 'ṅgāṅgibhāvarahitarasabhāvanibandhena
analyzed: atas eva ca iti vṛtta mātra varṇana prādhānye ṅga aṅgi bhāva rahita rasa bhāva nibandhena
translated: And for this very reason, when the poet's primary concern is the mere description of the story, and he binds rasa and bhava without the relation of primary and secondary,

original: ca kavīnām evaṃvidhāni skhalitāni bhavantīti rasādirūpavyaṅgyatātparyam evaiṣāṃ
analyzed: ca kavīnām evaṃvidhāni skhalitāni bhavanti iti rasa ādi rūpa vyaṅgya tātparyam eva eṣām
translated: such slips occur to the poets. Therefore, their intended meaning is the suggested meaning in the form of rasa, etc.

original: yuktam iti yatno 'smābhir ārabdho na dhvanipratipādanamātrābhiniveśena /
analyzed: yuktam iti smābhiḥ ārabdhaḥ na dhvani pratipādana mātra abhiniveśena
translated: We have made this effort, not out of a mere desire to expound the science of metrics, but because we think it is proper to do so.

original: punaś cāyam anyo rasabhaṅgahetur avadhāraṇīyo yat paripoṣaṃ gatasyāpi rasasya paunaḥpunyena dīpanam /
analyzed: punar ca ayam anyaḥ rasa bhaṅga hetuḥ avadhāraṇīyaḥ yat paripoṣam gatasya api rasasya paunaḥpunyena dīpanam
translated: And this other cause of the disruption of rasa should be understood: the repeated illumination of rasa, even when it has reached full development.

original: upabhukto hi rasaḥ svasāmagrīlabdhaparipoṣaḥ punaḥ punaḥ parāmṛśyamānaḥ parimlānakusumakalpaḥ kalpate /
analyzed: upabhuktaḥ hi rasaḥ sva sāmagrī labdha paripoṣaḥ punar punar parāmṛśyamānaḥ parimlāna kusuma kalpaḥ kalpate
translated: For rasa, once it has reached full development through the means proper to it, if it is repeatedly referred to, becomes like a flower whose petals have withered.

original: tathā vṛtter vyavahārasya yad anaucityaṃ tad api rasabhaṅgahetur eva /
analyzed: tathā vṛtteḥ vyavahārasya yat anaucityam tat api rasa bhaṅga hetuḥ eva
translated: Similarly, impropriety of style, that is, of usage, is also a cause of the disruption of rasa.

original: yathā nāyakaṃ prati nāyikāyāḥ kasyāścid ucitāṃ bhaṅgim antareṇa svayaṃ sambhogābhilāṣakathane /
analyzed: yathā nāyakam prati nāyikāyāḥ kasyāścid ucitām bhaṅgim antareṇa svayam sambhoga abhilāṣa kathane
translated: For example, when a certain heroine, without the proper coquettishness, herself expresses her desire for enjoyment to the hero.

original: yadi vā vṛttīnāṃ bharataprasiddhānāṃ kaiśikyādīnāṃ kāvyālaṅkārāntaraprasiddhānām upanāgarikādyānāṃ vā yad anaucityam aviṣaye nibandhanaṃ
analyzed: yadi vā vṛttīnām bharata prasiddhānām kaiśikī ādīnām kāvya alaṅkāra antara prasiddhānām upanāgarika ādyānām vā yat anaucityam aviṣaye nibandhanam
translated: Or, impropriety of style, that is, of the styles well-known to Bharata, such as the Kaishika, etc., or of the styles known in other poetic ornaments, such as the Upanagarika, etc., that is, the employment of them in an inappropriate context,

original: tad api rasabhaṅgahetuḥ /
analyzed: tat api rasa bhaṅga hetuḥ
translated: that too is a cause of the disruption of rasa.

original: evam eṣāṃ rasavirodhinām anyeṣāṃ cānayā diśā svayam utprekṣitānāṃ parihāre satkavibhir avahitair bhavitavyam /
analyzed: evam eṣām rasa virodhinām anyeṣām ca anayā diśā svayam utprekṣitānām parihāre sat kavibhiḥ avahitaiḥ bhavitavyam
translated: In the same way, good poets should be careful to avoid these and other such things that are incompatible with rasa and which they themselves may imagine in this way.

original: parikaraślokāś cātra
analyzed: parikara ślokāḥ ca atra
translated: And here are some verses in conclusion:

original: mukhyā vyāpāraviṣayāḥ sukavīnāṃ rasādayaḥ /
analyzed: mukhyāḥ vyāpāra viṣayāḥ su kavīnām rasa ādayaḥ
translated: The chief topics of the activity of good poets are rasa and the like.

original: teṣām nibandhane bhāvye taiḥ sadaivāpramādibhiḥ //
analyzed: teṣām nibandhane bhāvye taiḥ sadā eva apramādibhiḥ
translated: When composing them, they should always be careful.

original: nīrasas tu prabandho yaḥ so 'paśabdo mahān kaveḥ /
analyzed: nīrasaḥ tu prabandhaḥ yaḥ saḥ u paśabdaḥ mahān kaveḥ
translated: But a composition that is devoid of rasa is a great fault for a poet,

original: sa tenākavir eva syād anyenāsmṛtalakṣaṇaḥ //
analyzed: sa tena akaviḥ eva syāt anyena asmṛta lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: by which he would be a non-poet, his characteristics forgotten by others.

original: pūrve viśṛṅkhalagiraḥ kavayaḥ prāpyakīrtayaḥ /
analyzed: pūrve viśṛṅkhala giraḥ kavayaḥ prāpya kīrtayaḥ
translated: The ancient poets, their words unrestrained, attained fame.

original: tān samāśritya na tyājyā nītir eṣā manīṣiṇā //
analyzed: tān samāśritya na tyājyā nītiḥ eṣā manīṣiṇā
translated: Relying on them, this is the policy that the wise should not abandon.

original: vālmīkivyāsamukhyāś ca ye prakhyātāḥ kavīśvarāḥ /
analyzed: vālmīki vyāsa mukhyāḥ ca ye prakhyātāḥ kavi īśvarāḥ
translated: And Valmiki, Vyasa, and other famous great poets,

original: tadabhiprāyabāhyo 'yaṃ nāsmābhir darśito nayaḥ //iti// / //🔽vivakṣite rase labdhapratiṣṭhe tu virodhinām /
analyzed: tad abhiprāya bāhyaḥ yam na asmābhiḥ darśitaḥ nayaḥ iti  vivakṣite rase labdha pratiṣṭhe tu virodhinām
translated: this policy, which is outside their intention, has not been shown by us.🔽But when the intended rasa has been established, the mention of those to be contradicted,

original: bādhyānām aṅgabhāvaṃ vā prāptānām uktir acchalā // / //
analyzed: bādhyānām aṅga bhāvam vā prāptānām uktiḥ a chalā
translated: which have become subordinate or have attained the state of being subordinate, is faultless.

original: svasāmagryā labdhaparipoṣe tu vivakṣite rase virodhināṃ virodhirasāṅgānāṃ bādhyānām aṅgabhāvaṃ vā prāptānāṃ satām uktir adoṣā /
analyzed: sva sāmagryāḥ labdha paripoṣe tu vivakṣite rase virodhinām virodhi rasa aṅgānām bādhyānām aṅga bhāvam vā prāptānām satām uktiḥ adoṣā
translated: But when a rasa is intended to be developed by its own means, the mention of the obstructing rasas and their constituents, which are to be obstructed, or which have attained the state of being its constituents, is faultless.

original: bādhyatvaṃ hi virodhināṃ śakyābhibhavatve sati nānyathā /
analyzed: bādhya tvam hi virodhinām śakya abhibhava tve sati nā anyathā
translated: For the obstructing rasas are to be obstructed only when they are capable of being overcome, not otherwise.

original: tathā ca teṣām uktiḥ prastutarasaparipoṣāyaiva sampadyate /🔽aṅgabhāvaṃ prāptānāṃ ca teṣāṃ virodhitvam eva nivartate /
analyzed: tathā ca teṣām uktiḥ prastuta rasa paripoṣāya eva sampadyate  aṅga bhāvam prāptānām ca teṣām virodhi tvam eva nivartate
translated: And thus their mention serves only to develop the rasa intended.🔽And for those that have attained the state of being its constituents, their obstructing nature ceases.

original: aṅgabhāvaprāptir hi teṣāṃ svābhāvikī samāropakṛtā vā /
analyzed: aṅga bhāva prāptiḥ hi teṣām svābhāvikī samāra upakṛtā vā
translated: For their attainment of the state of being its constituents is either natural or imposed.

original: tatra yeṣāṃ naisargikī teṣāṃ tāvad uktāv avirodha eva /
analyzed: tatra yeṣām naisargikī teṣām tāvat uktau avirodhaḥ eva
translated: Among them, for those whose [obstructing nature] is natural, there is no contradiction in their mention.

original: yathā vipralambhaśṛṅgāre tadaṅgānāṃ vyādhyādīnāṃ teṣāṃ ca tadaṅgānām evādoṣo nātadaṅgānām /
analyzed: yathā vipralambha śṛṅgāre tad aṅgānām vyādhi ādīnām teṣām ca tad aṅgānām eva adoṣaḥ na a tad aṅgānām
translated: For example, in the erotic sentiment of love-in-separation, the natural constituents such as illness, and their constituents, are faultless, but not those that are not its constituents.

original: tadaṅgatve ca sambhavaty api maraṇasyopanyāso na jyāyān /
analyzed: tad aṅga tve ca sambhavati api maraṇasya upanyāsaḥ na jyāyān
translated: And the mention of death is not appropriate even when it can attain the state of being its constituent.

original: āśrayavicchede rasasyātyantavicchedaprāpteḥ /
analyzed: āśraya vicchede rasasya atyanta viccheda prāpteḥ
translated: Because when the basis is severed, the rasa is completely severed.

original: karuṇasya tu tathāvidhe viṣaye paripoṣo bhaviṣyatīti cet na /
analyzed: karuṇasya tu tathāvidhe viṣaye paripoṣaḥ bhaviṣyati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the sentiment of pathos will be developed in such a subject, that is not so.

original: yasyāprastutatvāt prastutasya ca vicchedāt /
analyzed: yasya a prastuta tvāt prastutasya ca vicchedāt
translated: because it is not the subject matter and because it interrupts the subject matter.

original: yatra tu karuṇarasasyaiva kāvyārthatvaṃ tatrāvirodhaḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu karuṇa rasasya eva kāvya artha tvam tatra avirodhaḥ
translated: But where the sentiment of pathos is itself the meaning of the poem, there is no contradiction.

original: śṛṅgāre vā maraṇasyādīrghakālapratyāpattisambhave kadācid upanibandho nātyantavirodhī /🔽dīrghakālapratyāpattau tu tasyāntarā pravāhaviccheda evety evaṃvidhetivṛttopanibandhanaṃ rasabandhapradhānena kavinā parihartavyam /
analyzed: śṛṅgāre vā maraṇasya adīrgha kāla pratyāpatti sambhave kadācid upanibandhaḥ na atyanta virodhī  dīrgha kāla pratyāpattau tu tasya antarā pravāha vicchedaḥ evā iti evaṃvidha iti vṛtta upanibandhanam rasa bandha pradhānena kavinā parihartavyam
translated: Or, if death is possible in love, then its inclusion is not very contradictory, if it is possible to return in a short time.🔽But if the return is after a long time, then there is an interruption in the flow in between. So a poet who is intent on the composition of rasa should avoid the inclusion of such a plot.

original: tatra labdhapratiṣṭhe tu vivakṣite rase virodhirasāṅgānāṃ bādhyatvenoktāv adoṣo yathā
analyzed: tatra labdha pratiṣṭhe tu vivakṣite rase virodhi rasa aṅgānām bādhya tvena uktau adoṣaḥ yathā
translated: But if a rasa is intended to be established there, and if it is said that the elements of contradictory sentiments are to be set aside as being sublated, then there is no fault, as in the following example:

original: kvākaryaṃ śaśalakṣmaṇaḥ kva ca kulaṃ bhūyo 'pi dṛśyeta sā
analyzed: kva akaryam śaśalakṣmaṇaḥ kva ca kulam dṛśyeta sā
translated: Where is the fault of the one with the mark of the hare? And where is the family? She may be seen again and again.

original: doṣāṇāṃ praśamāya me śrutam aho kope 'pi kāntaṃ mukham /
analyzed: doṣāṇām praśamāya me śrutam aho kope kāntam mukham
translated: I have heard that her face is lovely even in anger to pacify my faults.

original: kiṃ vakṣyanty apakalmaṣāḥ kṛtadhiyaḥ svapne 'pi sā durlabhā
analyzed: kim vakṣyanti apakalmaṣāḥ kṛta dhiyaḥ svapne sā durlabhā
translated: What will the sinless and grateful ones say? She is difficult to obtain even in a dream.

original: cetaḥ svāsthyam upaihi kaḥ khalu yuvā dhanyo 'dharaṃ pāsyati //
analyzed: cetaḥ svāsthyam upaihi kaḥ khalu yuvā dhanyaḥ dharam pāsyati
translated: O mind, be at ease. What young man will indeed drink her lip?

original: yathā vā puṇḍarīkasya mahāśvetāṃ prati pravṛttanirbharānurāgasya dvitīyamunikumāropadeśavarṇane /
analyzed: yathā vā puṇḍarīkasya mahāśvetām prati pravṛtta nirbhara anurāgasya dvitīya muni kumāra upadeśa varṇane
translated: Or, as in the following verse of the love-sick Pundarika addressed to Mahāśvetā:

original: svābhāvikyām aṅgabhāvaprāptāv adoṣo yathā🔽bhramim aratim alasahṛdayatāṃ
analyzed: svābhāvikyām aṅga bhāva prāptau adoṣaḥ yathā  bhramim aratim alasa hṛdaya tām
translated: When there is natural subordination, there is no fault, as in the following:🔽Dizziness, dejection, a languid heart,

original: pralayaṃ mūrcchāṃ tamaḥ śarīrasādam /
analyzed: pralayam mūrcchām tamaḥ śarīra sādam
translated: fainting, swooning, darkness, bodily lassitude,

original: maraṇaṃ ca jaladabhujagajaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam ca jalada bhuja gajam
translated: and even death, the serpent of the rainy season🔽overpowers the women separated from their lovers by poison.

original: prasahya kurute viṣaṃ viyoginīnām //ity ādau /
analyzed: prasahya kurute viṣam viyoginīnām iti ādau
translated: And so on.

original: samāropitāyām apy avirodho yathāpāṇḍukṣāmam ity ādau /
analyzed: samāropitāyām api avirodhaḥ yathā āpāṇḍu kṣāmam iti ādau
translated: Even when there is superimposed subordination, there is no contradiction, as in the verse beginning pale like the moon.

original: iyaṃ cāṅgabhāvaprāptir anyā yadādhikārikatvāt pradhāna ekasmin vākyārthe rasayor bhāvayor vā parasparavirodhinor dvayor aṅgabhāvagamanaṃ
analyzed: iyam ca aṅga bhāva prāptiḥ anyā yadā ādhikārika tvāt pradhāne ekasmin vākya arthe rasayoḥ bhāvayoḥ vā paraspara virodhinoḥ dvayoḥ aṅga bhāva gamanam
translated: And this subordination is different, because it is based on the principal meaning in a sentence, when two rasas or bhāvas that are mutually contradictory become subordinate to one another.

original: tasyām api na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: tasyām api na doṣaḥ
translated: Even in that case, there is no fault.

original: yathoktaṃ kṣipto hāstāvalagnaḥ ity ādau /
analyzed: yathā uktam kṣiptaḥ hā astāvalagnaḥ iti ādau
translated: As it is said in the verse beginning Alas, thrown down on the palm of the hand.

original: kathaṃ tatrāvirodha iti cet /
analyzed: katham tatra avirodhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there is no contradiction there,

original: dvayor api tayor anyaparatvena vyavasthānāt /
analyzed: dvayoḥ api tayoḥ anya para tvena vyavasthānāt
translated: it is because both of them are established as having a different purport.

original: anyaparatve 'pi virodhinoḥ kathaṃ virodhanivṛttir iti cet /
analyzed: anya para tve virodhinoḥ katham virodha nivṛttiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there can be the cessation of contradiction between two contradictory things even when they have a different purport,🔽it is said:

original: ucyatevidhau viruddhasamāveśasya duṣṭatvaṃ nānuvāde / yathā
analyzed: ucyate vidhau viruddha samāveśasya duṣṭa tvam na anuvāde yathā
translated: It is said: The combination of opposites is faulty in an injunction, not in a restatement. As in

original: ehi gaccha patottiṣṭha vada maunaṃ samācara /
analyzed: ehi gaccha pata uttiṣṭha vada maunam samācara
translated: Come, go, jump, stand up, speak, observe silence.

original: evam āśāgrahagrastaiḥ krīḍanti dhanino 'rthibhiḥ //ity ādau /
analyzed: evam āśā graha grastaiḥ krīḍanti dhaninaḥ rthibhiḥ iti ādau
translated: Thus the rich play with the supplicants seized by the noose of hope.

original: atra hi vidhipratiṣedhayor anūdyamānatvena samāveśe na virodhas tathehāpi bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: atra hi vidhi pratiṣedhayoḥ anūdyamāna tvena samāveśe na virodhaḥ tathā iha api bhaviṣyati
translated: Here, when the injunction and prohibition are restated, there is no contradiction, so it will be the same here.

original: śloke hy asminn īrṣyāvipralambhaśṛṅgārakaruṇavastunor na vidhīyamānatvam /
analyzed: śloke hi asmin īrṣyā vipralambha śṛṅgāra karuṇa vastunoḥ na vidhīyamāna tvam
translated: For in this verse, the subject of jealousy, deception, love in separation, and compassion are not being enjoined.

original: tripuraripuprabhāvātiśayasya vākyārthatvāt tadaṅgatvena ca tayor vyavasthānāt /
analyzed: tripura ripu prabhāva atiśayasya vākya artha tvāt tad aṅga tvena ca tayoḥ vyavasthānāt
translated: Because the meaning of the sentence is the greatness of the power of the enemy of Tripura, and they are established as its subordinate elements.

original: na ca raseṣu vidhyanuvādavyavahāro nāstīti śakyaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: na ca raseṣu vidhi anuvāda vyavahāraḥ na asti iti śakyam vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that there is no usage of injunction and restatement in the rasas.

original: teṣāṃ vākyārthatvenābhyupagamāt /🔽vākyārthasya vācyasya ca yau vidhyanuvādau tau tadākṣiptānāṃ rasānāṃ kena vāryate /
analyzed: teṣām vākya artha tvena abhyupagamāt  vākya arthasya vācyasya ca yau vidhi anuvādau tau tad ākṣiptānām rasānām kena vāryate
translated: Because they are accepted as the meaning of the sentence.🔽And who can prevent the rasas that are implied by the injunction and restatement of the expressed meaning, which is the meaning of the sentence?

original: yair vā sākṣātkāvyārthatā rasādīnāṃ nābhyupagamyate /
analyzed: yaiḥ vā sākṣāt kāvya artha tā rasa ādīnām na abhyupagamyate
translated: Or those who do not accept that rasa and so on are directly the meaning of poetry,

original: tais teṣāṃ tannimittatā tāvad avaśyam abhyupagantavyā /
analyzed: taiḥ teṣām tad nimitta tā tāvat avaśyam abhyupagantavyā
translated: by them the causality of those must certainly be accepted.

original: tathāpy atra śloke na virodhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api atra śloke na virodhaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, there is no contradiction in this verse.

original: yasmād anūdyamānāṅganimittobhayarasavastusahakāriṇo vidhīyamānāṃśād bhāvaviśeṣapratītir utpadyate tataś ca na kaścid virodhaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt anūdyamāna aṅga nimitta ubhaya rasa vastu sahakāriṇaḥ vidhīyamāna aṃśāt bhāva viśeṣa pratītiḥ utpadyate tatas ca na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: Because the cognition of a particular emotional state arises from the part being enjoined, which is the cooperative cause of the two flavors based on the mentioned subsidiary elements, and therefore there is no contradiction at all.

original: dṛśyate hi viruddhobhayasahakāriṇaḥ kāraṇāt kāryaviśeṣotpattiḥ /
analyzed: dṛśyate hi viruddha ubhaya sahakāriṇaḥ kāraṇāt kārya viśeṣa utpattiḥ
translated: For it is seen that a particular effect arises from a cause that is the cooperative cause of two contradictory [factors].

original: viruddhaphalotpādanahetutvaṃ hi yugapad ekasya kāraṇasya viruddhaṃ na tu viruddhobhayasahakāritvam /
analyzed: viruddha phala utpādana hetu tvam hi yugapad ekasya kāraṇasya viruddham na tu viruddha ubhaya sahakāri tvam
translated: For it is contradictory for a single cause to be the cause of producing two contradictory effects at the same time, but not for it to be the cooperative cause of two contradictory [factors].

original: evaṃvidhaviruddhapadārthaviṣayaḥ katham abhinayaḥ prayoktavya iti cet /🔽anūdyamānaivaṃvidhavācyaviṣaye yā vārtā sātrāpi bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: evaṃvidha viruddha padārtha viṣayaḥ katham abhinayaḥ prayoktavyaḥ iti ced  anūdyamānā evaṃvidha vācya viṣaye yā vārtā sā atrā api bhaviṣyati
translated: If it is asked how such a contradictory object should be performed in acting,🔽the same procedure that is to be followed in the case of a subject matter of this kind being mentioned will also be followed here.

original: evaṃvidhyanuvādanayāśrayeṇātra śloke parihṛtas tāvad virodhaḥ /
analyzed: evaṃvidhi anuvāda nayā āśrayeṇa atra śloke parihṛtaḥ tāvat virodhaḥ
translated: Thus, the contradiction in this verse has been resolved by the basis of such a kind of restatement.

original: kiṃ ca nāyakasyābhinandanīyodayasya kasyacit prabhāvātiśayavarṇane tatpratipakṣāṇāṃ
analyzed: kim ca nāyakasya abhinandanīya udayasya kasyacid prabhāva atiśaya varṇane tad pratipakṣāṇām
translated: Moreover, in the description of the great power of some rising hero who is to be admired,🔽that sentiment of pathos which is opposed to that

original: yaḥ karuṇo rasaḥ sa parīkṣakāṇāṃ na vaiklavyam ādadhāti pratyuta prītyatiśayanimittatāṃ
analyzed: yaḥ karuṇaḥ rasaḥ sa parīkṣakāṇām na vaiklavyam ādadhāti pratyuta prīti atiśaya nimitta tām
translated: does not cause the judges to lose their composure, but rather becomes the cause of an excess of joy.

original: pratipadyata ity atas tasya kuṇṭhaśaktikatvāt tadvirodhavidhāyino na kaścid doṣaḥ /
analyzed: pratipadyate iti atas tasya kuṇṭhaśaktika tvāt tad virodha vidhāyinaḥ na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: Since it is the rasa or the bhāva that is the meaning of the sentence that is contradicted, there is no fault in the contradiction of that by the word contradictory to rasa.

original: tasmād vākyārthībhūtasya rasasya bhāvasya vā virodhī rasavirodhīti vaktuṃ nyāyyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt vākya arthībhūtasya rasasya bhāvasya vā virodhī rasa virodhī iti vaktum nyāyyaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is proper to say that what is contradictory to rasa is what is contradictory to the rasa or bhāva that is the meaning of the sentence.

original: na tv aṅgabhūtasya kasyacit /
analyzed: na tu aṅga bhūtasya kasyacid
translated: But not of any [rasa or bhāva] that is a subordinate factor.

original: athavā vākyārthībhūtasyāpi kasyacit karuṇarasaviṣayasya tādṛśena śṛṅgāravastunā bhaṅgiviśeṣāśrayeṇa saṃyojanaṃ rasaparipoṣāyaiva jāyate
analyzed: athavā vākya arthībhūtasya api kasyacid karuṇa rasa viṣayasya tādṛśena śṛṅgāra vastunā bhaṅgi viśeṣa āśrayeṇa saṃyojanam rasa paripoṣāya eva jāyate
translated: Or, even if something is the meaning of the sentence, its connection with such a śṛṅgāra-matter based on a special kind of bhāṅgī is only for the nourishment of rasa,

original: yataḥ prakṛtimadhurāḥ padārthāḥ śocanīyatāṃ prāptāḥ prāgavasthābhāvibhiḥ saṃsmaryamāṇair vilāsair adhikataraṃ śokāveśam upajanayanti / yathā
analyzed: yatas prakṛti madhurāḥ padārthāḥ śocanīya tām prāptāḥ prāc avasthā bhāvibhiḥ saṃsmaryamāṇaiḥ vilāsaiḥ adhikataram śoka āveśam upajanayanti yathā
translated: because objects that are naturally sweet, when they become objects of sorrow, generate an even greater feeling of sorrow by being remembered with the playful activities that occurred in their former state. For example,

original: ayaṃ sa raśanotkarṣī pīnastanavimardanaḥ /
analyzed: ayam sa raśanā utkarṣī pīna stana vimardanaḥ
translated: This is the hand that pulled up the girdle, that pressed the full breasts,

original: nābhyūrujaghanasparśī nīvīvisraṃsanaḥ karaḥ //ity ādau /
analyzed: nābhi ūru jaghana sparśī nīvī visraṃsanaḥ karaḥ iti ādau
translated: that touched the navel, thighs and hips, and that loosened the knot of the garment.

original: tad atra tripurayuvatīnāṃ śāmbhavaḥ śarāgnir ārdrāparādhaḥ kāmī yathā vyavaharati sma /
analyzed: tat atra tripura yuvatīnām śāmbhavaḥ śara agniḥ ārdra aparādhaḥ kāmī yathā vyavaharati sma
translated: In this way, the fire of Śiva's arrow, which is moist with the crime of the young women of Tripura, behaves like a lover.

original: tathā vyavahṛtavān ity anenāpi prakāreṇāsty eva nirvirodhatvam /
analyzed: tathā vyavahṛtavān iti anena api prakāreṇa asti eva nirvirodha tvam
translated: And in the same way, by this method also, there is no contradiction.

original: tasmād yathā yathā nirūpyate tathā tathātra doṣābhāvaḥ / itthaṃ ca🔽krāmantyaḥ kṣatakomalāṅguligaladraktaiḥ sadarbhāḥ sthalīḥ🔽pādaiḥ pātitayāvakair iva patadbāṣpāmbudhautānanāḥ /🔽bhītā bhartṛkarāvalambitakarās tvadvairinātho 'dhunā
analyzed: tasmāt yathā yathā nirūpyate tathā tathā atra doṣa abhāvaḥ ittham ca  krāmantyaḥ kṣata komala aṅguli galat raktaiḥ sa darbhāḥ sthalīḥ  pādaiḥ pātita yāvakaiḥ iva patat bāṣpa ambu dhauta ānanāḥ  bhītāḥ bhartṛ kara avalambita karāḥ tvad vairi nāthaḥ dhunā
translated: Therefore, as it is examined in this way, in this way there is no fault here. And in this way,🔽The wives of your enemies, their tender limbs wounded, their feet dripping blood like red rice fallen on the ground, their faces washed with tears of grief,

original: dāvāgniṃ parito bhramanti punar apy udyadvivāhā iva //
analyzed: dāva agnim paritas bhramanti punar api udyat vivāhāḥ iva
translated: frightened, their hands clinging to the hands of their husbands, now wander around the forest fire, as if they were again about to be married.

original: ity evam ādīnāṃ sarveṣām eva nirvirodhatvam avagantavyam /
analyzed: iti evam ādīnām sarveṣām eva nirvirodha tvam avagantavyam
translated: Thus, it should be understood that all these [examples] are free from contradiction.

original: evaṃ tāvad rasādīnāṃ virodhirasādibhiḥ samāveśāsamāveśayor viṣayavibhāgo darśitaḥ // / //
analyzed: evam tāvat rasa ādīnām virodhi rasa ādibhiḥ samāveśa asamāveśayoḥ viṣaya vibhāgaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: Thus, the division of the subject matter of the inclusion and non-inclusion of rasa, etc. with contradictory rasas, etc. has been shown.

original: idānīṃ teṣām ekaprabandhaviniveśane nyāyyo yaḥ kramas taṃ pratipādayitum ucyate
analyzed: idānīm teṣām eka prabandha viniveśane nyāyyaḥ yaḥ kramaḥ tam pratipādayitum ucyate
translated: Now, in order to explain the proper sequence in the arrangement of those [rasas] in a single work, it is said:

original: prasiddhe 'pi prabandhānāṃ nānārasanibandhane /
analyzed: prasiddhe pi prabandhānām nānā rasa nibandhane
translated: Even though works are well-known to be composed with various rasas,

original: eko raso 'ṅgīkartavyas teṣām utkarṣam icchatā // / //
analyzed: ekaḥ rasaḥ ṅgīkartavyaḥ teṣām utkarṣam icchatā
translated: one rasa should be accepted by one who desires excellence for them.

original: prabandheṣu mahākāvyādiṣu nāṭakādiṣu vā viprakīrṇatayāṅgāṅgibhāvena bahavo rasā
analyzed: prabandheṣu mahākāvya ādiṣu nāṭaka ādiṣu vā viprakīrṇa tayā aṅga aṅgi bhāvena bahavaḥ rasāḥ
translated: In extended works such as great poems and dramas, many rasas are interwoven in a scattered manner as primary and secondary.

original: upanibadhyanta ity atra prasiddhau satyām api yaḥ prabandhānāṃ chāyātiśayayogam
analyzed: upanibadhyante iti atra prasiddhau satyām api yaḥ prabandhānām chāyā atiśaya yogam
translated: Even when this is well-known, one who desires that extended works have an excess of charm

original: icchati tena teṣāṃ rasānām anyatamaḥ kaścid vivakṣito raso 'ṅgitvena viniveśayitavya
analyzed: icchati tena teṣām rasānām anyatamaḥ kaścid vivakṣitaḥ rasaḥ ṅgi tvena viniveśayitavya
translated: should assign one of those rasas as the intended rasa as a secondary element.

original: ity ayaṃ yuktataro mārgaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti ayam yuktataraḥ mārgaḥ
translated: This is the more reasonable path.

original: nanu rasāntareṣu bahuṣu prāptaparipoṣeṣu satsu katham ekasyāṅgitā na virudhyata ity āśaṅkyedam ucyate
analyzed: nanu rasa antareṣu bahuṣu prāpta paripoṣeṣu satsu katham ekasya aṅgi tā na virudhyate iti āśaṅkya idam ucyate
translated: But when many other rasas have attained full development, how can one not contradict its being a secondary element? Fearing this doubt, it is said:

original: rasāntarasamāveśaḥ prastutasya rasasya yaḥ /
analyzed: rasa antara samāveśaḥ prastutasya rasasya yaḥ
translated: The inclusion of other rasas in the presented rasa

original: nopahanty aṅgitāṃ so 'sya sthāyitvenāvabhāsinaḥ // / //
analyzed: na upahanti aṅgi tām saḥ sya sthāyi tvena avabhāsinaḥ
translated: does not destroy its secondary nature, as it appears as the permanent mood.

original: prabandheṣu prathamataraṃ prastutaḥ san punaḥ punar anusandhīyamānatvena sthāyī yo
analyzed: prabandheṣu prathamataram prastutaḥ san punar punar anusandhīyamāna tvena sthāyī yaḥ
translated: In extended works, the rasa that is presented first and is repeatedly recalled as the permanent mood,

original: rasas tasya sakalabandhavyāpino rasāntarair antarālavartibhiḥ samāveśo yaḥ sa
analyzed: rasaḥ tasya sakala bandha vyāpinaḥ rasa antaraiḥ antarāla vartibhiḥ samāveśaḥ yaḥ sa
translated: which pervades the entire composition, the inclusion of other rasas in between

original: nāṅgitām upahanti // / //
analyzed: na aṅgitām upahanti
translated: does not destroy its secondary nature.

original: etad evopapādayitum ucyate
analyzed: etat eva upapādayitum ucyate
translated: This is explained:

original: kāryam ekaṃ yathā vyāpi prabandhasya vidhīyate /
analyzed: kāryam ekam yathā vyāpi prabandhasya vidhīyate
translated: Just as one effect is conceived to pervade the whole series,

original: tathā rasasyāpi vidhau virodho naiva vidyate // / //
analyzed: tathā rasasya api vidhau virodhaḥ nā eva vidyate
translated: in the same way, there is no contradiction in the case of rasa also.

original: sandhyādimayasya prabandhaśarīrasya yathā kāryam ekam anuyāyi vyāpakaṃ kalpyate na ca tatkāryāntarair na saṅkīryate /
analyzed: sandhyā ādi mayasya prabandha śarīrasya yathā kāryam ekam anuyāyi vyāpakam kalpyate na ca tat kārya antaraiḥ na saṅkīryate
translated: Just as for the body of a literary work consisting of the five parts such as the introduction etc., one all-pervading effect is conceived to follow, and that is not mixed up with other effects,

original: na ca taiḥ saṅkīryamāṇasyāpi tasya prādhānyam apacīyate /
analyzed: na ca taiḥ saṅkīryamāṇasya api tasya prādhānyam apacīyate
translated: and even when mixed up with them, its predominance is not diminished,

original: tathaiva rasasyāpy ekasya sanniveśe kriyamāṇe virodho na kaścit /
analyzed: tathā eva rasasya api ekasya sanniveśe kriyamāṇe virodhaḥ na kaścid
translated: in the same way, when the arrangement of rasa is being made, there is no contradiction at all.

original: pratyuta pratyuditavivekānām anusandhānavatāṃ sacetasāṃ tathāvidhe viṣaye prahlādātiśayaḥ pravartate // / //
analyzed: pratyuta pratyudita vivekānām anusandhānavatām sa cetasām tathāvidhe viṣaye prahlāda atiśayaḥ pravartate
translated: On the contrary, in such a subject, there arises an excess of delight in the minds of those who are endowed with discrimination and recollection.

original: nanu yeṣāṃ rasānāṃ parasparāvirodhaḥ yathāvīraśṛṅgārayoḥ śṛṅgārahāsyayo raudraśṛṅgārayor
analyzed: nanu yeṣām rasānām paraspara avirodhaḥ yathā vīra śṛṅgārayoḥ śṛṅgāra hāsyayoḥ raudra śṛṅgārayoḥ
translated: Now, those rasas which are not mutually contradictory, such as the heroic and the erotic, the erotic and the comic, the heroic and the erotic,

original: vīrādbhutayor vīraraudrayo raudrakaruṇayoḥ śṛṅgārādbhutayor vā tatra bhavatv aṅgāṅgibhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vīra adbhutayoḥ vīra raudrayoḥ raudra karuṇayoḥ śṛṅgāra adbhutayoḥ vā tatra bhavatu aṅga aṅgi bhāvaḥ
translated: the heroic and the marvellous, the heroic and the terrible, the terrible and the pathetic, the erotic and the marvellous, let there be the relation of primary and secondary between them.

original: teṣāṃ tu sa kathaṃ bhaved yeṣāṃ parasparaṃ bādhyabādhakabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām tu sa katham bhavet yeṣām parasparam bādhya bādhaka bhāvaḥ
translated: But how can that be in the case of those which are mutually contradictory?

original: yathāśṛṅgārabībhatsayor vīrabhayānakayoḥ śāntaraudrayoḥ śantaśṛṅgārayor vā ity āśaṅkyedam ucyate
analyzed: yathā śṛṅgāra bībhatsayoḥ vīra bhayānakayoḥ śānta raudrayoḥ vā iti āśaṅkya idam ucyate
translated: As in the case of erotic and disgusting, heroic and fearful, peaceful and wrathful, or peaceful and erotic, to anticipate this, this is said:

original: avirodhī virodhī vā raso 'ṅgini rasāntare /
analyzed: avirodhī virodhī vā rasaḥ ṅgini rasa antare
translated: A rasa, whether non-contradictory or contradictory, should not be developed to excess in another rasa that is the principal element.

original: paripoṣaṃ na netavyas tathā syād avirodhitā // / //
analyzed: paripoṣam na netavyaḥ tathā syāt avirodhi tā
translated: Thus there would be non-contradiction.

original: aṅgini rasāntare śṛṅgārādau prabandhavyaṅgye sati avirodhī virodhī vā rasaḥ paripoṣaṃ na netavyaḥ /
analyzed: aṅgini rasa antare śṛṅgāra ādau prabandha vyaṅgye sati avirodhī virodhī vā rasaḥ paripoṣam na netavyaḥ
translated: When another rasa, such as erotic, etc., which is suggested by the context, is present as the principal element, a rasa, whether non-contradictory or contradictory, should not be developed to excess.

original: tatrāvirodhino rasasyāṅgirasāpekṣayāty antam ādhikyaṃ na kartavyam ity ayaṃ prathamaḥ paripoṣaparihāraḥ /
analyzed: tatra avirodhinaḥ rasasya aṅgirasa apekṣayā ati antam ādhikyam na kartavyam iti ayam prathamaḥ paripoṣa parihāraḥ
translated: In that case, a non-contradictory rasa should not be made much more intense than the principal rasa. This is the first avoidance of over-development.

original: utkarṣasāmye 'pi tayor virodhāsambhavāt / yathā🔽ekato roditi priyā anyataḥ samaratūryanirghoṣaḥ /
analyzed: utkarṣa sāmye pi tayoḥ virodha asambhavāt yathā  ekatas roditi priyā anyatas samara tūrya nirghoṣaḥ
translated: Because even if there is equality of excellence between the two, there cannot be contradiction. As in:🔽On one side my beloved cries, on the other the sound of battle drums.

original: snehena raṇarasena ca bhaṭasya dolāyitaṃ hṛdayam /
analyzed: snehena raṇa rasena ca bhaṭasya dolāyitam hṛdayam
translated: The heart of the warrior sways between affection and the passion for battle.

original: yathā vā🔽kaṇṭhāc chitvākṣamālāvalayam iva kare hāram āvartayantī
analyzed: yathā vā  kaṇṭhāt śitvā akṣamālā valayam iva kare hāram āvartayantī
translated: Or as in:🔽Twirling the necklace on her wrist as if cutting the rosary from her neck,

original: kṛtvā paryaṅkabandhaṃ viṣadharapatinā mekhalāyā guṇena /
analyzed: kṛtvā paryaṅka bandham viṣadhara patinā mekhalāyāḥ guṇena
translated: Binding her legs in a cross-legged position with the girdle of the lord of serpents,

original: mithyāmantrābhijāpasphuradadharapuṭavyañjitāvyaktahāsā
analyzed: mithyā mantra abhijāpa sphurat adhara puṭa vyañjita avyakta hāsā
translated: With indistinct laughter expressed by the lips quivering from the recitation of false mantras,

original: devī sandhyābhyasūyā hasitapaśupatis tatra dṛṣṭā tu vo 'vyāt //ity atra /🔽aṅgirasaviruddhānāṃ vyabhicāriṇāṃ prācuryeṇāniveśanam /
analyzed: devī sandhyā abhyasūyā hasita paśupatiḥ tatra dṛṣṭā tu vaḥ iti atra  aṅgirasa viruddhānām vyabhicāriṇām prācuryeṇa a niveśanam
translated: The Goddess Evening, with a smile indistinctly manifest from her lips quivering with the muttered recitation of false mantras, and with a laugh that scorns Shiva, may she protect you there.🔽The second is: the non-inclusion, for the most part, of the contradictory and variable [figures] that are opposed to the Aṅgiras [figures].

original: niveśane vā kṣipram evāṅgirasavyabhicāryanuvṛttir iti dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: niveśane vā kṣipram eva āṅgirasa vyabhicāri anuvṛttiḥ iti dvitīyaḥ
translated: Or, if they are included, the quick repetition of the Aṅgiras and variable [figures].

original: aṅgatvena punaḥ punaḥ pratyavekṣā paripoṣaṃ nīyamānasyāpy aṅgabhūtasya rasasyeti tṛtīyaḥ /
analyzed: aṅga tvena punar punar pratyavekṣā paripoṣam nīyamānasya api aṅga bhūtasya rasasya iti tṛtīyaḥ
translated: The third is: the repeated consideration of a rasa that is being brought to fullness, even though it is a subordinate rasa.

original: anayā diśānye 'pi prakārā utprekṣaṇīyāḥ /
analyzed: anayā diśā anye pi prakārāḥ utprekṣaṇīyāḥ
translated: By this direction, other types should also be imagined.

original: virodhinas tu rasasyāṅgirasāpekṣayā kasyacin nyūnatā sampādanīyā /
analyzed: virodhinaḥ tu rasasya aṅgirasa apekṣayā kasyacid nyūna tā sampādanīyā
translated: But for one who is opposed to rasa, in relation to the Aṅgiras [figures], some deficiency should be accomplished.

original: yathā śānte 'ṅgini śṛṅgārasya śṛṅgāre vā śāntasya /
analyzed: yathā śānte ṅgini śṛṅgārasya śṛṅgāre vā śāntasya
translated: For example, of love in the case of peace as the predominant rasa, or of peace in the case of love.

original: paripoṣarahitasya rasasya kathaṃ rasatvam iti cetuktam atrāṅgirasāpekṣayeti /
analyzed: paripoṣa rahitasya rasasya katham rasa tvam iti ced uktam atra āṅgirasa apekṣayā iti
translated: If it is asked how a rasa that is devoid of fullness can be a rasa, it is said here that it is in relation to the Aṅgiras [figures].

original: aṅgino hi rasasya yāvān paripoṣas tāvāṃs tasya na kartavyaḥ /
analyzed: aṅginaḥ hi rasasya yāvān paripoṣaḥ tāvān tasya na kartavyaḥ
translated: For the predominant rasa should not have as much fullness as that [subordinate rasa].

original: svatas tu sambhavī paripoṣaḥ kena vāryate /
analyzed: svatas tu sambhavī paripoṣaḥ kena vāryate
translated: But who can prevent the fullness that naturally occurs?

original: etac cāpekṣikaṃ prakarṣayogitvam ekasya rasasya bahuraseṣu prabandheṣu rasānām🔽aṅgāṅgibhāvam anabhyupagacchatāpy aśakyapratikṣepam ity anena prakāreṇāvirodhināṃ
analyzed: etat ca āpekṣikam prakarṣa yogi tvam ekasya rasasya bahu raseṣu prabandheṣu rasānām  aṅga aṅgi bhāvam an abhyupagacchatā api aśakya pratikṣepam iti anena prakāreṇa avirodhinām
translated: And this superiority is relative. In works with many rasas, one rasa may be superior to the others.🔽Even by one who does not accept the relation of primary and secondary between rasas, this cannot be rejected. In this way, without contradiction,

original: virodhināṃ ca rasānām aṅgāṅgibhāvena samāveśe prabandheṣu syād avirodhaḥ /
analyzed: virodhinām ca rasānām aṅga aṅgi bhāvena samāveśe prabandheṣu syāt avirodhaḥ
translated: the inclusion of contradictory and non-contradictory rasas as primary and secondary in works is not contradictory.

original: etac ca sarvaṃ yeṣāṃ raso rasāntarasya vyabhicārī bhavati iti darśanaṃ tanmatenocyate /
analyzed: etat ca sarvam yeṣām rasaḥ rasa antarasya vyabhicārī bhavati iti darśanam tad matena ucyate
translated: And all this is stated from the point of view of those who hold the view that rasa is a variant of another rasa.

original: matāntare 'pi rasānāṃ sthāyino bhāvā upacārād rasaśabdenoktās teṣām aṅgatvaṃ nirvirodham eva // / //
analyzed: mata antare pi rasānām sthāyinaḥ bhāvāḥ upacārāt rasa śabdena uktāḥ teṣām aṅga tvam nirvirodham eva
translated: Even in another view, the permanent emotions of the rasas are spoken of by the word rasa figuratively, and their subordination is itself free from contradiction.

original: evam avirodhināṃ virodhināṃ ca prabandhasthenāṅginā rasena samāveśe sādhāraṇam avirodhopāyaṃ pratipādyedānīṃ virodhiviṣayam eva taṃ pratipādayitum
analyzed: evam avirodhinām virodhinām ca prabandha sthena aṅginā rasena samāveśe sādhāraṇam avirodha upāyam pratipādya idānīm virodhi viṣayam eva tam pratipādayitum
translated: Thus, having explained the general means of non-contradiction in the inclusion of contradictory and non-contradictory rasas in a work by the primary rasa, now, in order to explain just that means with regard to contradictory [rasas],

original: idam ucyate🔽viruddhaikāśrayo yas tu virodhī sthāyino bhavet /
analyzed: idam ucyate  viruddha eka āśrayaḥ yaḥ tu virodhī sthāyinaḥ bhavet
translated: this is said:🔽But when there is a contradiction with a single contradictory [rasa] of the permanent [rasa],

original: sa vibhinnāśrayaḥ kāryas tasya poṣe 'py adoṣatā // / //
analyzed: sa vibhinna āśrayaḥ kāryaḥ tasya poṣe pi adoṣa tā
translated: that should be made with a different substratum. There is no fault even in nourishing it.

original: ekādhikaraṇy avirodhī nairantaryavirodhī ceti dvividho virodhī /
analyzed: eka adhikaraṇī avirodhī nairantarya virodhī ca iti dvividhaḥ virodhī
translated: The contradiction is of two kinds: contradiction in the same context and contradiction in immediate sequence.

original: tatra prabandhasthena sthāyināṅginā rasenaucityāpekṣayā viruddhaikāśrayo yo virodhī yathā vīreṇa bhayānakaḥ sa vibhinnāśrayaḥ kāryaḥ /
analyzed: tatra prabandha sthena sthāyinā aṅginā rasena aucitya apekṣayā viruddha eka āśrayaḥ yaḥ virodhī yathā vīreṇa bhayānakaḥ sa vibhinna āśrayaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: Of these, the contradiction that is in the same context is to be made with the help of a hero who is the abode of a permanent mood that is in a literary composition and that is opposed to the mood that is proper to the context. For example, the terrible mood is to be made with the help of a hero.

original: tasya vīrasya ya āśrayaḥ kathānāyakas tadvipakṣaviṣaye sanniveśayitavyaḥ /
analyzed: tasya vīrasya yaḥ āśrayaḥ kathā nāyakaḥ tad vipakṣa viṣaye san niveśayitavyaḥ
translated: The hero who is the abode of that [terrible mood] is to be placed in a context that is opposed to the context of the hero who is the abode of the mood that is proper to the context.

original: tathā sati ca tasya virodhino 'pi yaḥ paripoṣaḥ sa nirdoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā sati ca tasya yaḥ paripoṣaḥ sa nirdoṣaḥ
translated: When that is so, then the development of that [terrible mood] which is opposed [to the proper mood] is faultless.

original: vipakṣaviṣaye hi bhayātiśayavarṇane nāyakasya nayaparākramādisampat sutarām uddyotitā bhavati /
analyzed: vipakṣa viṣaye hi bhaya atiśaya varṇane nāyakasya naya parākrama ādi sampad sutarām uddyotitā bhavati
translated: For, when the excess of fear is described in a context that is opposed [to the proper context], the excellence of the hero's policy, valor, etc. is very much illuminated.

original: etac ca madīye 'rjunacarite 'rjunasya pātālāvataraṇaprasaṅge vaiśadyena pradarśitam /
analyzed: etat ca madīye rjuna carite rjunasya pātāla avataraṇa prasaṅge vaiśadyena pradarśitam
translated: And this is clearly shown by me in the Arjuna Caritam, in the context of Arjuna's descent into the nether world.

original: evam aikādhikaraṇyavirodhinaḥ prabandhasthena sthāyinā rasenāṅgabhāvagamane nirvirodhatvaṃ yathā tathā tad darśitam /
analyzed: evam aika adhikaraṇya virodhinaḥ prabandha sthena sthāyinā rasena aṅga bhāva gamane nirvirodha tvam yathā tathā tat darśitam
translated: And thus, when the contradiction in the same context is made to become subordinate to the permanent mood that is in a literary composition, the absence of contradiction is shown in that way.

original: dvitīyasya tu tat pratipādayitum ucyate
analyzed: dvitīyasya tu tat pratipādayitum ucyate
translated: But the second [kind of contradiction] is to be explained in order to illustrate it.

original: ekāśrayatve nirdoṣo nairantarye virodhavān /
analyzed: eka āśraya tve nirdoṣaḥ nairantarye virodhavān
translated: When there is no contradiction in their being based on the same substratum, but there is contradiction in their being uninterrupted,

original: rasāntaravyavadhinā raso vyaṅgyaḥ sumedhasā // / //
translated: the wise should introduce rasa by the intervention of another rasa.

original: yaḥ punar ekādhikaraṇatve nirvirodho nairantarye tu virodhī sa rasāntaravyavadhānena prabandhe niveśayitavyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ punar eka adhikaraṇa tve nirvirodhaḥ nairantarye tu virodhī sa rasa antara vyavadhānena prabandhe niveśayitavyaḥ
translated: But when there is no contradiction in their being based on the same substratum, but there is contradiction in their being uninterrupted, that [rasa] should be introduced in a literary composition by the intervention of another rasa.

original: yathā śāntaśṛṅgārau nāgānande niveśitau /
analyzed: yathā śānta śṛṅgārau nāgānande niveśitau
translated: For example, the peaceful and erotic sentiments were introduced in the Nāgānanda.

original: śāntaś ca tṛṣṇākṣayasukhasya yaḥ paripoṣas tallakṣaṇo rasaḥ pratīyata eva /
analyzed: śāntaḥ ca tṛṣṇā kṣaya sukhasya yaḥ paripoṣaḥ tad lakṣaṇaḥ rasaḥ pratīyate eva
translated: And the peaceful sentiment, which is the nourishment of the bliss of the destruction of craving, is indeed experienced as a rasa.

original: tathā coktam
analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And it is said:

original: yac ca kāmasukhaṃ loke yac ca divyaṃ mahat sukham /
analyzed: yat ca kāma sukham loke yat ca divyam mahat sukham
translated: The bliss of love in the world and the great divine bliss,

original: tṛṣṇākṣayasukhasyaite nārhataḥ ṣoḍaśīṃ kalām //
analyzed: tṛṣṇā kṣaya sukhasya ete na arhataḥ ṣoḍaśīm kalām
translated: are not worth a sixteenth part of the bliss of the destruction of craving.

original: yadi nāma sarvajanānubhavagocaratā tasya nāsti naitāvatāsāv alokasāmānyamahānubhāvacittavṛttiviśeṣaḥ pratikṣeptuṃ śakyaḥ /
analyzed: yadi nāma sarva jana anubhava gocara tā tasya nā asti na etāvatā asau aloka sāmānya mahā anubhāva cittavṛtti viśeṣaḥ pratikṣeptum śakyaḥ
translated: Even if it is not the object of experience of all people, it cannot be denied that it is a great and extraordinary mental state common to all people.

original: na ca vīre tasyāntarbhāvaḥ kartuṃ yuktaḥ /🔽tasyābhimānamayatvena vyavasthāpanāt /
analyzed: na ca vīre tasya antarbhāvaḥ kartum yuktaḥ  tasya abhimāna maya tvena vyavasthāpanāt
translated: And it is not proper to include it within the heroic [sentiment].🔽Because that [heroic sentiment] is established as being of the nature of pride,

original: asya cāhaṅkārapraśamaikarūpatayā sthiteḥ /
analyzed: asya ca ahaṅkāra praśama eka rūpa tayā sthiteḥ
translated: and this [peaceful sentiment] exists as having the form of the complete cessation of egoism.

original: tayoś caivaṃvidhaviśeṣasadbhāve 'pi yady aikyaṃ parikalpyate tad vīraraudrayor api tathā prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tayoḥ ca evaṃvidha viśeṣa sadbhāve pi yadi aikyam parikalpyate tat vīra raudrayoḥ api tathā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And even if such a difference as this is admitted, if identity is imagined, then the same would follow for the heroic and the terrible.

original: dayāvīrādīnāṃ ca cittavṛttiviśeṣāṇāṃ sarvākāram ahaṅkārarahitatvena śāntarasaprabhedatvam /
analyzed: dayā vīra ādīnām ca citta vṛtti viśeṣāṇām sarvākāram ahaṅkāra rahita tvena śānta rasa prabheda tvam
translated: And the heroic sentiment of compassion and so on, being entirely devoid of the sense of egoism, are varieties of the tranquil sentiment.

original: itarathā tu vīraprabhedatvam iti vyavasthāpyamāne na kaścid virodhaḥ /
analyzed: itarathā tu vīra prabheda tvam iti vyavasthāpyamāne na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: But if it is established that they are varieties of the heroic sentiment, there is no contradiction at all.

original: tad evam asti śānto rasaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam asti śāntaḥ rasaḥ
translated: So the tranquil sentiment exists in this way.

original: tasya cāviruddharasavyavadhānena prabandhe virodhirasasamāveśe saty api nirvirodhatvam /
analyzed: tasya ca aviruddha rasa vyavadhānena prabandhe virodhi rasa samāveśe sati api nirvirodha tvam
translated: And it is not contradicted even when a contradictory sentiment is introduced in a connected whole, interrupted by a sentiment that is not contradictory.

original: yathā pradarśite viṣaye // / //
analyzed: yathā pradarśite viṣaye
translated: As in the case of the subject matter illustrated...

original: etad eva sthirīkartum idam ucyate
analyzed: etat eva sthirīkartum idam ucyate
translated: In order to make this very point clear, this is said:

original: rasāntarāntaritayor ekavākyasthayor api /
analyzed: rasa antara antaritayoḥ eka vākya sthayoḥ api
translated: Even when two sentiments are interrupted by another sentiment and occur in the same sentence,

original: nivartate hi rasayoḥ samāveśe virodhitā // / //
analyzed: nivartate hi rasayoḥ samāveśe virodhi tā
translated: the contradiction between the sentiments ceases, when they are combined.

original: rasāntaravyavahitayor ekaprabandhasthayor virodhitā nivartata ity atra na kācid bhrāntiḥ /
translated: There is no confusion at all in this matter, that the contradiction between two sentiments occurring in the same connected whole, interrupted by another sentiment, ceases.

original: yasmād ekavākyasthayor api rasayor uktayā nītyā viruddhatā nivartate / yathā
analyzed: yasmāt eka vākya sthayoḥ api rasayoḥ uktayā nītyā viruddha tā nivartate yathā
translated: Because the contradiction between two sentiments occurring in the same sentence also ceases, according to the method stated. For example:

original: bhūreṇudigdhān navapārijāta
analyzed: bhū reṇu digdhān nava pārijāta
translated: Covered with dust from the earth, like newly blossomed pārijāta trees,

original: mālārajovāsitabāhumadhyāḥ /🔽gāḍhaṃ śivābhiḥ parirabhyamāṇān🔽surāṅganāśliṣṭabhujān tarālāḥ //
analyzed: mālā rajaḥ vāsita bāhu madhyāḥ  gāḍham śivābhiḥ parirabhyamāṇān  sura aṅganā āśliṣṭa bhujān tarālāḥ
translated: Their bodies smeared with the dust of the earth, their arms fragrant with the pollen of fresh pārijāta garlands,🔽closely embraced by the Śiva goddesses, their arms entwined by the excited celestial women,

original: saśoṇitaiḥ kravyabhujāṃ sphuradbhiḥ🔽pakṣaiḥ khagānām u pavījyamānān /🔽saṃvījitāś candanavārisekaiḥ🔽sugandhibhiḥ kalpalatādukūlaiḥ //
analyzed: sa śoṇitaiḥ kravyabhujām sphuradbhiḥ  pakṣaiḥ khagānām u pavījyamānān  saṃvījitāḥ candana vāri sekaiḥ  sugandhibhiḥ kalpalatā dukūlaiḥ
translated: being fanned with the fluttering wings of blood-drinking birds,🔽and fanned with fragrant sandal water and the garments of the wish-fulfilling trees,

original: vimānaparyaṅkatale niṣaṇṇāḥ🔽kutūhalāviṣṭatayā tadānīm /🔽nirdiśyamānāṃ lalanāṅgulībhir
analyzed: vimāna paryaṅka tale niṣaṇṇāḥ  kutūhala āviṣṭa tayā tadānīm  nirdiśyamānām lalanā aṅgulībhiḥ
translated: seated on the cushions of their celestial vehicles, at that time, overwhelmed by curiosity,

original: vīrāḥ svadehān patitān apaśyan //ity ādau /
analyzed: vīrāḥ sva dehān patitān apaśyan iti ādau
translated: the heroes saw their fallen bodies being pointed out by the fingers of the women.

original: atra hi śṛṅgārabībhatsayos tadaṅgayor vā vīrarasavyavadhānena samāveśo na virodhī /
analyzed: atra hi śṛṅgāra bībhatsayoḥ tad aṅgayoḥ vā vīra rasa vyavadhānena samāveśaḥ na virodhī
translated: Here, the combination of erotic and disgusting sentiments or their subsidiary elements, interrupted by the heroic sentiment, is not contradictory.

original: virodham avirodhaṃ ca sarvatretthaṃ nirūpayet /
analyzed: virodham avirodham ca sarvatra ittham nirūpayet
translated: One should thus determine everywhere whether there is contradiction or non-contradiction.

original: viśeṣatas tu śṛṅgāre sukumāratamā hy asau // / //
analyzed: viśeṣataḥ tu śṛṅgāre sukumāratamā hi asau
translated: But especially in erotic sentiment, it is the most delicate.

original: yathoktalakṣaṇānusāreṇa virodhāvirodhau sarveṣu raseṣu prabandhe 'nyatra ca nirūpayet sahṛdayaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ukta lakṣaṇa anusāreṇa virodha avirodhau sarveṣu raseṣu prabandhe ca nirūpayet sahṛdayaḥ
translated: The connoisseur should determine the contradiction and non-contradiction in all the sentiments according to the definition given, in a literary composition and elsewhere.

original: viśeṣatas tu śṛṅgāre /
analyzed: viśeṣataḥ tu śṛṅgāre
translated: But especially in erotic sentiment.

original: sa hi ratiparipoṣātmakatvād rateś ca svalpenāpi nimittena bhaṅgasambhavāt sukumāratamaḥ sarvebhyo rasebhyo manāg api virodhisamāveśaṃ na
analyzed: sa hi rati paripoṣa ātmaka tvāt rateḥ ca su alpena api nimittena bhaṅga sambhavāt sukumāratamaḥ sarvebhyaḥ rasebhyaḥ manāk api virodhi samāveśam na
translated: For it is the most delicate of all tastes, because it consists in the nourishment of pleasure, and pleasure can be destroyed even by a slight cause.

original: sahate /
analyzed: sahate
translated: For that [passion] is the most delicate of all the passions, because it consists in the nourishment of love, and because love is liable to be destroyed even by a slight cause. It cannot bear even the slightest admixture of a contradictory passion.

original: avadhānātiśayavān rase tatraiva satkaviḥ /
analyzed: avadhāna atiśayavān rase tatra eva sat kaviḥ
translated: The good poet should be very attentive to that passion.

original: bhavet tasmin pramādo hi jhaṭity evopalakṣyate // / //
analyzed: bhavet tasmin pramādaḥ hi jhaṭiti evā upalakṣyate
translated: For negligence in that [passion] is quickly noticed.

original: tatraiva ca rase sarvebhyo 'pi rasebhyaḥ saukumāryātiśayayogini kavir avadhānavān prayatnavān syāt /
analyzed: tatra eva ca rase sarvebhyaḥ rasebhyaḥ saukumārya atiśaya yogini kaviḥ avadhānavān prayatnavān syāt
translated: And in that [passion], which is endowed with a greater degree of delicacy than all other passions, the poet should be attentive, should be diligent.

original: tatra hi pramādyatas tasya sahṛdayamadhye kṣipram evāvajñānaviṣayatā bhavati /
analyzed: tatra hi pramādyataḥ tasya sahṛdaya madhye kṣipram evā avajñāna viṣaya tā bhavati
translated: For one who is negligent in that [passion] quickly becomes an object of contempt among the connoisseurs.

original: śṛṅgāraraso hi saṃsāriṇāṃ niyamenānubhavaviṣayatvāt sarvarasebhyaḥ kamanīyatayā pradhānabhūtaḥ /
analyzed: śṛṅgāra rasaḥ hi saṃsāriṇām niyamena anubhava viṣaya tvāt sarva rasebhyaḥ kamanīya tayā pradhāna bhūtaḥ
translated: For the erotic passion, being invariably the object of experience for transmigrating beings, is the principal [passion] by its loveliness among all passions.

original: evaṃ ca sati
analyzed: evam ca sati
translated: And this being so,

original: vineyān unmukhīkartuṃ kāvyaśobhārtham eva vā /
analyzed: vineyān unmukhīkartum kāvya śobhā artham eva vā
translated: in order to attract the disciples or for the sake of the beauty of poetry,

original: tadviruddharasasparśas tadaṅgānāṃ na duṣyati // / //
analyzed: tad viruddha rasa sparśaḥ tad aṅgānām na duṣyati
translated: the contact with a passion opposed to that [erotic passion] in its subordinate elements does not vitiate.

original: śṛṅgāraviruddharasasparśaḥ śṛṅgārāṅgānāṃ yaḥ sa na kevalam avirodhalakṣaṇayoge sati na duṣyati yāvad vineyān unmukhīkartuṃ kāvyaśobhārtham 🔽eva vā kriyamāṇo na duṣyati /
analyzed: śṛṅgāra viruddha rasa sparśaḥ śṛṅgāra aṅgānām yaḥ sa na kevalam avirodha lakṣaṇa yoge sati na duṣyati yāvat vineyān unmukhīkartum kāvya śobhā artham  eva vā kriyamāṇaḥ na duṣyati
translated: it is not faulty even when it is employed to attract the attention of the audience and to enhance the beauty of the poem.

original: śṛṅgārarasāṅgair unmukhīkṛtāḥ santo hi vineyāḥ sukhaṃ vinayopadeśān gṛhṇanti /
analyzed: śṛṅgāra rasa aṅgaiḥ unmukhīkṛtāḥ santaḥ hi vineyāḥ sukham vinaya upadeśān gṛhṇanti
translated: For, when the audience is attracted by the constituent factors of erotic love, they readily accept the instruction in good conduct.

original: sadācāropadeśarūpā hi nāṭakādigoṣṭhī vineyajanahitārtham eva munibhir avatāritā /
analyzed: sat ācāra upadeśa rūpā hi nāṭaka ādi goṣṭhī vineya jana hita artham eva munibhiḥ avatāritā
translated: For, the assembly of dramatic performances such as the Nāṭaka, which is in the form of instruction in good conduct, is introduced by the sages solely for the benefit of the audience.

original: kiṃ ca śṛṅgārasya sakalajanamanoharābhirāmatvāt tadaṅgasamāveśaḥ kāvye śobhātiśayaṃ puṣyatīty anenāpi prakāreṇa virodhini rase śṛṅgārāṅgasamāveśo
analyzed: kim ca śṛṅgārasya sakala jana manohara abhirāma tvāt tad aṅga samāveśaḥ kāvye śobhā atiśayam puṣyati iti anena api prakāreṇa virodhini rase śṛṅgāra aṅga samāveśaḥ
translated: Moreover, since erotic love is delightful and charming to the minds of all people, the inclusion of its constituent factors in a poem enhances its beauty to a very high degree. In this way also, the inclusion of the constituent factors of erotic love in a rasa that is opposed to it

original: na virodhī /
analyzed: na virodhī
translated: is not opposed.

original: tataś ca
analyzed: tatas ca
translated: And therefore,

original: satyaṃ manoramā rāmāḥ satyaṃ ramyā vibhūtayaḥ /
analyzed: satyam manoramāḥ rāmāḥ satyam ramyāḥ vibhūtayaḥ
translated: Truly, women are delightful, truly, riches are charming,

original: kiṃ tu mattāṅganāpāṅgabhaṅgalolaṃ hi jīvitam //🔽ity ādiṣu nāsti rasavirodhadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: kim tu matta aṅganā apāṅga bhaṅga lolam hi jīvitam  iti ādiṣu na asti rasa virodha doṣaḥ
translated: but life is fickle, swaying with the sidelong glances of intoxicated women.🔽 In such passages, there is no fault of opposition of rasa.

original: vijñāyetthaṃ rasādīnām avirodhavirodhayoḥ /
analyzed: vijñāya ittham rasa ādīnām avirodha virodhayoḥ
translated: Having understood thus the non-opposition and opposition of rasa and so on,

original: viṣayaṃ sukaviḥ kāvyaṃ kurvan muhyati na kvacit // / //🔽ittham anenānantaroktena prakāreṇa rasādīnāṃ rasabhāvatadābhāsānāṃ parasparaṃ
analyzed: viṣayam su kaviḥ kāvyam kurvan muhyati na kvacid  ittham anena anantara uktena prakāreṇa rasa ādīnām rasa bhāva tad ābhāsānām parasparam
translated: a good poet, when composing poetry, is never confused about the subject matter.

original: virodhasyāvirodhasya ca viṣayaṃ vijñāya sukaviḥ kāvyaviṣaye pratibhātiśayayuktaḥ
analyzed: virodhasya avirodhasya ca viṣayam vijñāya su kaviḥ kāvya viṣaye pratibhā atiśaya yuktaḥ
translated: Thus, having understood the subject matter of the mutual contradiction and non-contradiction of rasa, bhāva, and their imitations, as described above, a good poet, endowed with an excess of poetic genius in the realm of poetry,

original: kāvyaṃ kurvan na kvacin muhyati /
analyzed: kāvyam kurvan na kvacid muhyati
translated: when composing poetry, is never confused about anything.

original: evaṃ rasādiṣu virodhāvirodhanirūpaṇasyopayogitvaṃ pratipādya vyañjakavācyavācakanirūpaṇasyāpi tadviṣayasya tat pratipādyate
analyzed: evam rasa ādiṣu virodha avirodha nirūpaṇasya upayogi tvam pratipādya vyañjaka vācya vācaka nirūpaṇasya api tad viṣayasya tat pratipādyate
translated: Having thus shown the usefulness of determining the contradiction and non-contradiction of rasa etc., it is now shown that the determination of the suggestive, denoted, and denotative, which is related to that [subject matter], is also useful for that [purpose].

original: vācyānāṃ vācakānāṃ ca yad aucityena yojanam /
analyzed: vācyānām vācakānām ca yat aucityena yojanam
translated: The proper arrangement of the denoted and the denotative

original: rasādiviṣayeṇaitat karma mukhyaṃ mahākaveḥ // / //
analyzed: rasa ādi viṣayeṇa etat karma mukhyam mahā kaveḥ
translated: is the primary function of a great poet in the realm of rasa etc.

original: vācyānām itivṛttaviśeṣāṇāṃ vācakānāṃ ca tadviṣayāṇāṃ rasādiviṣayeṇaucityena yad yojanam etan mahākaver mukhyaṃ karma /
analyzed: vācyānām iti vṛtta viśeṣāṇām vācakānām ca tad viṣayāṇām rasa ādi viṣayeṇa aucityena yat yojanam etat mahā kaveḥ mukhyam karma
translated: The proper arrangement of the denoted, the particular incidents, and the denotative, which are related to that [realm of rasa etc.], is the primary function of a great poet.

original: ayam eva hi mahākaver mukhyo vyāpāro yad rasādīnām eva mukhyatayā kāvyārthīkṛtya tadvyaktyanuguṇatvena śabdānām arthānāṃ copanibandhanam
analyzed: ayam eva hi mahā kaveḥ mukhyaḥ vyāpāraḥ yat rasa ādīnām eva mukhya tayā kāvya arthīkṛtya tad vyakti anuguṇa tvena śabdānām arthānām ca upanibandhanam
translated: For this is the chief function of the great poet, that he makes the meaning of poetry consist chiefly in rasa, etc., and employs words and meanings in accordance with their suitability to the manifestation of those [rasa, etc.].

original: etac ca rasāditātparyeṇa kāvyanibandhanaṃ bharatādāvapi suprasiddham eveti pratipādayitum āha
analyzed: etat ca rasa ādi tātparyeṇa kāvya nibandhanam bharata ādau api su prasiddham evā iti pratipādayitum āha
translated: And in order to show that this composition of poetry with rasa, etc., as its aim is well known even to Bharata and others, he says:

original: rasādyanuguṇatvena vyavahāro 'rthaśabdayoḥ /
analyzed: rasa ādi anuguṇa tvena vyavahāraḥ rtha śabdayoḥ
translated: The usage of words and meanings in accordance with their suitability to rasa, etc.,

original: aucityavānyastā etā vṛttayo dvividhāḥ sthitāḥ // / //
analyzed: aucityavān yaḥ tāḥ etāḥ vṛttayaḥ dvividhāḥ sthitāḥ
translated: These meters, divided into two kinds, are characterized by propriety.

original: vyavahāro hi vṛttir ity ucyate /
analyzed: vyavahāraḥ hi vṛttiḥ iti ucyate
translated: For usage is said to be a meter.

original: tatra rasānuguṇa aucityavān vācyāśrayo yo vyavahāras tā etāḥ kaiśikyādyā vṛttayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra rasa anuguṇaḥ aucityavān vācya āśrayaḥ yaḥ vyavahāraḥ tāḥ etāḥ kaiśikī ādyāḥ vṛttayaḥ
translated: Among them, those usages which are characterized by propriety in accordance with rasa are the meters beginning with the Kaishika, which are based on the expressed meaning.

original: vācakāśrayāś copanāgarikādyāḥ /
analyzed: vācaka āśrayāḥ ca upanāgarika ādyāḥ
translated: And those based on the expressed meaning are the meters beginning with the Upanagarika.

original: vṛttayo hi rasāditātparyeṇa saṃniveśitāḥ kām api nāṭyasya kāvyasya ca chāyām āvahanti /
analyzed: vṛttayaḥ hi rasa ādi tātparyeṇa saṃniveśitāḥ kām api nāṭyasya kāvyasya ca chāyām āvahanti
translated: For meters, when arranged with rasa, etc., as their aim, bring about a certain charm in drama and poetry.

original: rasādayo hi dvayor api tayor jīvabhūtāḥ /
analyzed: rasa ādayaḥ hi dvayoḥ api tayoḥ jīva bhūtāḥ
translated: For rasa, etc., are the life of both of them.

original: itivṛttādi tu śarīrabhūtam eva /
analyzed: itivṛtta ādi tu śarīra bhūtam eva
translated: But the story, etc., are merely the body.

original: atra kecid āhuḥguṇaguṇivyavahāro rasādīnām itivṛttādibhiḥ saha yuktaḥ /
analyzed: atra kecid āhuḥ guṇa guṇi vyavahāraḥ rasa ādīnām iti vṛtta ādibhiḥ saha yuktaḥ
