original: tasmāt pratipādyo viṣayaḥ śabdānāṃ na liṅgitvena sambandhī vācyavat /
analyzed: tasmāt pratipādyaḥ viṣayaḥ śabdānām na liṅgi tvena sambandhī vācya vat
translated: Therefore, the indicated sense is not related to words as the object of the indicative function, like the denoted sense.

original: yo hi liṅgitvena teṣāṃ sambandhī yathā darśito viṣayaḥ sa na vācyatvena pratīyate /
analyzed: yaḥ hi liṅgi tvena teṣām sambandhī yathā darśitaḥ viṣayaḥ sa na vācya tvena pratīyate
translated: The sense that is related to them as the indicative function, as shown, is not perceived as the denoted sense.

original: api tūpādhitvena /
analyzed: api tu upādhi tvena
translated: But rather as the qualifying factor.

original: pratipādyasya ca viṣayasya liṅgitve tadviṣayāṇāṃ vipratipattīnāṃ laukikair eva kriyamāṇānām abhāvaḥ prasajyeteti /
analyzed: pratipādyasya ca viṣayasya liṅgi tve tad viṣayāṇām vipratipattīnām laukikaiḥ eva kriyamāṇānām abhāvaḥ prasajyeta iti
translated: And if the indicated sense were related to them as the indicative function, then the various opinions of ordinary people regarding that sense would not arise.

original: etac coktam eva /
analyzed: etat ca uktam eva
translated: This has already been stated.

original: yathā ca vācyaviṣaye pramāṇāntarānugamena samyaktvapratītau kvacit kriyamāṇāyāṃ tasya pramāṇāntaraviṣayatve saty api na śabdavyāpāraviṣayatāhānis
analyzed: yathā ca vācya viṣaye pramāṇa antara anugamena samyaktva pratītau kvacid kriyamāṇāyām tasya pramāṇa antara viṣaya tve sati api na śabda vyāpāra viṣaya tā hāniḥ
translated: And just as, when the truth of a certain fact is being ascertained by the corroboration of other means of knowledge, even though that fact is the object of another means of knowledge, it does not cease to be the object of verbal operation.

original: tadvyaṅgyasyāpi /
analyzed: tad vyaṅgyasya api
translated: because it is also suggested.

original: kāvyaviṣaye ca vyaṅgyapratītīnāṃ satyā satyanirūpaṇasyāprayojakatvam eveti tatra pramāṇāntaravyāpāraparīkṣopahāsāyaiva sampadyate /
analyzed: kāvya viṣaye ca vyaṅgya pratītīnām satyā satya nirūpaṇasya aprayojaka tvam eva iti tatra pramāṇa antara vyāpāra parīkṣā upahāsāya eva sampadyate
translated: And when the suggested meanings are true in the case of poetry, the ascertainment of truth is irrelevant. Thus, the examination of the operation of another means of knowledge in that case becomes a mere mockery.

original: tasmāl liṅgipratītir eva sarvatra vyaṅgyapratītir iti na śakyate vaktum /🔽yat tv anumeyarūpavyaṅgyaviṣayaṃ śabdānāṃ vyañjakatvaṃ taddhvanivyavahārasyāprayojakam /
analyzed: tasmāt liṅgi pratītiḥ eva sarvatra vyaṅgya pratītiḥ iti na śakyate vaktum  yat tu anumeya rūpa vyaṅgya viṣayam śabdānām vyañjaka tvam tat dhvani vyavahārasya aprayojakam
translated: Therefore, it cannot be said that the cognition of the suggested meaning is everywhere the cognition of an inferred fact.🔽But that suggestive power of words which has for its object a suggested meaning in the form of an inference is not relevant to the usage of dhvani.

original: api tu vyañjakatvalakṣaṇaḥ śabdānāṃ vyāpāra autpattikaśabdārthasambandhavādināpy abhyupagantavya iti pradarśanārtham upanyastam /
analyzed: api tu vyañjaka tva lakṣaṇaḥ śabdānām vyāpāraḥ autpattika śabda artha sambandha vādinā api abhyupagantavyaḥ iti pradarśana artham upanyastam
translated: It is set forth only to show that even one who holds that the relation between a word and its meaning is innate must admit the operation of words in the form of suggestion.

original: tad dhi vyañjakatvaṃ kadācil liṅgatvena kadācid rūpāntareṇa śabdānāṃ vācakānām avācakānāṃ ca sarvavādibhir apratikṣepyam ity ayam asmābhir 🔽yatna ārabdhaḥ /
analyzed: tat hi vyañjaka tvam kadācid liṅga tvena kadācid rūpa antareṇa śabdānām vācakānām avācakānām ca sarva vādibhiḥ a pratikṣepyam iti ayam asmābhiḥ  yatnaḥ ārabdhaḥ
translated: For that is the manifesting [function] of words, which is sometimes by way of indication and sometimes by some other means, and is not to be rejected by any of the disputants regarding expressive or non-expressive words. This is the effort we have undertaken.

original: tad evaṃ guṇavṛttivācakatvādibhyaḥ śabdaprakārebhyo niyamenaiva tāvad vilakṣaṇaṃ vyañjakatvam /
analyzed: tat evam guṇa vṛtti vācaka tva ādibhyaḥ śabda prakārebhyaḥ niyamena eva tāvat vilakṣaṇam vyañjaka tvam
translated: Thus, the manifesting [function] is certainly different from the types of words such as expressive, figurative, and expressive by convention.🔽Even if it is included within that, when it is forcibly called that [type], the manifestation of that particular type of dhvani, in order to remove disagreement or to instruct the connoisseurs,

original: tadantaḥpātitve 'pi tasya haṭhād abhidhīyamāne tadviśeṣasya dhvaner yatprakāśanaṃ vipratipattinirāsāya sahṛdayavyutpattaye vā tatkriyamāṇam
analyzed: tad antaḥpāti tve pi tasya haṭhāt abhidhīyamāne tad viśeṣasya dhvaneḥ yat prakāśanam vipratipatti nirāsāya sahṛdaya vyutpattaye vā tat kriyamāṇam
translated: is being done.

original: anatisandheyam eva /
analyzed: an atisandheyam eva
translated: It is not to be disregarded at all.

original: na hi sāmānyamātralakṣaṇenopayogiviśeṣalakṣaṇānāṃ pratikṣepaḥ śakyaḥ kartum /
analyzed: na hi sāmānya mātra lakṣaṇena upayogi viśeṣa lakṣaṇānām pratikṣepaḥ śakyaḥ kartum
translated: For it is not possible to reject the definitions of useful particulars by the definition of the mere general [property].

original: evaṃ hi sati sattāmātralakṣaṇe kṛte sakalasadvastulakṣaṇānāṃ paunaruktyaprasaṅgaḥ / tad evam
analyzed: evam hi sati sattā mātra lakṣaṇe kṛte sakala sat vastu lakṣaṇānām paunaruktya prasaṅgaḥ tat evam
translated: If it were so, then after the definition of mere existence is done, there would be the undesirable consequence of the repetition of the definitions of all existent things. Thus,

original: vimativiṣayo ya āsīn manīṣiṇāṃ satatam aviditasatattvaḥ /
analyzed: vimati viṣayaḥ yaḥ āsīt manīṣiṇām satatam a vidita sa tattvaḥ
translated: that which was the object of doubt for the wise, always unknown in its true nature,

original: dhvanisaṃjñitaḥ prakāraḥ kāvyasya vyañjitaḥ so 'yam // / //
analyzed: dhvani saṃjñitaḥ prakāraḥ kāvyasya vyañjitaḥ saḥ yam
translated: that type of poetry called dhvani is now manifested...🔽...

original: prakāro 'nyo guṇībhūtavyaṅgyaḥ kāvyasya dṛśyate /
analyzed: prakāraḥ nyaḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgyaḥ kāvyasya dṛśyate
translated: Another type of poetry is seen where the suggested sense is subordinate.

original: yatra vyaṅgyānvaye vācyacārutvaṃ syāt prakarṣavat // / //
analyzed: yatra vyaṅgya anvaye vācya cāru tvam syāt prakarṣavat
translated: Where the suggested sense, being connected, would have the excellence of the expressed sense to a high degree.

original: vyaṅgyo 'rtho lalanālāvaṇyaprakhyo yaḥ pratipāditas tasya prādhānye dhvanir ity uktam /🔽tasya tu guṇībhāvena vācyacārutvaprakarṣe guṇībhūtavyaṅgyo nāma kāvyaprabhedaḥ prakalpyate /
analyzed: vyaṅgyaḥ rthaḥ lalanā lāvaṇya prakhyaḥ yaḥ pratipāditaḥ tasya prādhānye dhvaniḥ iti uktam  tasya tu guṇībhāvena vācya cāru tva prakarṣe guṇībhūtavyaṅgyaḥ nāma kāvya prabhedaḥ prakalpyate
translated: The suggested sense, which has been shown to be like the beauty of a young woman, is said to be dhvani when it is primary.🔽But when it is subordinate, and the excellence of the expressed sense is to a high degree, a type of poetry called where the suggested sense is subordinate is conceived.

original: tatra vastumātrasya vyaṅgyasya tiraskṛtavācyebhyaḥ pratīyamānasya kadācid vācyarūpavākyārthāpekṣayā guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatā
analyzed: tatra vastu mātrasya vyaṅgyasya tiraskṛta vācyebhyaḥ pratīyamānasya kadācid vācya rūpa vākyārtha apekṣayā guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tā  /
translated: There, when the mere fact suggested, which is implied by those [passages] where the expressed meaning is set aside, is sometimes subordinate to the meaning of the sentence in the form of the expressed meaning, it is called where the suggested sense is subordinate.

original: yathā
analyzed: yathā
translated: For example:

original: lāvaṇyasindhur aparaiva hi keyam atra🔽yatrotpalāni śaśinā saha samplavante /
analyzed: lāvaṇya sindhuḥ aparā eva hi kā iyam atra  yatra utpalāni śaśinā saha samplavante
translated: Is this not another ocean of beauty,🔽where lotuses float together with the moon,

original: unmajjati dviradakumbhataṭī ca yatra
analyzed: unmajjati dvirada kumbha taṭī ca yatra
translated: where the temples of elephants emerge,

original: yatrāpare kadalikāṇḍamṛṇāladaṇḍāḥ //
analyzed: yatra apare kadali kāṇḍa mṛṇāla daṇḍāḥ
translated: and elsewhere are the stalks and shoots of plantain trees?

original: atiraskṛtavācyebhyo 'pi śabdebhyaḥ pratīyamānasya vyaṅgyasya kadācid vācyaprādhānyena kāvyacārutvāpekṣayā guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatā /
analyzed: a tiraskṛta vācyebhyaḥ śabdebhyaḥ pratīyamānasya vyaṅgyasya kadācid vācya prādhānyena kāvya cāru tva apekṣayā guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tā
translated: Even when the suggested sense is sometimes subordinated to the expressed sense in poetry, which is dependent on the beauty of the expressed sense, there is the state of being subordinated of the suggested sense, even though it is suggested by words where the suggested sense is not suppressed.

original: yathodāhṛtamanurāgavatī sandhyā ity evam ādi /
analyzed: yathā udāhṛtam anurāgavatī sandhyā iti evam ādi
translated: As has been cited, The evening is full of love, and so on.

original: tasyaiva svayam uktyā prakāśīkṛtatvena guṇībhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasya eva svayam uktyā prakāśīkṛta tvena guṇībhāvaḥ
translated: That [suggested sense] is subordinated by its own statement being made manifest.

original: yathodāhṛtam
analyzed: yathā udāhṛtam
translated: As has been cited,

original: saṅketakālamanasam ity ādi /
analyzed: saṅketa kāla manasam iti ādi
translated: The mind at the time of the convention, and so on.

original: rasādirūpavyaṅgyasya guṇībhāvo rasavadalaṅkāre darśitaḥ /
analyzed: rasa ādi rūpa vyaṅgyasya guṇībhāvaḥ rasavat alaṅkāre darśitaḥ
translated: The subordination of the suggested sense in the form of rasa, etc. is shown in the rasa-based ornament.

original: tatra ca teṣām ādhikārikavākyāpekṣayā guṇībhāvo vivahanapravṛttabhṛtyānuyāyirājavat /
analyzed: tatra ca teṣām ādhikārika vākya apekṣayā guṇībhāvaḥ vivahana pravṛtta bhṛtya anuyāyi rāja vat
translated: And there, their subordination is in relation to the authoritative statement, like a servant who follows a king who has set out on a journey.

original: vyaṅgyālaṅkārasya guṇībhāve dīpakādiviṣayaḥ // / //
analyzed: vyaṅgya alaṅkārasya guṇībhāve dīpaka ādi viṣayaḥ
translated: In the subordination of the suggested ornament, the subject of the lamp-based ornament, etc. is omitted.

original: tathā
analyzed: tathā
translated: Similarly,

original: prasannagambhīrapadāḥ kāvyabandhāḥ sukhāvahāḥ /
analyzed: prasanna gambhīra padāḥ kāvya bandhāḥ sukha āvahāḥ
translated: Poetic compositions with clear and profound words are delightful.

original: ye ca teṣu prakāro 'yam eva yojyāḥ sumedhasā // / //
analyzed: ye ca teṣu prakāraḥ yam eva yojyāḥ sumedhasā
translated: And in those, this very type should be employed by the wise.

original: ye caite 'parimitasvarūpā api prakāśamānās tathāvidhārtharamaṇīyāḥ santo vivekināṃ sukhāvahāḥ kāvyabandhās teṣu sarveṣv evāyaṃ prakāro guṇībhūtavyaṅgyo
analyzed: ye ca ete parimita sva rūpāḥ api prakāśamānāḥ tathāvidha artha ramaṇīyāḥ santaḥ vivekinām sukha āvahāḥ kāvya bandhāḥ teṣu sarveṣu eva ayam prakāraḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgyaḥ
translated: And those poetic compositions which, though of immeasurable form, are shining forth, delightful in that way with objects, and bring happiness to the discerning, in all of them this type should be applied as subordinated suggestion.

original: nāma yojanīyaḥ / yathā
analyzed: nāma yojanīyaḥ yathā
translated: For example:

original: lacchī duhidā jāmāuo harī taṃsa ghariṇiā gaṅgā /
analyzed: lacchī duhidā jāmāuaḥ harī gaṅgā
translated: Lakshmi is the daughter, Hari is the son-in-law, and Ganga is the wife.

original: amiamiaṅkā a suā aho kuḍumbaṃ mahoahiṇo //
analyzed: a suā aho kuḍumbam mahoahiṇaḥ
translated: The two, nectar and the deer-marked moon, are the sons. Oh, what a family of the great ocean!

original: lakṣmī duhitā jāmātā hariḥ tathā gṛhiṇī gaṅgā /
analyzed: lakṣmī duhitā jāmātā hariḥ tathā gṛhiṇī gaṅgā
translated: Lakshmi is the daughter, Hari is the son-in-law, and Ganga is the wife.

original: amṛtamṛgāṅkau ca sutau aho kuṭumbaṃ mahodadheḥ //// ///
analyzed: amṛta mṛgāṅkau ca sutau aho kuṭumbam mahā udadheḥ
translated: The two, nectar and the deer-marked moon, are the sons. Oh, what a family of the great ocean!

original: vācyālaṅkāravargo 'yaṃ vyaṅgyāṃśānugame sati /
analyzed: vācya alaṅkāra vargaḥ yam vyaṅgya aṃśa anugame sati
translated: This group of verbal ornaments, when following the suggested portion,

original: prāyeṇaiva parāṃ chāyāṃ bibhral lakṣye nirīkṣyate // / //
analyzed: prāyeṇa eva parām chāyām bibhrat lakṣye nirīkṣyate
translated: is seen in poetry to bear the highest charm, for the most part.

original: vācyālaṅkāravargo 'yaṃ vyaṅgyāṃśasyālaṅkārasya vastumātrasya vā yathāyogam anugame sati cchāyātiśayaṃ bibhrallakṣaṇakārair ekadeśena
analyzed: vācya alaṅkāra vargaḥ yam vyaṅgya aṃśasya alaṅkārasya vastu mātrasya vā yathāyogam anugame sati chāyā atiśayam bibhrat lakṣaṇa kāraiḥ ekadeśena
translated: This group of verbal ornaments, when following the ornament in the suggested portion or the mere fact, as appropriate, and bearing an excess of charm, is described by the authors of definitions as an ornament in one part.

original: sa tu tathārūpaḥ prāyeṇa sarva eva parīkṣyamāṇo lakṣye nirīkṣyate /
analyzed: sa tu tathārūpaḥ prāyeṇa sarvaḥ eva parīkṣyamāṇaḥ lakṣye nirīkṣyate
translated: But that, of such a form, is seen in poetry, for the most part, when examined, as all of it.

original: tathā hidīpakasamāsoktyādivadanye 'py alaṅkārāḥ prāyeṇa vyaṅgyālaṅkārāntaravastvantarasaṃsparśino dṛśyante /
analyzed: tathā hi dīpaka samāsokti ādi vat anye pi alaṅkārāḥ prāyeṇa vyaṅgya alaṅkāra antara vastu antara saṃsparśinaḥ dṛśyante
translated: For instance, other figures of speech, like the lamp-simile, are seen to touch upon other suggested figures of speech and other suggested objects.

original: yataḥ prathamaṃ tāvad atiśayoktigarbhatā sarvālaṅkāreṣu śakyakriyā /
analyzed: yatas prathamam tāvat atiśayokti garbha tā sarva alaṅkāreṣu śakya kriyā
translated: Because, first of all, hyperbole can be employed in all figures of speech.

original: kṛtaiva ca sā mahākavibhiḥ kām api kāvyacchaviṃ puṣyati /
analyzed: kṛtā eva ca sā mahā kavibhiḥ kām api kāvya chavim puṣyati
translated: And it has been employed by great poets, which enhances the beauty of poetry in some way.

original: kathaṃ hy atiśayayogitā svaviṣayaucityena kriyamāṇā satī kāvye notkarṣam āvahet /
analyzed: katham hi atiśaya yogi tā sva viṣaya aucityena kriyamāṇā satī kāvye nā utkarṣam āvahet
translated: For how could the combination of hyperbole, when done in accordance with the appropriateness of its subject, not bring about excellence in poetry?

original: bhāmahenāpy atiśayoktilakṣaṇe yad uktam
analyzed: bhāmahena api atiśayokti lakṣaṇe yat uktam
translated: And what was said by Bhämaha in the definition of hyperbole:

original: saiṣā sarvaiva vakroktir anayārtho vibhāvyate /
analyzed: sā eṣā sarvā eva vakroktiḥ anayā arthaḥ vibhāvyate
translated: This very crooked speech, the meaning of which is inferred,

original: yatno 'syāṃ kavinā kāryaḥ ko 'laṅkāro 'nayā vinā //iti /
analyzed: syām kavinā kāryaḥ kaḥ laṅkāraḥ nayā vinā iti
translated: in which the poet should make an effort, what figure of speech is there without it?

original: tatrātiśayoktir yam alaṅkāram adhitiṣṭhati kavipratibhāvaśāt tasya cārutvātiśayayogo
analyzed: tatra atiśayoktiḥ yam alaṅkāram adhitiṣṭhati kavi pratibhā vaśāt tasya cāru tva atiśaya yogaḥ
translated: There, hyperbole, which is based on some figure of speech by the power of the poet's imagination, has the quality of an excess of beauty,

original: 'nyasya tv alaṅkāramātrataiveti sarvālaṅkāraśarīrasvīkaraṇayogyatvenābhedopacārāt
analyzed: nyasya tu alaṅkāra mātra tā eva iti sarva alaṅkāra śarīra svīkaraṇa yogya tvena abheda upacārāt
translated: while the other [figures of speech] are merely figures of speech. Thus, because of the figurative identification as being fit to be accepted as the body of all figures of speech,

original: saiva sarvālaṅkārarūpety ayam evārtho 'vagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: sā eva sarva alaṅkāra rūpā iti ayam eva arthaḥ vagantavyaḥ
translated: this very [hyperbole] is of the nature of all figures of speech - this is the meaning that should be understood.

original: tasyāś cālaṅkārāntarasaṃkīrṇatvaṃ kadācid vācyatvena kadacid vyaṅgyatvena /🔽vyaṅgyatvam api kadācit prādhānyena kadācid guṇabhāvena /
analyzed: tasyāḥ ca alaṅkāra antara saṃkīrṇa tvam kadācid vācya tvena kadacid vyaṅgya tvena  vyaṅgya tvam api kadācid prādhānyena kadācid guṇa bhāvena
translated: And it is sometimes suggested as a figure of speech mixed with another figure of speech, and sometimes as a suggested sense.🔽And even in the case of suggested sense, it is sometimes primary and sometimes subordinate.

original: tatrādye pakṣe vācyālaṅkāramārgaḥ /
analyzed: tatra ādye pakṣe vācya alaṅkāra mārgaḥ
translated: Of these, in the first case, it is a figure of speech that is expressed.

original: dvitīye tu dhvanāv antarbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: dvitīye tu dhvanau antarbhāvaḥ
translated: In the second case, it is included in suggestion.

original: tṛtīye tu guṇībhūtavyaṅgyarūpatā /
analyzed: tṛtīye tu guṇībhūta vyaṅgya rūpa tā
translated: In the third case, it is a subordinate suggested sense.

original: ayaṃ ca prakāro 'nyeṣām apy alaṅkārāṇām asti /
analyzed: ayam ca prakāraḥ nyeṣām api alaṅkārāṇām asti
translated: And this type exists for other figures of speech as well.

original: teṣāṃ tu na sarvaviṣayaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām tu na sarva viṣayaḥ
translated: But it is not applicable to all of them.

original: atiśayoktes tu sarvālaṅkāraviṣayo 'pi sambhavatīty ayaṃ viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atiśayokteḥ tu sarva alaṅkāra viṣayaḥ sambhavati iti ayam viśeṣaḥ
translated: But in the case of hyperbole, it is possible to apply to all figures of speech. This is the difference.

original: yeṣu cālaṅkāreṣu sādṛśyamukhena tattvapratilambhaḥ yathā rūpakopamātulyayogitānidarśanādiṣu
analyzed: yeṣu ca alaṅkāreṣu sādṛśya mukhena tattva pratilambhaḥ yathā rūpaka upamā tulya yogi tā nidarśana ādiṣu
translated: And in those figures of speech where the truth is obtained through similarity, such as metaphor, simile, equal pairing, illustration, etc.,

original: teṣu gamyamānadharmamukhenaiva yat sādṛśyaṃ tad eva śobhātiśayaśāli bhavatīti
analyzed: teṣu gamyamāna dharma mukhena eva yat sādṛśyam tat eva śobhā atiśaya śāli bhavati iti
translated: in them, the similarity that is conveyed only through the suggested sense is itself full of the charm of excellence.

original: te sarve 'pi cārutvātiśayayoginaḥ santo guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasyaiva viṣayāḥ /
analyzed: te sarve pi cāru tva atiśaya yoginaḥ santaḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya eva viṣayāḥ
translated: And all of them, being endowed with the charm of excellence, are the objects only of the subordinate suggested sense.

original: samāsoktyākṣepaparyāyoktyādiṣu tu gamyamānāṃśāvinābhāvenaiva tattvavyavasthānād guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatā nirvivādaiva /
analyzed: samāsokti ākṣepa paryāyokti ādiṣu tu gamyamāna aṃśa avinābhāvena eva tattva vyavasthānāt guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tā nirvivādā eva
translated: But in cases of suggestion by implication, by pervasion, by metonymy, and so on, the determination of the nature of the suggestion is by the absence of the suggested portion, and so the fact that the suggestion is subordinated is beyond dispute.

original: tatra ca guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatāyām alaṅkārāṇāṃ keṣāñcid alaṅkāraviśeṣagarbhatāyāṃ niyamaḥ /
analyzed: tatra ca guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tāyām alaṅkārāṇām keṣāñcid alaṅkāra viśeṣa garbha tāyām niyamaḥ
translated: And in that case, in the case of suggestion subordinated, there is a rule that some figures of speech contain another figure of speech.

original: yathā vyājastuteḥ preyo 'laṅkāragarbhatve /
analyzed: yathā vyāja stuteḥ preyaḥ laṅkāra garbha tve
translated: For example, the figure of speech vyajastuti (praise by way of a pretext) contains the figure of speech preyo (the agreeable).

original: keṣāñcid alaṅkāramātragarbhatāyāṃ niyamaḥ /
analyzed: keṣāñcid alaṅkāra mātra garbha tāyām niyamaḥ
translated: There is a rule that some figures of speech contain only a figure of speech.

original: yathā sandehādīnām upamāgarbhatve /
analyzed: yathā sandeha ādīnām upamā garbha tve
translated: For example, the figures of speech saṃdeha (doubt) and so on contain the figure of speech upamā (simile).

original: keṣāñcid alaṅkārāṇāṃ parasparagarbhatāpi sambhavati /
analyzed: keṣāṃcid alaṅkārāṇām paraspara garbha tā api sambhavati
translated: It is possible that some figures of speech contain each other.

original: yathā dīpakopamayoḥ /
analyzed: yathā dīpaka upamayoḥ
translated: For example, dīpaka (illumination) and upamā (simile).

original: tatra dīpakam upamāgarbhatvena prasiddham /
analyzed: tatra dīpakam upamā garbha tvena prasiddham
translated: Of these, dīpaka is well known to contain upamā (simile).

original: upamāpi kadācid dīpakacchāyānuyāyinī /
analyzed: upamā api kadācid dīpaka chāyā anuyāyinī
translated: Upamā (simile) sometimes follows the shadow of dīpaka (illumination).

original: yathā mālopamā /
analyzed: yathā mālā upamā
translated: For example, in the case of mālôpamā (stringed simile).

original: tathā hi prabhāmahatyā śikhayeva dīpaḥ ity ādau sphuṭaiva dīpakacchāyā lakṣyate /
analyzed: tathā hi prabhā mahatyā śikhayā iva dīpaḥ iti ādau sphuṭā eva dīpaka chāyā lakṣyate
translated: For example, in the passage like a lamp with a very bright flame, the shadow of dīpaka (illumination) is clearly seen.

original: tad evaṃ vyaṅgyāṃśasaṃsparśe sati cārutvātiśayayogino rūpakādayo 'laṅkārāḥ sarva eva guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasya mārgaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam vyaṅgya aṃśa saṃsparśe sati cāru tva atiśaya yoginaḥ rūpaka ādayaḥ laṅkārāḥ sarve eva guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya mārgaḥ
translated: Thus, when there is contact with the suggested portion, all the figures of speech such as rūpaka (metaphor) and so on, which possess an excess of beauty, are the path of suggestion subordinated.

original: guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatvaṃ ca teṣāṃ tathājātīyānāṃ sarveṣām evoktānuktānāṃ sāmānyam /
analyzed: guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tvam ca teṣām tathājātīyānām sarveṣām eva ukta anuktānām sāmānyam
translated: And the fact that they have a subordinate suggestion is a common characteristic of all such figures, whether mentioned or not.

original: tallakṣaṇe sarva evaite sulakṣitā bhavanti /
analyzed: tad lakṣaṇe sarve eva ete su lakṣitāḥ bhavanti
translated: They are all well defined by that definition.

original: ekaikasya svarūpaviśeṣakathanena tu sāmānyalakṣaṇarahitena pratipādapāṭheneva śabdā na śakyante tattvato nirjñātum ānantyāt /
analyzed: ekaikasya svarūpa viśeṣa kathanena tu sāmānya lakṣaṇa rahitena pratipāda pāṭhena iva śabdāḥ na śakyante tattvataḥ nirjñātum ānantyāt
translated: But if they are described by stating the specific nature of each one, without a general definition, they cannot be truly known, because of their infinite number, just as words cannot be known by a list of their individual meanings.

original: anantā hi vāgvikalpās tatprakārā eva cālaṅkārāḥ /
analyzed: anantāḥ hi vāc vikalpāḥ tad prakārāḥ eva ca alaṅkārāḥ
translated: For there are infinite varieties of language, and figures of speech are of the same kind.

original: guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasya ca prakārāntareṇāpi vyaṅgyārthānugamalakṣaṇena viṣayatvam asty eva /
analyzed: guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya ca prakāra antareṇa api vyaṅgya artha anugama lakṣaṇena viṣaya tvam asti eva
translated: And the figure with a subordinate suggestion also has a subject matter that is defined by its connection with a suggested meaning in another way.

original: tad ayaṃ dhvaniniṣyandarūpo dvitīyo 'pi mahākaviviṣayo 'tiramaṇīyo lakṣaṇīyaḥ sahṛdayaiḥ /
analyzed: tat ayam dhvani nisyanda rūpaḥ dvitīyaḥ pi mahā kavi viṣayaḥ ti ramaṇīyaḥ lakṣaṇīyaḥ sahṛdayaiḥ
translated: Therefore this second great subject matter of the great poets, which is the outflow of dhvani, should also be defined by the connoisseurs as extremely delightful.

original: sarvathā nāsty eva sahṛdayahṛdayahāriṇaḥ kāvyasya sa prakāro yatra na pratīyamānārthasaṃsparśena saubhāgyam /
analyzed: sarvathā nā asti eva sahṛdaya hṛdaya hāriṇaḥ kāvyasya sa prakāraḥ yatra na pratīyamāna artha saṃsparśena saubhāgyam
translated: In every way there is no type of poetry that delights the heart of the connoisseur in which there is not the good fortune of contact with the suggested meaning.

original: tad idaṃ kāvyarahasyaṃ param iti sūribhir bhāvanīyam /
analyzed: tat idam kāvya rahasyam param iti sūribhiḥ bhāvanīyam
translated: This is the highest secret of poetry, and should be considered by the wise.

original: mukhyā mahākavigirām alaṅkṛtibhṛtām api /
analyzed: mukhyāḥ mahā kavi girām alaṅkṛti bhṛtām api
translated: The primary figures of speech of the great poets, even though they bear ornaments,

original: pratīyamānacchāyaiṣā bhūṣā lajjeva yoṣitām // / //🔽anayā suprasiddho 'py arthaḥ kim api kāmanīyakamānīyate / tad yathā
analyzed: pratīyamāna chāyā eṣā bhūṣā lajjā iva yoṣitām  anayā su prasiddhaḥ api arthaḥ kim api kāmanīyakam ānīyate tat yathā
translated: This is the ornament of suggestion, as it were, of bashful women.🔽By this, even a well-known meaning is somehow made desirable. For example:

original: viśrambhotthā manmathājñāvidhāne
analyzed: viśrambha utthāḥ manmatha ājñā vidhāne
translated: The certain commands of the god of love arising from confidence,

original: ye mugdhākṣyāḥ ke 'pi līlāviśeṣāḥ /
analyzed: ye mugdhākṣyāḥ ke pi līlā viśeṣāḥ
translated: are certain special graces of the innocent-eyed one.

original: akṣuṇṇās te cetasā kevalena
analyzed: a kṣuṇṇāḥ te cetasā kevalena
translated: They are not impaired by the mere mind,

original: sthitvaikānte santataṃ bhāvanīyāḥ //
analyzed: sthitvā ekānte santatam bhāvanīyāḥ
translated: having remained in solitude, they should be constantly contemplated.

original: ity atra ke 'pīty anena padena vācyam aspaṣṭam abhidadhatā pratīyamānaṃ vastvakliṣṭam anantam arpayatā kā chāyā nopapāditā // / //
analyzed: iti atra ke pi iti anena padena vācyam aspaṣṭam abhidadhatā pratīyamānam vastu akliṣṭam anantam arpayatā kā chāyā na upapāditā
translated: Here, by the word 'certain', expressing the inexplicit meaning, by presenting the suggested meaning as unstrained and endless, what charm is not produced?

original: arthāntaragatiḥ kākvā yā caiṣā paridṛśyate /
analyzed: artha antara gatiḥ kākvā yā ca eṣā paridṛśyate
translated: And this transition to another meaning that is seen through irony,

original: sā vyaṅgyasya guṇībhāve prakāram imam āśritā // / //
analyzed: sā vyaṅgyasya guṇībhāve prakāram imam āśritā
translated: that is based on this type when the suggested meaning is subordinated.

original: yā caiṣā kākvā kvacid arthāntarapratītirdṛśyate sa vyaṅgyasyārthasya guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūtavyaṅgyalakṣaṇaṃ kāvyaprabhedamāśrayate /
analyzed: yā ca eṣā kākvā kvacid artha antara pratītiḥ dṛśyate sa vyaṅgyasya arthasya guṇībhāve sati guṇībhūta vyaṅgya lakṣaṇam kāvya prabhedam āśrayate
translated: And this transition to another meaning that is seen through irony, when the suggested meaning is subordinated, it is based on the type of poetry characterized by the subordinated suggested meaning.🔽For example:

original: yathāsvasthā bhavanti mayi jīvati dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ / yathā vā
analyzed: yathāsvasthāḥ bhavanti mayi jīvati dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ yathā vā
translated: How can the sons of Dhritarashtra be well, as long as I live? Or:

original: ām asatyaḥ uparama pativrate na tvayā malinitaṃ śīlam /
analyzed: ām asatyaḥ uparama pativrate na tvayā malinitam śīlam
translated: O unchaste woman, stop! You have not sullied your character.

original: kiṃ punar janasya jāyeva nāpitaṃ taṃ na kāmayāmahe //🔽śabdaśaktir eva hi svābhidheyasāmarthyākṣiptakākusahāyā saty arthaviśeṣapratipattihetur na kākumātram /
analyzed: kim punar janasya jāyā iva nāpitam tam na kāmayāmahe  śabda śaktiḥ eva hi sva abhidheya sāmarthya ākṣipta kāku sahāyā satī artha viśeṣa pratipatti hetuḥ na kāku mātram
translated: But we do not desire that barber, just as a wife does not desire another man.🔽For the power of the word, aided by the gesture indicated by its own denotative power, is the cause of understanding a particular meaning, not just the gesture alone.

original: viṣayāntare svecchākṛtāt kākumātrāt tathāvidhārthapratipattyasambhavāt /🔽sa cārthaḥ kākuviśeṣasahāyaśabdavyāpāropārūḍho 'py arthasāmarthyalabhya iti vyaṅgyarūpa eva /
analyzed: viṣaya antare sva icchā kṛtāt kāku mātrāt tathāvidha artha pratipatti asambhavāt  sa ca arthaḥ kāku viśeṣa sahāya śabda vyāpāra upārūḍhaḥ api artha sāmarthya labhyaḥ iti vyaṅgya rūpaḥ eva
translated: Because it is impossible to understand such a meaning from mere gesture created by one's own will in a different context.🔽And that meaning, though based on the operation of the word aided by a particular gesture, is to be understood by the power of the meaning, and is therefore of the nature of the suggested meaning.

original: vācakatvānugamenaiva tu yadā tadviśiṣṭavācyapratītis tadā guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatayā tathāvidhārthadyotinaḥ kāvyasya vyapadeśaḥ /
analyzed: vācaka tva anugamena eva tu yadā tad viśiṣṭa vācya pratītiḥ tadā guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tayā tathāvidha artha dyotinaḥ kāvyasya vyapadeśaḥ
translated: But when the understanding of the denoted meaning qualified by that [suggested meaning] occurs only through the operation of the denotative power, then that type of poetry which illuminates such a meaning is designated as having the suggested meaning as a secondary element.

original: vyaṅgyaviśiṣṭavācyābhidhāyino hi guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatvam /
analyzed: vyaṅgya viśiṣṭa vācya abhidhāyinaḥ hi guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tvam
translated: For that which expresses the denoted meaning qualified by the suggested meaning has the suggested meaning as a secondary element.

original: prabhedasyāsya viṣayo yaś ca yuktyā pratīyate /
analyzed: prabhedasya asya viṣayaḥ yaḥ ca yuktyā pratīyate
translated: And the object which is understood by reasoning in this type [of poetry],

original: vidhātavyā sahṛdayair na tatra dhvaniyojanā // / //
analyzed: vidhātavyā sahṛdayaiḥ na tatra dhvani yojanā

translated: Giving support to a fig tree that has gone astray, that is inauspicious, and is devoid of fruits, flowers, and leaves,

original: badaryā vṛttiṃ dadatpāmāraḥ bhoḥ hasiṣyase //
analyzed: badaryāḥ vṛttim dadat pāmāraḥ bhoḥ hasiṣyase
translated: the pamara, O friend, will surely laugh.

original: atra hi vācyārtho nātyantaṃ sambhavī na cāsambhavī /
analyzed: atra hi vācyārthaḥ na atyantam sambhavī na ca asambhavī
translated: Here, the literal meaning is neither absolutely possible nor impossible.

original: tasmād vācyavyaṅgyayoḥ prādhānyāprādhānye yatnato nirūpaṇīye // / //
analyzed: tasmāt vācya vyaṅgyayoḥ prādhānya aprādhānye yatnataḥ nirūpaṇīye
translated: Therefore, the predominance and non-predominance of the literal and suggested meanings should be carefully examined.

original: pradhānaguṇabhāvābhyāṃ vyaṅgyasyaivaṃ vyavasthite /
analyzed: pradhāna guṇa bhāvābhyām vyaṅgyasya evam vyavasthite
translated: When the suggested meaning is established as predominant or subordinate,

original: kāvye ubhe tato 'nyad yat tac citram abhidhīyate // / //
analyzed: kāvye ubhe yat tat citram abhidhīyate
translated: then the other type in poetry is called 'chitra' (variegated).

original: citraṃ śabdārthabhedena dvividhaṃ ca vyavasthitam /
analyzed: citram śabda artha bhedena dvividham ca vyavasthitam
translated: The variegated is also established as twofold, based on the difference in word and meaning.

original: tatra kiṃcic chabdacitraṃ vācyacitram ataḥ param // / //
analyzed: tatra kiṃcid śabda citram vācya citram atas param
translated: Among them, some is variegated in word, and the variegated in meaning comes after that.

original: vyaṅgyasyārthasya prādhānye dhvanisaṃjñitakāvyaprakāraḥ guṇabhāve tu guṇībhūtavyaṅgyatā /🔽tato 'nyad rasabhāvāditātparyarahitaṃ vyaṅgyārthaviśeṣaprakāśanaśaktiśūnyaṃ
analyzed: vyaṅgyasya arthasya prādhānye dhvani saṃjñita kāvya prakāraḥ guṇa bhāve tu guṇībhūta vyaṅgya tā  rasa bhāva ādi tātparya rahitam vyaṅgya artha viśeṣa prakāśana śakti śūnyam
translated: When the suggested meaning is predominant, it is the type of poetry called dhvani (suggestive poetry). When it is subordinate, it is guṇībhūtavyaṅgya (subordinate suggestion).🔽Then, the other type of poetry is devoid of rasa, bhava, etc. as its primary purpose, and is devoid of the power to reveal a particular suggested meaning.

original: ca kāvyaṃ kevalavācyavācakavaicitryamātrāśrayeṇopanibaddham ālekhyaprakhyaṃ
analyzed: ca kāvyam kevala vācya vācaka vaicitrya mātra āśrayeṇa upanibaddham ālekhya prakhyam
translated: That poetry, which appears like a painting, composed solely based on the variety of words and meanings,

original: yad ābhāsate tac citram /
analyzed: yat ābhāsate tat citram
translated: is called 'chitra' (variegated).

original: na tanmukhyaṃ kāvyam /
analyzed: na tat mukhyam kāvyam
translated: That is not the primary kind of poetry.

original: kāvyānukāro hy asau /
analyzed: kāvya anukāraḥ hi asau
translated: For it is a mere imitation of poetry.

original: tatra kiṃcic chabdacitraṃ yathā duṣkarayamakādi /
analyzed: tatra kiṃcid śabda citram yathā duṣkara yamaka ādi
translated: There, some is word-painting, such as difficult yamakas, etc.

original: vācyacitraṃ tataḥ śabdacitrād anyad vyaṅgyārthasaṃsparśarahitaṃ prādhānyena vākyārthatayā sthitaṃ rasāditātparyarahitam utprekṣādi /
analyzed: vācya citram tatas śabda citrāt anyat vyaṅgya artha saṃsparśa rahitam prādhānyena vākya artha tayā sthitam rasa ādi tātparya rahitam utprekṣā ādi
translated: The word-painted is different from that word-painting, devoid of the contact of suggested meaning, existing primarily as the meaning of a sentence, devoid of the intention of rasa, etc., such as imagination, etc.

original: atha kim idaṃ citraṃ nāma /
analyzed: atha kim idam citram nāma
translated: Now, what is this so-called painting?

original: yatra na pratīyamānārthasaṃsparśaḥ /
analyzed: yatra na pratīyamāna artha saṃsparśaḥ
translated: Where there is no contact with the suggested meaning.

original: pratīyamāno hy arthas tribhedaḥ prāk pradarśitaḥ /
analyzed: pratīyamānaḥ hi arthaḥ tri bhedaḥ prāk pradarśitaḥ
translated: For the suggested meaning is of three kinds, as shown before.

original: tatra yatra vastvalaṅkārāntaraṃ vā vyaṅgyaṃ nāsti sa nāma citrasya kalpyatāṃ viṣayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yatra vastu alaṅkāra antaram vā vyaṅgyam nā asti sa nāma citrasya kalpyatām viṣayaḥ
translated: There, where there is no suggested object or ornament, that may be imagined to be the domain of painting.

original: yatra tu rasādīnām aviṣayatvaṃ sa kāvyaprakāro na sambhavaty eva /
analyzed: yatra tu rasa ādīnām aviṣaya tvam sa kāvya prakāraḥ na sambhavati eva
translated: But that kind of poetry where there is no scope for rasa, etc., is not possible at all.

original: yasmād avastusaṃsparśitā kāvyasya nopapadyate /
analyzed: yasmāt avastu saṃsparśi tā kāvyasya nā upapadyate
translated: Because the absence of contact with an object is not possible for poetry.

original: vastu ca sarvam eva jagad gatam avaśyaṃ kasyacid rasasya bhāvasya vāṅgatvaṃ pratipadyate antato vibhāvatvena /
analyzed: vastu ca sarvam eva jagat gatam avaśyam kasyacid rasasya bhāvasya vā aṅga tvam pratipadyate antatas vibhāva tvena
translated: And every object in the world necessarily becomes an accessory of some rasa or bhāva, at least as an arousing factor.

original: cittavṛttiviśeṣā hi rasādayaḥ /
analyzed: citta vṛtti viśeṣāḥ hi rasa ādayaḥ
translated: For rasa, etc. are particular states of the mind.

original: na ca tad asti vastu kiṃcid yan na cittavṛttiviśeṣam upajanayati tadanutpādane vā kaviviṣayataiva tasya na syāt kaviviṣayaś ca citratayā 🔽kaścin nirūpyate /
analyzed: na ca tat asti vastu kiṃcid yat na citta vṛtti viśeṣam upajanayati tad anutpādane vā kavi viṣaya tā eva tasya na syāt kavi viṣayaḥ ca citra tayā  kaścid nirūpyate
translated: And there is no such thing which does not produce a particular mental state; if it does not produce it, it cannot be the object of a poet; and being the object of a poet, it is described as variegated.

original: atrocyatesatyaṃ na tādṛkkāvyaprakāro 'sti yatra rasādīnām apratītiḥ /
analyzed: atrā ucyate satyam na tādṛś kāvya prakāraḥ sti yatra rasa ādīnām apratītiḥ
translated: Here it is said: It is true that there is no such kind of poetry where rasa and others are not perceived.

original: kiṃ tu yadā rasabhāvādivivakṣāśūnyaḥ kaviḥ śabdālaṅkāram arthālaṅkāraṃ vopanibadhnāti tadā tadvivakṣāpekṣayā rasādiśūnyatārthasya parikalpyate
analyzed: kim tu yadā rasa bhāva ādi vivakṣā śūnyaḥ kaviḥ śabdālaṅkāram arthālaṅkāram vā upanibadhnāti tadā tad vivakṣā apekṣayā rasa ādi śūnyatā arthasya parikalpyate
translated: But when a poet devoid of the intention to express rasa, bhāva, etc. employs a sound ornament or sense ornament, then its lack of rasa, etc. is imagined in relation to that intention to express.

original: vivakṣopārūḍha eva hi kāvye śabdānām arthaḥ /
analyzed: vivakṣā upārūḍhaḥ eva hi kāvye śabdānām arthaḥ
translated: For the meaning of words in poetry is indeed superimposed on the intention to express.

original: vācyasāmarthyavaśena vā kavivivakṣāvirahe 'pi tathāvidhe viṣaye rasādipratītir
analyzed: vācya sāmarthya vaśena vā kavi vivakṣā virahe tathāvidhe viṣaye rasa ādi pratītiḥ
translated: Or, even in the absence of a poet's intention, the perception of rasa, etc. in such a subject occurs by the power of the expressed meaning,

original: bhavantī paridurbalā bhavatīty anenāpi prakāreṇa nīrasatvaṃ parikalpya citraviṣayo vyavasthāpyate /
analyzed: bhavantī paridurbalā bhavati iti anena api prakāreṇa nīrasa tvam parikalpya citra viṣayaḥ vyavasthāpyate
translated: and it becomes very weak. By this method also, the lack of rasa is imagined, and the variegated subject is established.

original: tad idam uktam🔽rasabhāvādiviṣayavivakṣāvirahe sati /
analyzed: tat idam uktam  rasa bhāva ādi viṣaya vivakṣā virahe sati
translated: This is what is said:🔽When there is an absence of the intention to express the subject of rasa, bhāva, etc.,

original: alaṅkāranibandho yaḥ sa citraviṣayo mataḥ //
analyzed: alaṅkāra nibandhaḥ yaḥ sa citra viṣayaḥ mataḥ
translated: that composition of ornaments is considered to have a variegated subject.

original: rasādiṣu vivakṣā tu syāt tātparyavatī yadā /
analyzed: rasa ādiṣu vivakṣā tu syāt tātparyavatī yadā
translated: When there is a desire to express rasa, etc. with a purpose,

original: tadā nāsty eva tat kāvyaṃ dhvaner yatra na gocaraḥ //
analyzed: tadā nā asti eva tat kāvyam dhvaneḥ yatra na gocaraḥ
translated: then that is not poetry, where dhvani is not the subject matter.

original: etac ca citraṃ kavīnāṃ viśṛṅkhalagirāṃ rasāditātparyam anapekṣyaiva kāvyapravṛttidarśanād asmābhiḥ parikalpitam /
analyzed: etat ca citram kavīnām viśṛṅkhala girām rasa ādi tātparyam an apekṣya eva kāvya pravṛtti darśanāt asmābhiḥ parikalpitam
translated: And this variety of poets with unrestrained speech, the desire to express rasa, etc., without regard, we have imagined, seeing the engagement in poetry.

original: idānīntanānāṃ tu nyāyye kāvyanayavyavasthāpane kriyamāṇe nāsty eva dhvanivyatiriktaḥ kāvyaprakāraḥ /🔽yataḥ paripākavatāṃ kavīnāṃ rasāditātparyavirahe vyāpāra eva na śobhate /
analyzed: idānīntanānām tu nyāyye kāvya naya vyavasthāpane kriyamāṇe nā asti eva dhvani vyatiriktaḥ kāvya prakāraḥ  yatas paripākavatām kavīnām rasa ādi tātparya virahe vyāpāraḥ eva na śobhate
translated: But for those of the present time, when the proper establishment of the way of poetry is being done, there is no type of poetry other than dhvani.🔽Because for poets of maturity, when there is an absence of the desire to express rasa, etc., the engagement itself does not shine.

original: rasāditātparye ca nāsty eva tad vastu yad abhimatarasāṅgatāṃ nīyamānaṃ na praguṇībhavati /
analyzed: rasa ādi tātparye ca nā asti eva tat vastu yat abhimata rasa aṅga tām nīyamānam na praguṇībhavati
translated: And when there is the desire to express rasa, etc., there is no such object which, when made a constituent of the desired rasa, does not become pleasing.

original: acetanā pi hi bhāvā yathāyatham ucitarasavibhāvatayā cetanavṛttāntayojanayā vā na santy eva te ye yānti na rasāṅgatām /
analyzed: acetanāḥ hi bhāvāḥ yathāyatham ucita rasa vibhāva tayā cetana vṛttānta yojanayā vā na santi eva te ye yānti na rasa aṅga tām
translated: Even insentient things, in accordance with their proper rasa-evoking power, or by being connected with the events of sentient beings, there are none which do not become constituents of rasa.

original: tathā cedam ucyate
analyzed: tathā ca idam ucyate
translated: And this is said:

original: apāre kāvyasaṃsāre kavir ekaḥ prajāpatiḥ /
analyzed: apāre kāvya saṃsāre kaviḥ ekaḥ prajāpatiḥ
translated: In the vast ocean of poetry, the poet is the one Prajapati.

original: yathāsmai rocate viśvaṃ tathedaṃ parivartate //🔽śṛṅgārī cet kaviḥ kāvye jātaṃ rasamayaṃ jagat /
analyzed: yathā asmai rocate viśvam tathā idam parivartate  śṛṅgārī ced kaviḥ kāvye jātam rasa mayam jagat
translated: As it pleases him, so does the universe revolve.🔽If the poet is a lover, the world becomes full of rasa in poetry.

original: sa eva vītarāgaś cen nīrasaṃ sarvam eva tat //
analyzed: saḥ eva vīta rāgaḥ ced nīrasam sarvam eva tat
translated: If he is free from passion, everything becomes tasteless.

original: bhāvān acetanān api cetanavac cetanānacetanavat /
analyzed: bhāvān acetanān api cetanavat cetana an acetana vat
translated: The good poet deals with even insentient things as if they were sentient, and sentient things as if they were insentient,

original: vyavahārayati yatheṣṭaṃ sukaviḥ kāvye svatantratayā //
analyzed: vyavahārayati yathā iṣṭam su kaviḥ kāvye svatantra tayā
translated: as he wishes, with independence in poetry.

original: tasmān nāsty eva tad vastu yat sarvātmanā rasatātparyavataḥ kaves tadicchayā tadabhimatarasāṅgatāṃ na dhatte /
analyzed: tasmāt nā asti eva tat vastu yat sarva ātmanā rasa tātparyavataḥ kaveḥ tad icchayā tad abhimata rasa aṅga tām na dhatte
translated: Therefore, there is no such thing that does not entirely assume the nature of the desired rasa by the poet whose purpose is rasa.

original: tathopanibadhyamānaṃ vā na cārutvātiśayaṃ puṣṇāti /
analyzed: tathā upanibadhyamānam vā na cāru tva atiśayam puṣṇāti
translated: Or, if presented in that way, it does not enhance the charm.

original: sarvam etac ca mahākavīnāṃ kāvyeṣu dṛśyate /
analyzed: sarvam etat ca mahā kavīnām kāvyeṣu dṛśyate
translated: All this is seen in the works of great poets.

original: asmābhir api sveṣu kāvyaprabandheṣu yathāyathaṃ darśitam eva /
analyzed: asmābhiḥ api sveṣu kāvya prabandheṣu yathāyatham darśitam eva
translated: And it has been shown by us in our own poetic compositions as appropriate.

original: sthite caivaṃ sarva eva kāvyaprakāro na dhvanidharmatām atipatati rasādyapekṣāyāṃ kaver guṇībhūtavyaṅgyalakṣaṇo 'pi prakāras tadaṅgatām
analyzed: sthite ca evam sarvaḥ eva kāvya prakāraḥ na dhvani dharma tām atipatati rasa ādi apekṣāyām kaveḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgya lakṣaṇaḥ pi prakāraḥ tad aṅga tām
translated: And this being the case, all types of poetry do not go beyond the nature of dhvani. Even the type characterized as having suggested meaning subordinated to the expressed meaning, when it requires rasa, etc.,

original: avalambata ity uktaṃ prāk /
analyzed: avalambataḥ iti uktam prāk
translated: is said to be based on that as its accessory, as stated earlier.

original: yadā tu cāṭuṣu devatāstutiṣu vā rasādīnām aṅgatayā vyavasthānaṃ hṛdayavatīṣu ca
analyzed: yadā tu cāṭuṣu devatā stutiṣu vā rasa ādīnām aṅga tayā vyavasthānam hṛdayavatīṣu ca
translated: But when rasa, etc. are established as subordinate in flattery or in the praise of deities,

original: suprajñakagāthāsu kāsucid vyaṅgyaviśiṣṭavācye prādhānyaṃ tad api guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasya
analyzed: su prajñaka gāthāsu kāsucid vyaṅgya viśiṣṭa vācye prādhānyam tat api guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya
translated: or in some verses of good wisdom that are full of feeling, and when the expressed meaning is predominant when qualified by the suggested meaning, even that is said to be of the type where the suggested meaning is subordinate,

original: dhvaniniṣpandabhūtatvam evety uktaṃ prāk /
analyzed: dhvani niṣpanda bhūta tvam eva iti uktam prāk
translated: because it is a mere outflow of dhvani, as stated earlier.

original: tad evam idānīṃtanakavikāvyanayopadeśe kriyamāṇe prāthamikānām abhyāsārthināṃ yadi paraṃ citreṇa vyavahāraḥ /
analyzed: tat evam idānīṃtana kavi kāvya naya upadeśe kriyamāṇe prāthamikānām abhyāsa arthinām yadi param citreṇa vyavahāraḥ
translated: Thus, when instruction is being given in the method of poetry by contemporary poets, if beginners who are seeking practice use it in a figurative sense,

original: prāptapariṇatīnāṃ tu dhvanir eva kāvyam iti sthitam etat /
analyzed: prāpta pariṇatīnām tu dhvaniḥ eva kāvyam iti sthitam etat
translated: but for those who have attained perfection, it is established that poetry is only dhvani.

original: tad ayam atra saṅgrahaḥ🔽yasmin raso vā bhāvo vā tātparyeṇa prakāśate /
analyzed: tat ayam atra saṅgrahaḥ  yasmin rasaḥ vā bhāvaḥ vā tātparyeṇa prakāśate
translated: This is the summary here:🔽In which rasa or bhāva is manifested with intention,

original: saṃvṛttyābhihitau vastu yatrālaṅkāra eva vā //
analyzed: saṃvṛttyā abhihitau vastu yatra alaṅkāraḥ eva vā
translated: where the real thing is expressed by convention, or where it is an ornament itself.

original: kāvyādhvani dhvanir vyaṅgyaprādhānyaikanibandhanaḥ /
translated: In poetic dhvani, dhvani is solely based on the predominance of the suggested meaning.

original: sarvatra tatra viṣayī jñeyaḥ sahṛdayair janaiḥ // / //
analyzed: sarvatra tatra viṣayī jñeyaḥ sahṛdayaiḥ janaiḥ
translated: There, by connoisseurs, the object should be known everywhere.

original: saguṇībhūtavyaṅgyaiḥ sālaṅkāraiḥ saha prabhedaiḥ svaiḥ /
analyzed: sa guṇībhūta vyaṅgyaiḥ sa alaṅkāraiḥ saha prabhedaiḥ svaiḥ
translated: Along with the suggested meaning that is subordinate, along with the ornaments, and along with its own varieties.

original: saṅkarasaṃsṛṣṭibhyāṃ punar apy uddyotate bahudhā // / //
analyzed: saṅkara saṃsṛṣṭibhyām punar api uddyotate bahudhā
translated: And by the mixture and combination of these, it shines forth in many ways.

original: tasya ca dhvaneḥ svaprabhedair guṇībhūtavyaṅgyena vācyālaṅkāraiś ca saṅkarasaṃsṛṣṭivyavasthāyāṃ kriyamāṇāyāṃ bahuprabhedatā lakṣye dṛśyate
analyzed: tasya ca dhvaneḥ sva prabhedaiḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgyena vācya alaṅkāraiḥ ca saṅkara saṃsṛṣṭi vyavasthāyām kriyamāṇāyām bahu prabheda tā lakṣye dṛśyate
translated: And when the mixture and combination of dhvani with its own varieties, with that which has a subordinate suggestion, and with the figures of speech that are suggested, are being established, many varieties are seen in the object to be defined.

original: tathā hi svaprabhedasaṅkīrṇaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi sva prabheda saṅkīrṇaḥ
translated: For example, it is mixed with its own varieties.

original: svaprabhedasaṃsṛṣṭo guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasaṅkīrṇo guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasaṃsṛṣṭo vācyālaṅkārāntarasaṅkīrṇo
analyzed: sva prabheda saṃsṛṣṭaḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgya saṅkīrṇaḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgya saṃsṛṣṭaḥ vācya alaṅkāra antara saṅkīrṇaḥ
translated: It is mixed with its own varieties, mixed with that which has a subordinate suggestion, mixed with that which has a subordinate suggestion and mixed with another figure of speech that is suggested,

original: vācyālaṅkārāntarasaṃsṛṣṭaḥ saṃsṛṣṭālaṅkārasaṅkīrṇaḥ saṃsṛṣṭālaṅkārasaṃsṛṣṭaś ceti
analyzed: vācya alaṅkāra antara saṃsṛṣṭaḥ saṃsṛṣṭa alaṅkāra saṅkīrṇaḥ saṃsṛṣṭa alaṅkāra saṃsṛṣṭaḥ ca iti
translated: mixed with another figure of speech that is suggested and mixed with a mixed ornament.

original: bahudhā dhvaniḥ prakāśate /
analyzed: bahudhā dhvaniḥ prakāśate
translated: Dhvani shines forth in many ways.

original: tatra svaprabhedasaṅkīrṇatvaṃ kadācid anugrāhyānugrāhakabhāvena /
analyzed: tatra sva prabheda saṅkīrṇa tvam kadācid anugrāhya anugrāhaka bhāvena
translated: Among these, the mixture with its own varieties is sometimes by the relation of that which is favored and that which favors.

original: yathāevaṃvādini devarṣau ity ādau /
analyzed: yathā evam vādini devarṣau iti ādau
translated: For example, in the passage beginning When the divine sage spoke thus...

original: atra hy arthaśaktyudbhavānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyadhvaniprabhedenālakṣyakramavyaṅgyadhvaniprabhedo 'nugṛhyamāṇaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: atra hi artha śakti udbhava anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgya dhvani prabhedena alakṣya krama vyaṅgya dhvani prabhedaḥ nugṛhyamāṇaḥ pratīyate
translated: For here, the variety of dhvani that is suggested in an unperceived order, which arises from the power of meaning and is in the form of a reverberating suggestion, is perceived to be favored.

original: evaṃ kadācit prabhedadvayasampātasandehena / yathā
analyzed: evam kadācid prabheda dvaya sampāta sandehena yathā
translated: Similarly, sometimes there is doubt due to the collision of two types. For example,

original: khaṇapāhuṇiā deara esā jāāeṃ kiṃ pi de bhaṇidā /🔽ruai paḍoharavalahīgharammi aṇuṇijjau barāī //🔽kṣaṇaprāghuṇikā devara eṣā jāyayā kim api te bhaṇitā /
analyzed: khaṇa pāhuṇiā deara esā jāāeṃ kim pi de bhaṇidā  ruai paḍohara valahī gharammi  kṣaṇaprāghuṇikā devaraḥ eṣā jāyayā kim api te bhaṇitā
translated: Kṣaṇaprāghuniā devara esā jāyāyā kiṃ pi de bhaniā.

original: roditi śūnyavalabhīgṛhe 'nunīyatāṃ varākī //
analyzed: roditi śūnya valabhī gṛhe nunīyatām varākī
translated: Rodati śūnya-valabhī-gṛhe 'nuññijjā varāī.

original: atra hy anunīyatām ity etatpadam arthāntarasaṅkramitavācyatvena vivakṣitāny aparavācyatvena ca sambhāvyate /
analyzed: atra hi anunīyatām iti etat padam artha antara saṅkramita vācyatvena vivakṣitāni apara vācyatvena ca sambhāvyate
translated: Here, the word anuññijjā is possible as having a meaning that has shifted to another meaning and as having a meaning that is intended but not directly expressed.

original: na cānyatarapakṣanirṇaye pramāṇam asti /
analyzed: na ca anyatara pakṣa nirṇaye pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no evidence for determining one of the two alternatives.

original: ekavyañjakānupraveśena tu vyaṅgyatvam alakṣyakramavyaṅgyasya svaprabhedāntarāpekṣayā bāhulyena sambhavati /
analyzed: eka vyañjaka anupraveśena tu vyaṅgya tvam alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya sva prabheda antara apekṣayā bāhulyena sambhavati
translated: But suggestiveness is possible in abundance by the entry of a single suggestive element in the case of that which is suggested without a perceptible sequence in relation to its own other subdivisions.

original: yathāsnigdhaśyāmala ity ādau /
analyzed: yathā snigdha śyāmalaḥ iti ādau
translated: As in snigdhaśyāmalādibhiḥ.

original: svaprabhedasaṃsṛṣṭatvaṃ ca yathā pūrvodāharaṇa eva /
analyzed: sva prabheda saṃsṛṣṭa tvam ca yathā pūrva udāharaṇe eva
translated: And the mixture with its own subdivisions is like in the same example given earlier.

original: atra hy arthāntarasaṃkramitavācyasyātyantatiraskṛtavācyasya ca saṃsargaḥ /
analyzed: atra hi artha antara saṃkramita vācyasya atyanta tiraskṛta vācyasya ca saṃsargaḥ
translated: For here there is a mixture of that which has a meaning that has shifted to another meaning and that which has a meaning that is completely suppressed.

original: guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasaṅkīrṇatvaṃ yathānyakkāro hy ayam eva me yad arayaḥ ity ādau /
analyzed: guṇībhūta vyaṅgya saṅkīrṇa tvam yathā anyakkāraḥ hi ayam eva me yat arayaḥ iti ādau
translated: An example of the type where the suggested sense is mixed up with the subordinated sense is the verse beginning with the words, ‘This is indeed a great insult to me that my enemies...’

original: yathā vā
analyzed: yathā vā
translated: Or, for example,

original: kartā dyūtacchalānāṃ jatumayaśaraṇoddīpanaḥ so 'bhimānī
analyzed: kartā dyūta chalānām jatu maya śaraṇa uddīpanaḥ saḥ bhimānī
translated: He who is the perpetrator of the tricks of gambling, who set fire to the lac house, who is proud,

original: kṛṣṇākeśottarīyavyapanayanapaṭuḥ pāṇḍavā yasya dāsāḥ /
analyzed: kṛṣṇākeśa uttarīya vyapanayana paṭuḥ pāṇḍavāḥ yasya dāsāḥ
translated: Who is clever at pulling the hair of Draupadi, whose slaves are the Pandavas,

original: rājā duḥśāsanāder gurur anujaśatasyāṅgarājasya mitraṃ
analyzed: rājā duḥśāsana ādeḥ guruḥ anuja śatasya aṅga rājasya mitram
translated: The king who is the teacher of Dushasana and others, the friend of the king of Anga, the elder brother of a hundred brothers,

original: kvāste duryodhano 'sau kathayata na ruṣā draṣṭum abhyāgatau svaḥ //🔽atra hy alakṣyakramavyaṅgyasya vākyārthībhūtasya vyaṅgyaviśiṣṭavācyābhidhāyibhiḥ padaiḥ sammiśratā /🔽ata eva ca padārthāśrayatve guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasya vākyārthāśrayatve ca dhvaneḥ saṅkīrṇatāyām api na virodhaḥ svaprabhedāntaravat /
analyzed: kva āste duryodhanaḥ sau kathayata na ruṣā draṣṭum abhyāgatau svaḥ  atra hi alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya vākya arthībhūtasya vyaṅgya viśiṣṭa vācya abhidhāyibhiḥ padaiḥ sammiśra tā  atas eva ca padārtha āśraya tve guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya vākyārtha āśraya tve ca dhvaneḥ saṅkīrṇa tāyām api na virodhaḥ sva prabheda antara vat
translated: Where is that Duryodhana? Tell us, we have come here to see him without anger.🔽Here the suggested sense, which is not manifest in sequence, and which is the sense of the sentence, is mixed up with the words which express the suggested sense qualified by the expressed sense.🔽And for this very reason, even in the case of the mixed type, where the suggested sense is based on the sense of the words and the dhvani is based on the sense of the sentence, there is no contradiction, just as there is none between its own sub-varieties.

original: yathā hi dhvaniprabhedāntarāṇi parasparaṃ saṅkīryante padārthavākyārthāśrayatvena ca na viruddhāni /
analyzed: yathā hi dhvani prabheda antarāṇi parasparam saṅkīryante padārtha vākyārtha āśraya tvena ca na viruddhāni
translated: For just as the sub-varieties of dhvani are mixed up with each other and are not contradictory when based on the sense of words and the sense of the sentence,

original: kiṃ caikavyaṅgyāśrayatve tu pradhānaguṇabhāvo virudhyate na tu vyaṅgyabhedāpekṣayā /
analyzed: kim ca eka vyaṅgya āśraya tve tu pradhāna guṇa bhāvaḥ virudhyate na tu vyaṅgya bheda apekṣayā
translated: Moreover, if the two were based on the same suggested sense, the relation of primary and secondary would be contradicted, but not if the difference in the suggested sense is taken into account.

original: tato 'py asya na virodhaḥ /
analyzed: tatas api asya na virodhaḥ
translated: So there is no contradiction here either.

original: ayaṃ ca saṅkarasaṃsṛṣṭivyavahāro bahūnām ekatra vācyavācakabhāva iva vyaṅgyavyañjakabhāve 'pi nirvirodha eva mantavyaḥ /
analyzed: ayam ca saṅkara saṃsṛṣṭi vyavahāraḥ bahūnām ekatra vācya vācaka bhāvaḥ iva vyaṅgya vyañjaka bhāve pi nirvirodhaḥ eva mantavyaḥ
translated: And this usage of “mixture” and “combination” should be understood as free from contradiction even in the case of the relation of suggested and suggester, just as in the case of the relation of denoted and denoter, where many are denoted or expressed by one.

original: yatra tu padāni kānicid avivakṣitavācyāny anuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyavācyāni vā tatra dhvaniguṇībhūtavyaṅgyayoḥ saṃsṛṣṭatvam /
analyzed: yatra tu padāni kānicid avivakṣita vācyāni anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgya vācyāni vā tatra dhvani guṇībhūta vyaṅgyayoḥ saṃsṛṣṭa tvam
translated: But where some words have a denoted sense that is not intended, or where the denoted sense is suggested in the form of an echo, there is a mixture of the “suggestive” and the “secondary suggestive” types.

original: yathāteṣāṃ gopavadhūvilāsasuhṛdām ity ādau /
analyzed: yathā teṣām gopa vadhū vilāsa suhṛdām iti ādau
translated: For example, in the verse beginning “They, friends of the amorous dalliance of the cowherd girls…”

original: atra hi vilāsasuhṛdām rādhārahaḥsākṣiṇām ity ete pade dhvaniprabhedarūpe te jāne ity ete ca pade guṇībhūtavyaṅgyarūpe /
analyzed: atra hi vilāsa suhṛdām rādhā rahaḥsākṣiṇām iti ete pade dhvani prabheda rūpe te jāne iti ete ca pade guṇībhūta vyaṅgya rūpe
translated: Here, the words “friends of the amorous dalliance” and “witnesses to the secret meetings with Rādhā” are of the “suggestive” type, and the words “I know” are of the “secondary suggestive” type.

original: vācyālaṅkārasaṅkīrṇatvam alakṣyakramavyaṅgyāpekṣayā rasavati sālaṅkāre kāvye sarvatra suvyavasthitam /
analyzed: vācya alaṅkāra saṅkīrṇa tvam alakṣya krama vyaṅgya apekṣayā rasavati sa alaṅkāre kāvye sarvatra su vyavasthitam
translated: The mixture with the ornaments of the denoted sense is well-established everywhere in poetry that has rasa and is endowed with ornaments, in relation to the suggested sense that is not directly perceived.

original: prabhedāntarāṇām api kadācit saṅkīrṇatvaṃ bhavaty eva /
analyzed: prabheda antarāṇām api kadācid saṅkīrṇa tvam bhavati eva
translated: Even in the case of other subdivisions, there may sometimes be a mixture.

original: yathā mamaiva
analyzed: yathā mama eva
translated: For example, in my own

original: yā vyāpāravatī rasān rasayituṃ kācit kavīnāṃ navā
analyzed: yā vyāpāravatī rasān rasayitum kācid kavīnām navā
translated: That which is active in relishing the sentiments, some new one of the poets,

original: dṛṣṭir yā pariniṣṭhitārthaviṣayonmeṣā ca vaipaścitī /
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ yā pariniṣṭhita artha viṣaya unmeṣā ca vaipaścitī
translated: And that which is the eye of the wise, whose opening is on the object of ultimate reality,

original: te dve apy avalambya viśvam aniśaṃ nirvarṇayanto vayaṃ
analyzed: te dve api avalambya viśvam aniśam nirvarṇayantaḥ vayam
translated: Relying on both of those, we who constantly describe the universe

original: śrāntā naiva ca labdham abdhiśayana /
analyzed: śrāntāḥ nā eva ca labdham abdhiśayana
translated: Are tired, but have not obtained the ocean-bed,

original: tvadbhaktitulyaṃ sukham //
analyzed: tvad bhakti tulyam sukham
translated: Happiness equal to devotion to you.

original: ity atra virodhālaṅkāreṇārthāntarasaṃkramitavācyasya dhvaniprabhedasya saṅkīrṇatvam /🔽vācyālaṅkārasaṃsṛṣṭatvaṃ ca padāpekṣayaiva /
analyzed: iti atra virodha alaṅkāreṇa artha antara saṃkramita vācyasya dhvani prabhedasya saṅkīrṇa tvam  vācya alaṅkāra saṃsṛṣṭa tvam ca pada apekṣayā eva
translated: Here, in the figure of contradiction, there is a mixture of the type of suggestion whose denoted meaning has shifted to another meaning.🔽And the mixture with the ornament of the denoted meaning is only in terms of the words.

original: yatra hi kānicit padāni vācyālaṅkārabhāñji kānicic ca dhvaniprabhedayuktāni / yathā
analyzed: yatra hi kānicid padāni vācya alaṅkāra bhāñji kānicid ca dhvani prabheda yuktāni yathā
translated: Where some words have the ornament of the denoted meaning and some have the type of suggestion, as in:

original: dīrghīkurvan paṭu madakalaṃ kūjitaṃ sārasānāṃ🔽pratyūṣeṣu sphuṭitakamalāmodamaitrīkaṣāyaḥ /🔽yatra strīṇāṃ harati surataglānim aṅgānukūlaḥ
analyzed: dīrghīkurvan paṭu mada kalam kūjitam sārasānām                yatra strīṇām harati surata glānim aṅga anukūlaḥ
translated: Lengthening the loud and sweet cries of the cranes,🔽Reddened by the fragrance of the fully blossomed lotuses at dawn,🔽The Siprā breeze, favorable to the limbs, removes the fatigue of lovemaking

original: siprāvātaḥ priyatama iva prārthanācāṭukāraḥ //
analyzed: siprā vātaḥ priyatamaḥ iva prārthanā cāṭu kāraḥ
translated: Of the women, like a beloved lover making flattering requests.

original: atra hi maitrīpadam avivakṣitavācyo dhvaniḥ /
analyzed: atra hi maitrī padam avivakṣita vācyaḥ dhvaniḥ
translated: Here, the word friendship is a suggestion whose denoted meaning is not intended.

original: padāntareṣv alaṅkārāntarāṇi /
analyzed: pada antareṣu alaṅkāra antarāṇi
translated: In the other words there are other ornaments.

original: saṃsṛṣṭālaṅkārāntarasaṅkīrṇo dhvanir / yathā
analyzed: saṃsṛṣṭa alaṅkāra antara saṅkīrṇaḥ dhvaniḥ yathā
translated: Dhwani mixed with another figure of speech is as follows:

original: dantakṣatāni karajaiś ca vipāṭitāni
analyzed: danta kṣatāni karajaiḥ ca vipāṭitāni
translated: The wounds on your teeth and the lacerations caused by the claws,

original: prodbhinnasāndrapulake bhavataḥ śarīre /
analyzed: prodbhinna sāndra pulake bhavataḥ śarīre
translated: on your body with thick hair standing on end,

original: dattāni raktamanasā mṛgarājavadhvā
analyzed: dattāni rakta manasā mṛgarāja vadhvā
translated: were inflicted by the doe with a loving heart,

original: jātaspṛhair munibhir apy avalokitāni //
analyzed: jāta spṛhaiḥ munibhiḥ api avalokitāni
translated: and were seen even by the sages with desire aroused.

original: atra hi samāsoktisaṃsṛṣṭena virodhālaṅkāreṇa saṅkīrṇasyālakṣyakramavyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ prakāśanam /
analyzed: atra hi samāsokti saṃsṛṣṭena virodha alaṅkāreṇa saṅkīrṇasya alakṣya krama vyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ prakāśanam
translated: Here, the dhvani, which is not directly perceived, is mixed with the figure of speech contradiction, mixed with samāsokti (poetic compression).

original: dayāvīrasya paramārthato vākyārthībhūtatvāt /🔽saṃsṛṣṭālaṅkārasaṃsṛṣṭatvaṃ ca dhvaner yathā
analyzed: dayāvīrasya paramārthataḥ vākya arthībhūta tvāt  saṃsṛṣṭa alaṅkāra saṃsṛṣṭa tvam ca dhvaneḥ yathā
translated: Because the compassionate hero is actually the meaning of the sentence.🔽The mixture of dhvani with another figure of speech is as follows:

original: abhinavapayodhararasiteṣu pathikaśyāmāyiteṣu divaseṣu /
analyzed: abhinava payodhara rasiteṣu pathika śyāmāyiteṣu divaseṣu
translated: In the sounds of the new monsoon clouds, and in the days darkened by the traveler,

original: śobhate prasāritagrīvāṇāṃ nṛttaṃ mayūravṛndānām //
analyzed: śobhate prasārita grīvāṇām nṛttam mayūra vṛndānām
translated: the dance of the peacocks with their necks outstretched is beautiful.

original: atra hy upamārūpakābhyāṃ śabdaśaktyudbhavānuraṇanarūpavyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ saṃsṛṣṭatvam /
analyzed: atra hi upamā rūpakābhyām śabda śakti udbhava anuraṇana rūpa vyaṅgyasya dhvaneḥ saṃsṛṣṭa tvam
translated: Here, the dhvani, which is a reverberating suggestion arising from the power of words, is mixed with simile and metaphor.

original: evaṃ dhvaneḥ prabhedāḥ prabhedabhedāś ca kena śakyante /
analyzed: evam dhvaneḥ prabhedāḥ prabheda bhedāḥ ca kena śakyante
translated: In this way, who can enumerate the varieties and subdivisions of dhvani?

original: saṅkhyātuṃ diṅmātraṃ teṣām idam uktam asmābhiḥ // / //
analyzed: saṅkhyātum diś mātram teṣām idam uktam asmābhiḥ
translated: We have merely indicated a direction by stating this much...

original: anantā hi dhvaneḥ prakārāḥ sahṛdayānāṃ vyutpattaye teṣāṃ diṅmātraṃ kathitam //
analyzed: anantāḥ hi dhvaneḥ prakārāḥ sahṛdayānām vyutpattaye teṣām diś mātram kathitam
translated: For the varieties of dhvani are infinite. Only a general idea of them has been given for the instruction of the sensitive readers.

original: ity uktalakṣaṇo yo dhvanir vivecyaḥ prayatnataḥ sadbhiḥ
analyzed: iti ukta lakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ dhvaniḥ vivecyaḥ prayatnataḥ sadbhiḥ
translated: Thus, the dhvani, which has been defined above, should be carefully distinguished by the good people

original: satkāvyaṃ kartuṃ vā jñātuṃ vā samyag abhiyuktaiḥ // / //
analyzed: satkāvyam kartum vā jñātum vā samyak abhiyuktaiḥ
translated: who are really engaged in composing or understanding good poetry.

original: uktasvarūpadhvaninirūpaṇanipuṇā hi satkavayaḥ sahṛdayāś ca niyatam eva kāvyaviṣaye parāṃ prakarṣapadavīm āsādayanti //
analyzed: ukta svarūpa dhvani nirūpaṇa nipuṇāḥ hi sat kavayaḥ sahṛdayāḥ ca niyatam eva kāvya viṣaye parām prakarṣa padavīm āsādayanti
translated: For, the good poets and the sensitive readers, who are clever in describing the dhvani, which has been defined above, certainly attain the highest stage of excellence in the field of poetry.

original: asphuṭasphuritaṃ kāvyatattvam etad yathoditam /
analyzed: asphuṭa sphuritam kāvya tattvam etat yathā uditam
translated: This essence of poetry, as stated above, is dimly perceived.

original: aśaknuvadbhir vyākartuṃ rītayaḥ sampravartitāḥ // / //
analyzed: a śaknuvadbhiḥ vyākartum rītayaḥ sampravartitāḥ
translated: Unable to explain it, the rules were formulated.

original: etaddhvanipravartanena nirṇītaṃ kāvyatattvam asphuṭasphuritaṃ sad aśaknuvadbhiḥ pratipādayituṃ vaidarbhī gauḍī pāñcālī ceti rītayaḥ pravartitāḥ
analyzed: etat dhvani pravartanena nirṇītam kāvya tattvam asphuṭa sphuritam sat a śaknuvadbhiḥ pratipādayitum vaidarbhī gauḍī pāñcālī ca iti rītayaḥ pravartitāḥ
translated: Unable to explain this essence of poetry, which is dimly perceived by the introduction of dhvani, the rules of Vaidarbhi, Gaudi, and Panchali were formulated.

original: rītilakṣaṇavidhāyināṃ hi kāvyatattvam etad asphuṭatayā manāksphuritam āsīd iti lakṣyate tad atra sphuṭatayā sampradarśitenānyena rītilakṣaṇena
analyzed: rīti lakṣaṇa vidhāyinām hi kāvya tattvam etat asphuṭa tayā manāk sphuritam āsīt iti lakṣyate tat atra sphuṭa tayā sampradarśitena anyena rīti lakṣaṇena
translated: For, it is understood that this essence of poetry was slightly dimly perceived by those who formulated the rules of the styles. Therefore, by another definition of the styles, which is clearly stated here,

original: na kiṃcit // / //
analyzed: na kiṃcid
translated: Nothing at all.

original: śabdatattvāśrayāḥ kāścid arthatattvayujo 'parāḥ /
analyzed: śabda tattva āśrayāḥ kāścid artha tattva yujaḥ parāḥ
translated: Some are based on the truth of words, others are connected with the truth of meaning.

original: vṛttayo 'pi prakāśante jñāte 'smin kāvyalakṣaṇe // / //
analyzed: vṛttayaḥ pi prakāśante jñāte smin kāvya lakṣaṇe
translated: Even the meters shine when this definition of poetry is known.

original: asmin vyaṅgyavyañjakabhāvavivecanamaye kāvyalakṣaṇe jñāte sati yāḥ kāścitprasiddhā
analyzed: asmin vyaṅgya vyañjaka bhāva vivecana maye kāvya lakṣaṇe jñāte sati yāḥ kāścid prasiddhā
translated: When this definition of poetry, which distinguishes the expressed and the suggestive, is known, whatever well-known

original: upanāgarikādyāḥ śabdatattvāśrayāḥ vṛttayo yāścārthatattvasambaddhāḥ kaiśikyādayastāḥ
analyzed: upanāgarikā ādyāḥ śabda tattva āśrayāḥ vṛttayaḥ yāḥ ca artha tattva sambaddhāḥ kaiśikī ādayaḥ tāḥ
translated: meters based on the truth of words such as the Upanāgarī, and those connected with the truth of meaning such as the Kaishiki,

original: samyagrītipadavīmavataranti /
analyzed: samyak rīti padavīm avataranti
translated: they enter the path of proper composition.

original: anyathā tu tāsāmadṛṣṭārthānām iva vṛttīnāmaśraddheyatvam eva syānnānubhavasiddhatvam /
analyzed: anyathā tu tāsām adṛṣṭa arthānām iva vṛttīnām aśraddheya tvam eva syāt na anubhava siddha tvam
translated: Otherwise, like meters with unseen meanings, they would be unbelievable and not established by experience.

original: evaṃ sphuṭatayaiva lakṣaṇīyaṃ svarūpamasya dhvaneḥ /
analyzed: evam sphuṭa tayā eva lakṣaṇīyam svarūpam asya dhvaneḥ
translated: Thus, the nature of this dhvani is to be defined with clarity.

original: yatra śabdānām arthānāṃ ca keṣāñcitpratipattṛviśeṣasaṃvedyaṃ jātyatvam iva ratnaviśeṣāṇāṃ
analyzed: yatra śabdānām arthānām ca keṣāñcid pratipattṛ viśeṣa saṃvedyam jātya tvam iva ratna viśeṣāṇām
translated: Where in poetry there appears a beauty that is indescribable, like the individuality of some words and meanings that is to be experienced by a particular listener,

original: cārutvamanākhyeyamavabhāsate kāvye tatra dhvanivyavahāra iti yallakṣaṇaṃ dhvaner
analyzed: cāru tvam anākhyeyam avabhāsate kāvye tatra dhvani vyavahāraḥ iti yat lakṣaṇam dhvaneḥ
translated: like the individuality of precious gems, there is the usage of dhvani. This definition of dhvani

original: ucyate kenacittadayuktam iti nābhidheyatāmarhati /
analyzed: ucyate kenacid tat ayuktam iti na abhidheya tām arhati
translated: that is stated by someone is not appropriate and does not deserve to be stated.

original: yataḥ śabdānāṃ svarūpāśrayas tāvad akliṣṭatve satyaprayuktaprayogaḥ /
analyzed: yatas śabdānām sva rūpa āśrayaḥ tāvat akliṣṭa tve satya prayukta prayogaḥ
translated: Because the basis of words is, in the first place, the absence of defects, and the use of words that are not difficult.

original: vācakāśrayas tu prasādo vyañjakatvaṃ ceti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ca iti
translated: But the basis of speech is fluency, and the quality of being expressive. This is the difference.

original: arthānāṃ ca sphuṭatvenāvabhāsanaṃ vyaṅgyaparatvaṃ vyaṅgyāṃśaviśiṣṭatvam ceti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: arthānām ca sphuṭa tvena avabhāsanam vyaṅgya para tvam vyaṅgya aṃśa viśiṣṭa tvam ca iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: And the difference in the case of meanings is that they appear clearly, that they are suggestive, and that they are distinguished by the suggested portion. This is the difference.

original: tau ca viśeṣau vyākhyātuṃ śakyete vyākhyātau ca bahuprakāram /
analyzed: tau ca viśeṣau vyākhyātum śakyete vyākhyātau ca bahu prakāram
translated: And those differences can be explained, and have been explained in many ways.

original: tadvyatiriktānākhyeyaviśeṣasambhāvanā tu vivekāvasādabhāvamūlaiva /
analyzed: tad vyatirikta anākhyeya viśeṣa sambhāvanā tu viveka avasāda bhāva mūlā eva
translated: But the possibility of a difference that cannot be expressed, apart from those, is based only on the absence of discrimination and depression.

original: yasmādanākhyeyatvaṃ sarvaśabdāgocaratvena na kasyacitsambhavati /
analyzed: yasmāt anākhyeya tvam sarva śabda agocara tvena na kasyacid sambhavati
translated: Because inexpressibility is not possible for anyone by being beyond the range of all words,

original: antato 'nākhyeyaśabdena tasyābhidhānasambhavāt /🔽sāmānyasaṃsparśivikalpaśabdāgocaratve sati /
analyzed: antatas na ākhyeya śabdena tasya abhidhāna sambhavāt  sāmānya saṃsparśi vikalpa śabda agocara tve sati
translated: because it is possible to express it by the word inexpressible, in the end.🔽Even if it is beyond the range of words that touch universals and conceptual thoughts,

original: prakāśamānatvaṃ tu yadanākhyeyatvam ucyate kvacit tad api kāvyaviśeṣāṇāṃ ratnaviśeṣāṇām iva na sambhavati /
analyzed: prakāśamāna tvam tu yat anākhyeya tvam ucyate kvacid tat api kāvya viśeṣāṇām ratna viśeṣāṇām iva na sambhavati
translated: the inexpressibility that is said to be the manifestation of something is also not possible for certain types of poetry, like certain types of jewels.

original: teṣāṃ lakṣaṇakāraivyākṛtarūpatvāt /
analyzed: teṣām lakṣaṇakāraiḥ vyākṛta rūpa tvāt
translated: Because their form has been defined by the authors of definitions.

original: ratnaviśeṣāṇāṃ ca sāmānyasambhāvanayaiva mūlyasthitiparikalpanādarśanācca /
analyzed: ratna viśeṣāṇām ca sāmānya sambhāvanayā eva mūlya sthiti parikalpanā darśanāt ca
translated: And because the value of special gems is determined by a general estimate of their worth.

original: ubhayeṣām api teṣāṃ pratipattṛviśeṣasaṃvedyatvamasty eva /
analyzed: ubhayeṣām api teṣām pratipattṛ viśeṣa saṃvedya tvam asti eva
translated: And both of them are to be experienced by a particular kind of connoisseur.

original: vaikaṭikā eva hi ratnatattvavidaḥ /
analyzed: vaikaṭikāḥ eva hi ratna tattva vidaḥ
translated: Only the gem-cutters are the experts in the knowledge of gems.

original: sahṛdayā eva hi kāvyānāṃ rasajñā iti kasyātra vipratipattiḥ /
analyzed: sahṛdayāḥ eva hi kāvyānām rasa jñāḥ iti kasya atra vipratipattiḥ
translated: Only the connoisseurs are the experts in the knowledge of poetry. Who disagrees with this?

original: yat tv anirdeśyatvaṃ sarvalakṣaṇaviṣayaṃ bauddhānāṃ prasiddhaṃ tattanmataparīkṣāyāṃ granthāntare nirūpayiṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: yat tu anirdeśya tvam sarva lakṣaṇa viṣayam bauddhānām prasiddham tat tad mata parīkṣāyām grantha antare nirūpayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: As for the Buddhists' well-known doctrine that the definition of all things is inexpressible, we will discuss it in another treatise on the examination of their views.

original: iha tu granthāntaraśravaṇalavaprakāśanaṃ sahṛdayavaimanasyapradāyīti na prakriyate /
analyzed: iha tu grantha antara śravaṇa lava prakāśanam sahṛdaya vaimanasya pradāyi iti na prakriyate
translated: But here, to mention another treatise would only cause annoyance to the connoisseurs, so it is not taken up.

original: bauddhamatena vā yathā pratyakṣādilakṣaṇaṃ tathāsmākaṃ dhvanilakṣaṇaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: bauddha matena vā yathā pratyakṣa ādi lakṣaṇam tathā asmākam dhvani lakṣaṇam bhaviṣyati
translated: Or, just as the Buddhists have their definition of perception and so on, we can have our definition of dhvani.

original: tasmāllakṣaṇāntarasyāghaṭanādaśabdārthatvācca tasyoktam eva dhvanilakṣaṇaṃ sādhīyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt lakṣaṇa antarasya aghaṭanāt aśabda artha tvāt ca tasya uktam eva dhvani lakṣaṇam sādhīyaḥ
translated: Therefore, since no other definition is possible and since that [definition of dhvani] is not the meaning of the word, the definition of dhvani stated [by Ānandavardhana] is the best.

original: tad idam uktam
analyzed: tat idam uktam
translated: This is what has been said:

original: anākhyeyāṃśabhāsitvaṃ nirvācyārthatayā dhvaneḥ /
analyzed: anākhyeya aṃśa bhāsi tvam nirvācya artha tayā dhvaneḥ
translated: The fact that dhvani is manifested by an inexpressible part and has a definable meaning

original: na lakṣaṇaṃ /
analyzed: na lakṣaṇam
translated: is not its definition.

original: lakṣaṇaṃ tu sādhīyo 'sya yathoditam //
analyzed: lakṣaṇam tu sādhīyaḥ yathā uditam
translated: But the definition of it is better stated as follows:

original: iti śrīrājānakānandavardhanācāryaviracite dhvanyāloke tṛtīya uddyotaḥ //
analyzed: iti śrī rāja ānaka ānandavardhana ācārya viracite dhvanyāloke tṛtīyaḥ uddyotaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter of Dhvanyaloka composed by the great scholar Rajanakananda.

original: caturthoddyotaḥ //
analyzed: caturtha uddyotaḥ
translated: Chapter 4

original: evaṃ dhvaniṃ saprapañcaṃ vipratipattinirāsārthaṃ vyutpādya tadvyutpādane prayojanāntaram ucyate
analyzed: evam dhvanim sa prapañcam vipratipatti nirāsa artham vyutpādya tad vyutpādane prayojana antaram ucyate
translated: Having thus explained dhvani along with its varieties for the purpose of removing misconceptions, another purpose of explaining it is stated:

original: dhvaner yaḥ saguṇībhūtavyaṅgyasyādhvā pradarśitaḥ /
analyzed: dhvaneḥ yaḥ sa guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya adhvā pradarśitaḥ
translated: The path of dhvani, which is expressed through the subordinate suggestion,

original: anenānantyam āyāti kavīnāṃ pratibhāguṇaḥ // / //
analyzed: anena ānantyam āyāti kavīnām pratibhā guṇaḥ
translated: By this, the quality of the poet's imagination becomes endless.

original: ya eṣa dhvaner guṇībhūtavyaṅgyasya ca mārgaḥ prakāśitas tasya phalāntaraṃ kavipratibhānantyam /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣa dhvaneḥ guṇībhūta vyaṅgyasya ca mārgaḥ prakāśitaḥ tasya phala antaram kavi pratibhā ānantyam
translated: The other fruit of the path of dhvani and the subordinate suggestion that has been revealed is the endlessness of the poet's imagination.

original: katham iti cet
analyzed: katham iti ced
translated: If it is asked how,

original: ato hy anyatamenāpi prakāreṇa vibhūṣitā /
analyzed: atas hi anyatamena api prakāreṇa vibhūṣitā
translated: Because of this, even speech adorned with any one of the modes,

original: vāṇī navatvam āyāti pūrvārthānvayavaty api // / //
analyzed: vāṇī nava tvam āyāti pūrva artha anvayavatī api
translated: Attains novelty, even though connected with the old meaning.

original: ato dhvaner uktaprabhedamadhyād anyatamenāpi prakāreṇa vibhūṣitā satī vāṇī purātanakavinibaddhārthasaṃsparśavaty api navatvam āyāti /
analyzed: atas dhvaneḥ ukta prabheda madhyāt anyatamena api prakāreṇa vibhūṣitā satī vāṇī purātana kavi nibaddha artha saṃsparśavatī api nava tvam āyāti
translated: Therefore, even speech adorned with any one of the modes of dhvani mentioned above, even though touching the meaning expressed by the ancient poets, attains novelty.

original: tathā hy avivakṣitavācyasya dhvaneḥ prakāradvayasamāśrayeṇa navatvaṃ pūrvārthānugame 'pi / yathā
analyzed: tathā hi avivakṣita vācyasya dhvaneḥ prakāra dvaya samāśrayeṇa nava tvam pūrva artha anugame yathā
translated: For, even when the new meaning follows the old, the suggestion, whose suggested meaning is not intended to be conveyed, is new by depending on the two kinds. For example,

original: smitaṃ kiṃcin mugdhaṃ taralamadhuro dṛṣṭivibhavaḥ
analyzed: smitam kiṃcid mugdham tarala madhuraḥ dṛṣṭi vibhavaḥ
translated: A slight smile, a charming, playful, sweet glance,

original: parispando vācām abhinavavilāsormisarasaḥ /
analyzed: parispandaḥ vācām abhinava vilāsa ūrmi sarasaḥ
translated: A playful movement of the speech, full of the charm of new love,

original: gatānām ārambhaḥ kisalayitalīlāparimalaḥ
analyzed: gatānām ārambhaḥ kisalayita līlā parimalaḥ
translated: The beginning of those who have attained, a fragrance of playful charm,

original: spṛśantyās tāruṇyaṃ kim iva hi na ramyaṃ mṛgadṛśaḥ //
analyzed: spṛśantyāḥ tāruṇyam kim iva hi na ramyam mṛga dṛśaḥ
translated: What is not beautiful in a doe-eyed woman who is touching youth?

original: ity asya /
analyzed: iti asya
translated: This is the case.

original: savibhramasmitodbhedā lolākṣyaḥ praskhaladgiraḥ /
analyzed: sa vibhrama smita udbhedāḥ lola akṣyaḥ praskhalat giraḥ
translated: With playful smiles, rolling eyes, stumbling words,

original: nitambālasagāminyaḥ kāminyaḥ kasya na priyāḥ //
analyzed: nitamba alasa gāminyaḥ kāminyaḥ kasya na priyāḥ
translated: Loitering in their gait, who does not love the passionate women?

original: ity evam ādiṣu ślokeṣu satsv api tiraskṛtavācyadhvanisamāśrayeṇāpūrvatvam eva pratibhāsate / tathā
analyzed: iti evam ādiṣu ślokeṣu satsu api tiraskṛta vācya dhvani samāśrayeṇa apūrva tvam eva pratibhāsate tathā
translated: Even though verses like this exist, by depending on the suggestion whose literal meaning is suppressed, it appears to be new. Similarly,

original: yaḥ prathamaḥ prathamaḥ sa tu tathā hi hatahastibahalapalalāśī /
analyzed: yaḥ prathamaḥ prathamaḥ sa tu tathā hi hata hasti bahala palala āśī
translated: He who is the first, the first, he is like that, for he is the eater of the thick fodder of slain elephants.

original: śvāpadagaṇeṣu siṃhaḥ siṃhaḥ kenādharīkriyate //ity asya /
analyzed: śvāpada gaṇeṣu siṃhaḥ siṃhaḥ kena adharīkriyate iti asya
translated: Among the multitudes of beasts of prey, the lion, the lion, by whom is he surpassed?

original: svatejaḥkrītamahimā kenānyenātiśayyate /
analyzed: sva tejaḥ krīta mahimā kena anyena atiśayyate
translated: By whom is the glory bought by his own splendor surpassed?

original: mahadbhir api mātaṅgaiḥ siṃhaḥ kim abhibhūyate //
analyzed: mahadbhiḥ api mātaṅgaiḥ siṃhaḥ kim abhibhūyate
translated: By even great elephants, is the lion overcome?

original: ity evam ādiṣu ślokeṣu satsv apy arthāntarasaṅkramitavācyadhvanisamāśrayeṇa navatvam /
analyzed: iti evam ādiṣu ślokeṣu satsu api artha antara saṅkramita vācya dhvani samāśrayeṇa nava tvam
translated: Even though verses like these exist, [the newness] is based on the dhvani whose suggested meaning has shifted to another meaning.
